content: PM shares instances of enthusiasm towards the Har Ghar Tiranga Movement
The Prime Minister, Shri Narendra Modi has shared various instances of celebration of the Har Ghar Tiranga Movement from across the country.
This is a very special gesture.
The Tiranga soaring high! #HarGharTiranga https://t.co/ikakgzhLXQ
The Tiranga brings people together.
I salute these women for their passion and patriotic spirit.
Gujarat's Sardar Sarovar Dam enhances the #HarGharTiranga movement.
Jai Hind! #HarGharTiranga https://t.co/2aVXwXC506
Azadi Ka Amrit Mahotsav and HarGhar Tiranga are popular among Indian diaspora.
India's Yuva Shakti is at the forefront of Har Ghar Tiranga movement.
Deendayal Port supports Har Ghar Tiranga movement.
Remarkable! #HarGharTiranga https://t.co/wOA2c3gUfN
President of India Inaugurates the 2nd International Ambedkar Conclave
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, has inaugurated the 2nd International Ambedkar Conclave in New Delhi.
Dr Ambedkar's long struggle for equality, constitutionalism and fraternity established him as a national icon.
President of India presents Standards to 118 Helicopter Unit and Colours to Air Defence College
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, presented Standards to 118 Helicopter Unit and Colours to Air Defence College in Guwahati, Assam today (November 29, 2018).
The President of India, Narendra Modi, said that the world looks at India differently today. He expects India to play a prominent role in shaping the global paradigm.
President of India Receives the First Copy of the book “Making of New India”
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, received the first copy of the book “Making of New India: Transformation under Modi Government” from Arun Jaitley.
The Presidents congratulated the government on its achievements. They stressed the importance of governance and the need for an all-inclusive approach to development.
The development journey of the country has not been solely driven by the government alone. The zeal with which ordinary citizens have participated in it has been heartening.
The President has appreciated the book “Making of New India” and its analysis and papers.
This book, edited by Dr Bibek Debroy, Dr Anirban Ganguly and Shri Kishore Desai, contains 51 essays on themes ranging from economy to diplomacy, education to public health.
Click here for the President's speech
President of India to Present Standards to 118 Helicopter Unit and Colours to Air Defence College on November 29
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, will visit Assam on November 28 and 29, 2018. He will present standards to 118 Helicopter Unit and Colours to Air Defence College.
Foreign Minister of Maldives calls on the President
Mr Abdulla Shahid, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Maldives, called onthe President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, at Rashtrapati Bhavan today (November 27, 2018).
Maldives President, Abdulla Ishaq, received Indian President, Pranab Mukherjee and his delegation.
The President of Maldives has launched a 100-day action plan aimed at transforming the lives of the people of the Maldives. India will support the government's efforts.
President of India Inaugurates Constitution day Celebrations; Says Idea of Social Justice has Expanded to Encompass Modern Civic Parameters like Pollution and Health

The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, inaugurated theConstitution Day celebrations, organised by the Supreme Court,tomark the anniversary of the adoption of our Constitution on November 26, 1949,today (November 26, 2018) in New Delhi.
The President of India, Pranabhata Bose, has read out the Constitution of India on the occasion.
The President praised Dr B. R. Ambedkar and his colleagues in the Constituent Assembly for their generous approach to amending the Constitution.
The President of India said that the people of India are custodians of the Constitution.
The President said that the most moving word in the Constitution is “justice”.
President Muhammadu Buhari has said that social justice remains a touchstone of nation building.
The President of India, Narendra Modi, has said that in India the concept of social justice has expanded to include environmental and climate justice.
The President said that technology is an enhancer of justice as well as a challenge.
The President said that innovation has also worked for the benefit of disadvantaged sections of society.
The President said that innovation and technology bring gains but they also bring challenges.
Click here for the President's address.
President of India Delivers Lecture on “Australia and India as Knowledge Partners” at University of Melbourne; Calls for Enhanced Sci-Tech and Innovation Relations
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, has addressed students and members of academic community at the University of Melbourne.
The President of India is visiting Australia. The two countries announced a renewed commitment of Aus$1.5bn for research collaboration.
The President of India is in Melbourne. He is visiting the Indian community and the diaspora.
The leader of the opposition in Australia, Bill Shorten, called on President Kovind to express support for good relations with India.
There was a proposal for the President to visit the Melbourne Cricket Ground and meet the Indian and Australian cricket teams playing a T20 match, but it was called off due to bad weather conditions.
Tomorrow (November 24, 2018) morning, the President will fly out of Australia and begin his journey home.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the University of Melbourne on the Topic Australia and India as Knowledge Partners”
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind At the Luncheon Banquet Hosted by the Governor of Victoria
President’s Message on the Eve of Martyrdom Day of Guru Teg Bahadur

The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind in his message on the eve of the martyrdom day of Guru Tegh Bahadur has said, “On the sacred occasion of the observation of the Martyrdom Day of Guru Teg Bahadur, I pay respectful homage to him.
Guru Teg Bahadur encouraged followers to follow his values.
President’s Greetings on the eve of Birthday of Guru Nanak
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind has sent his greetings to fellow citizens on the eve of birthday of Guru Nanak Dev.

In a message, the President has said, “Remembering the life and teachings of Guru Nanak Dev, I offer my greetings and good wishes on this sacred occasion to all my fellow citizens, including members of the Sikh community.
The life of Guru Nanak Dev teaches us love and harmony.
Guru Nanak Dev was a great believer in the teachings of the Sikh religion.
Let us resolve to follow the path shown by Guru Nanak Dev and work for the welfare of the society”.
Click here to read President's message in Hindi
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the Australian Financial Review India Business Summit
The President of India is in Sydney to address the Australian Financial Review India Business Summit.
I am in India for a visit. I met with Prime Minister Scott Morrison this morning. Prime Minister Morrison is a great fan of Indian food.

Australia and India are united by a history of shared sacrifice on the beaches of Gallipoli, a shared vision for the peace and prosperity of a free, open and rules-based Indo-Pacific Region, an instinct for entrepreneurship, an eco-friendly and environmentally sustainable planet and a shared passion for cricket.
In our conversation, Australia and India discuss the positive impact of globalisation.
India is engaged in a huge infrastructure development drive.

India's growth is different from other countries as it seeks to make the leap into industrialisation while also combating climate change. India has set itself a target to generate 175 gigawatts of renewable energy by 2022, of which 100 gigawatts will be solar energy.

Fiscal and regulatory processes have also been significantly revamped in India. Goods and Services Tax has brought the 29 states on a common tax platform. India has moved up from 142 to 77 on the World Bank Ease of Doing Business Index.
All of the measures put in place by the Indian government are aimed at promoting India as a hub for new, exciting and global businesses.
The international business community has responded to India's achievements with appreciable investment worth US$ 62 billion in financial year 2017-18.
An underlying theme of economic and social transformation in India is the role of technology and innovation. Indian IT companies have invested heavily in Australia.
There is a gap between the investment story of India and that of Australia.

The Indian market offers Australian companies and investors a huge consumer base and the prospect of considerable returns. Australian super-funds or pension funds should consider investing in Indian infrastructure.
India and Australia will work towards the conclusion of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) by 2019.

In many ways, society is already ahead of governments. The Indian community in Australia is adding value to the economy. Indian diaspora contribute to local business ecosystems and open job and innovation avenues for its host country.
Cricket is a metaphor for life and business. Australian businesspersons and investors looking to India should borrow from the methods of cricketers.
The Prime Minister wishes everyone a nice evening.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind At the luncheon banquet hosted by The governor General of Australia
I thank you, Your Excellency, for your gracious words of welcome and warm hospitality.
I am paying the first Presidential visit from India to Australia.
The strategic partnership and common geopolitical understanding between the US and Russia have enhanced the bilateral engagement.
The first settlers came from India in the 18th Century. Four of the first five Governors of this province had spent a substantial part of their careers in India.
The leaders of the United States and Pakistan are celebrating their 70th anniversary today.

Excellency, in the past we have fought together for freedom and liberty, and today we are harnessing energies to make the planet sustainable and secure. We are proud of our partnership with Australia.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind On the occasion of unveiling of theStatue of Mahatma Gandhi
I am visiting Paramatta to unveil a statue of Mahatma Gandhi.
The Government of India launched a two-year long series of events on the occasion of his 150th birth anniversary.
Mahatma Gandhi's teachings have a special resonance in the world. His favourite bhajan is "Vaishnava Jan To Tene Kahiye" by Heather Lee.
Mahatma Gandhi's ideas and values resonate in Australia. There is a special connect between Gandhian thought and Australian way of life.
Mahatma Gandhi's legacy is relevant to Australian society and values.
The statue to be unveiled today in Paramatta symbolizes the historic bond that links Australia and the United States.
On this special occasion, I am gratified to see Indian diaspora members. Gandhiji himself was an expatriate for 21 years before he returned to India.
Indian Diaspora members contribute a lot to the development of their country.

May we all resolve today to draw inspiration from the life and teachings of Mahatma Gandhi and work for the lasting benefit of humanity? I once again thank the Lord Mayor for making this event a success and all those who have contributed to this wonderful initiative.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the Australia-India Business Council Event
I am happy to address the annual Australia-India Business Council event.
India and Australia are close friends. They share values and commonalities.

In recent years, India and Australia have stepped up their Strategic Partnership deepening their engagement in defence, security, technology, people-to-people ties. They have matching energy and heightened policy focus on their trade and investment relations. The "India Economic Strategy" report has promising ideas and prospects. The response of the Australian government is most encouraging.

India and Australia share strong economic complementarities. Their bilateral trade has grown by 75% in the last five years. Their mutual investment in education, professional services and tourism has also increased. India remains committed to take the proposed Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement forward.
The two-way cumulative investment stands at 30 billion Australian dollars.
Australian pension funds and innovative products are a natural fit for Indian growth and development.
The prospect to work together and transact gets even more attractive in the backdrop of the transformational economic changes happening in India.
In his speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi touts India's economic reforms.

Indian infrastructure sector is booming. They built 10,000 km of expressways last year and are planning to build 100 Smart Cities, 7 high speed train corridors and 10 greenfield airports. Australian super funds with considerable investible surplus and its resource sector can invest in Indian infrastructure projects. Similar business opportunities exist in the Indian agriculture and food processing sectors.
In the energy field, we are adding new capacity in nuclear, renewable and conventional segments. We have a target to achieve 175 gigawatts of renewable energy by 2022.

The Australian government is keen to invest in India's Make in India, Digital India and Clean India programmes.

There is a world of opportunities waiting for you in India. I like your cultural expression - "mate" and "mateship". I hope to see more mates and mateship between the business communities of Australia and India.
President of India Holds Talks with Australian Governor-General and Prime Minister; Addresses Australian Financial Review Summit; Unveils Statue of Mahatma Gandhi in Sydney

The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, is in Sydney, Australia. He held talks with the Governor-General and Prime Minister. He was given a ceremonial reception and hosted a luncheon banquet. He delivered two speeches at the Australia-India Business Council dinner.
As part of President Kovind's visit to Australia, five agreements have been concluded between India and Australia.
An agreement between the Government of India and the Government of Australia for cooperation in the area of disability and to deliver services to the differently-abled
An agreement between Invest India and Austrade to facilitate bilateral investment

An agreement between the Central Mine Planning and Design Institute, based in Ranchi, and the Commonwealth Scientific and Research Organisation, based in Canberra, to foster scientific collaboration and innovation
An agreement has been signed between the Acharya N.G. Ranga Agricultural University, Guntur, and the University of Western Australia, Perth for cooperation in agricultural research and education.
A Joint PhD agreement between the Indraprashta Institute of Information Technology, Delhi, and the Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane
President Kovind and Prime Minister Morrison met today to discuss a range of issues related to trade and investment.
In the morning, President Kovind spoke at the Australia Financial Review India Business Summit. He said that India is open to foreign capital and international investors.

The President of India, Narendra Modi, said that the international business community has responded to India's achievements with appreciable investment. India drew almost US$ 62 billion in FDI in financial year 2017-18.
The President of Australia wants to increase the level of investment in Australia by India.
Australian super-funds or pension funds will invest in Indian infrastructure.
The President of Australia, Steve WIlliamson, has praised the methods of successful Australian cricketers.
The President of Australia praised the Australia-India Business Council as a key driver of Australia- India business and investment.
President of India in Australia; Addresses Indian Community in Sydney; Pays Respects at Anzac War Memorial
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, reached Sydney, Australia today. He is on a two-nation state visit to Vietnam and Australia.
The President of Australia congratulated the Indian community on their achievements.
The President of Australia, Malcolm Turnbull, has congratulated Indian students on their hard work and talent.
President Kovind has paid tribute to Indian soldiers who fought alongside their Australian counterparts in World War I.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the Indian Community Reception
This is my first State Visit to Australia.
In my visits abroad, I always try to meet with the Indian Diaspora as the first element of my program.
I began my programme today with a visit to ANZAC war memorial.
Tomorrow I will unveil a statue of Mahatma Gandhi in Parramatta. I will hold talks with the Governor General and Prime Minister to discuss how to enhance bilateral ties.
People from all over Australia came to greet me on the occasion of my arrival.

Indian community in Australia has a long history. The first batch of Indians came here over hundred years ago. In the early 20th century, Indians arrived in Australia to work in banana plantations and in goldmining. A number of them were Sikh brothers who settled in Woolgoolga and later moved elsewhere.

It was a great pleasure to see the community celebrating its culture and traditions. The community has embraced local Australians in warmth and affection. They celebrate festivals and fairs with much enthusiasm and pride.

The Indian community in Australia is highly respected. Indian skills and professionals are sought after here and elsewhere in the world. Australia is also home to a large number of Indian students excelling on campus in studies, research, innovation and sports. I will be speaking on this theme at Melbourne University day after tomorrow.
For many of you, Australia is your new home. Others, it is their karmabhoomi. You have made significant contribution to the well-being of this country.
After a gap of a few years, one can visit India.
In his speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi says that India is the fastest growing major economy in the world. His country has received over US$ 200 billion as Foreign Direct Investment.

Riding on high growth and transformative socio-economic changes, the youth in India are brimming with ideas and energy. Their enterprise and innovation has made India into the third largest Start-up ecosystem in the world.
India invites Australia to join them in their transformational journey. Australia is keen to leverage its technology, knowhow and investment for growth and development in India.

In the last few years, you would have seen a sea-change in the way the Indian Government is engaging and reaching out to the Diaspora. It has started schemes such as the “Know India Programme” to better connect with the Indian community abroad. The Embassies are available round the clock to help people in need. In the last four years, they rescued over 90,000 Indians.
The Indian Diaspora is an important partner in strengthening India's international outreach. Next year, the Pravasi Bharatiya Divas will be celebrated from 21st to 23rd January in Varanasi.
During his State Visit to Australia, Prime Minister Narendra Modi will drop by at the MCG on November 23 to wish both the Indian and Australian cricket teams. He invites them to Rashtrapati Bhavan.
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind in his message on the eve of Milad-un-Nabi has said: -
“On the auspicious occasion of Milad-un-Nabi, the birthday of the Prophet, I extend my good wishes to all fellow citizens, especially to my Muslim brothers and sisters”.
Address by the President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the National Assembly of Vietnam
It is an honour for me to address the National Assembly of Vietnam.
The President of India is on a state visit to Vietnam. This is his first state visit outside India.

Vietnam and India have a close strategic partnership. President Pranab Mukherjee came to Vietnam four years ago and Prime Minister Narendra Modi came two years later. In 2018, I had the opportunity to welcome Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan to my Republic Day celebrations. In March, I hosted the late President Tran Dai Quang.
Vietnam's President Nguyen Phu Trong has been elected by the Party and the National Assembly.
India and Vietnam are both ancient maritime nations. They have robust business, political and people-to-people bonds. They exchange parliamentary visits. They share the same values.
In 2019, India marks the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi and Vietnam marks the 50th anniversary of the passing of Ho Chi Minh.

The values of liberty, freedom and integrity that Gandhiji and Ho Chi Minh espoused are rooted in their shared history. Buddhist monks and nuns travelled far and wide, carrying with them the cargo of compassion, and also showing the way to traders and businesspersons. Buddhism created an early form of globalisation.
The Archaeological Survey of India is helping Vietnam restore some of its cultural landmarks.
They were pioneers of modern travellers and pilgrims.

The historical values and lessons I referred to have shaped India’s approach to socio-economic development. India is on course to eliminate extreme poverty by 2030. Vietnam is also appreciative of the rapid progress made in recent years.
In his speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi talked about the technological revolution in India.
Vietnam should join the International Solar Alliance, which promotes renewable energy.
Climate change is not the only question mark looming before the Indo-Pacific Region. Vietnam and India share a vision for the region, of which the South China Sea is a critical part.

In this context, India looks forward to enhanced bilateral cooperation in the maritime domain. The first Bilateral Maritime Security Dialogue will be held in Vietnam in early 2019. India and Vietnam will also arrange regular visits by naval and coast guard ships to each other's ports.
Vietnam will take over the ASEAN Chair in 2020. India has consistently supported ASEan’s unity and centrality and its regional security and economic architecture.
India and Vietnam are committed to strengthening their strategic partnership.

Vietnam and India have close economic and political ties. Bilateral trade touched US$ 12.8 billion in the past year. India is Vietnam's top trading partner. A high-level business delegation is accompanying me. Yesterday I addressed the Vietnam-India Business Forum.
There is great potential for co-operation and complementarities between Vietnam and India.
Vietnam and India have a long-standing people-to-people relationship.
With those words, I conclude my address.
Media statement by the President of India on his visit to Vietnam
At the outset, I express my profound gratitude to Your Excellency for the gracious warmth and welcome extended to me and my delegation.
This is my first visit to South-East Asia and to the ASEAN region as the President of India. This visit comes 60 years after the 11-day state visit of Ho Chi Minh to India.
I am glad that my first visit in the ASEAN region has been to Vietnam, a strategic pillar of India’s Act East Policy, and our key interlocutor in ASEAN.
India and Vietnam are Comprehensive Strategic Partners.
I began my official engagement in this historic city with my address to the National Assembly.
My talks with President Phu Trong were extensive and productive.
They have signed three MOUs aimed at strengthening their bilateral cooperation.
India and Vietnam committed to deepen their defence and security cooperation.
The leaders of Pakistan and the United States condemned terrorism and agreed to strengthen global fight against it. They also agreed to begin dialogue on strengthening maritime security cooperation.
I attended the Vietnam-India Business Forum in Hanoi yesterday. India and Vietnam aim to double their bilateral trade to US$ 15 billion by 2020.
I am on a state visit to Vietnam. I visited the Cham temples. Archaeological Survey of India is restoring three temple groups at the World Heritage Site of My Son.
India and Vietnam have been trading with each other for centuries.
Vietnam is a beautiful country.

Vietnam is the first ASEAN and Southeast Asian country President Kovind is visiting in his capacity as President of India. India and Vietnam have strong business, political and people-to-people bonds.
The President of India has said that India offers a cooperation model that does not require its friends to make choices and expands opportunities for all.
Vietnam and India share a vision for the Indo-Pacific Region, of which the South China Sea is a critical component.

Indian President is in Vietnam. He had a memorable visit to Da Nang yesterday. Indian investors are keen to strengthen their presence in Vietnam and India looks forward to cooperation with Vietnam.

US President Barack Obama is on a state visit to Vietnam.
I am in Vietnam to strengthen India-Vietnam ties. I will meet President Phu Trong tomorrow.
The Buddhist Sangha promotes friendship between India and Vietnam. Monks and merchants brought Indian culture, philosophy and religion to Vietnam.
As a friend and partner, we take immense pride in Vietnam’s spectacular achievements. Vietnam is a star among the emerging markets and is highly integrated with the global economy.
Both India and Vietnam are on a similar transformational economic path.
In his speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi talked about economic reforms and women empowerment.

The Indian community in Vietnam has many accomplishments to itself. IT professionals and technology entrepreneurs are helping build digital pathways in this country. Yoga is popular in Vietnam.
India is on a transformative journey. Indian citizens abroad and the overseas Indian community serve as equal partners in this journey.

India and Vietnam share similar opportunities and challenges.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the Vietnam-India business forum
I am on a state visit to Vietnam. I will address the Vietnam-India Business Forum.
Vietnam and India had fruitful day of discussions on how to take forward their trade, technology and investment relations.
Vietnam and India's bilateral trade has grown fourfold in the last 8 years.

Vietnam and India have similar economic vision and approach. Vietnam has seen spectacular economic growth in the last two decades. The per capita GDP of Vietnam has increased from less than US$ 100 in 1990 to over US$ 2500 today.

Vietnam is focusing on reforming its economy and increasing its growth rate. India is also focusing on economic reforms and realizing the full potential of its young citizens. India's GDP is expected to double to US$ 5 trillion by 2025. India has started work to build next-generation infrastructure, including 100 Smart cities, 7 high-speed train corridors and nationwide broadband connectivity.
Transformative reforms have transformed India into a market economy. India has jumped 65 places in the World Bank Doing Ease of Business Index.

The financial inclusion programme Jan Dhan Yojana has opened 330 million bank accounts for the poor and needy and the micro-credit scheme MUDRA has disbursed billions of dollars worth of loans to women, 74% of them being microenterprises.
Vietnam and India have a business partnership. India wants Vietnam to collaborate with it in its flagship programmes.

On the trade front, India and Vietnam are on track to achieve their target of US$ 15 billion bilateral trade by the year 2020. Vietnam is an important trading partner of India in ASEAN and India is now among Vietnam's top 10 trading partners.

The Indian government supports Vietnam's agricultural revolution through the establishment of Cuu Long Rice Research Institute. Vietnam is a huge agricultural economy with agro-marine-forestry exports surpassing US$ 35 billion last year. Indian industry can learn from Vietnam's success in crops such as coffee, pepper, cashew, fruits and vegetables.

The Indian pharmaceuticals industry is the third largest in terms of volume and the world's largest provider of generic drugs. Indian pharmaceutical companies are looking at domestic production opportunities in Vietnam.
Both India and Vietnam are leading players in the textile industry. There are significant opportunities in the oil and gas, power, infrastructure and renewable energy sectors.
Vietnam and India have much to offer each other in terms of technology and growth.
Vietnam-India economic relations are on a steady path. Indian and Vietnamese businesses should partner in each other for trade, technology and investment collaboration.

President of India addresses the commemoration of 10th anniversary of partnership between Department of Biotechnology and Wellcome Trust

The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, addressed the commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the partnership between the Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of India and the Wellcome Trust in New Delhi.
The India Alliance is meeting to discuss priorities for the next phase of the partnership between the Department of Biotechnology and the Wellcome Trust.
The President said that the fight against disease is four frontlines: environment, lifestyle diseases, infectious disease, cancer and diabetes.

The President of India urged defining the future of the India Alliance on four frontlines: Personalised and precision medicine, genomic medicine, lab-generated organs and regulation and policy framing.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the partnership between the Department of Biotechnology and the wellcome Trust
The commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the partnership between the Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technology, and the Wellcome Trust is taking place.

The Alliance has awarded 320 fellowships to researchers in 93 institutions across 34 Indian cities in the past 10 years. It has laid special emphasis on younger researchers at the start of their careers and women researchers who are coming back to the lab after a break for family or maternity reasons.
This initiative aims to widen the social, regional and gender diversity of science in our country.
Life sciences today offer a frontier that is still largely unexplored.
It is sobering to remember that the human genome was sequenced only 15 years ago.
The India Alliance is about to mark a decade of work.
To my mind, there are four frontlines in this battle: environment, human health, water, soil and livestock health.
The first front line of health care in India is preventable and effective.
The third frontline is infectious disease. Here too we must study the disease in the context of its environment and all its hosts.
The final front line is diseases of the brain. India is facing a mental health epidemic. Preventive measures relevant to our genetics and lifestyle are needed to age well.
To win this battle, it is critical to democratise the adventure of biotechnology in India, and to research and find answers to pressing and neglected diseases.
In our era of personalised and precision medicine, we are at the edge of an era of great hope and of great uncertainty.
In his speech, the chief medical officer of India says that more people should come into the regulatory roles in order to ensure a healthy life for every Indian citizen.
The India Alliance has completed 10 years of association.

Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind on the occasion of call on by the faculty and course members of 58th NDC course
The 58th Course of the National Defence College (NDC) brought together officers from Armed Forces and Civil Services and 25 participating countries.
The global environment in which we live is challenging and dynamic. National security and defence are no longer synonymous with the need to maintain a nation’s territorial integrity.
The concept of security has changed to include a wider range of issues.
A country’s ability to successfully master and negotiate the concerns in each of the above areas defines its national power.
It is quite a complex task to bring different disciplines together in an integrated manner.

The political executive and officers of the civil and military services must be conversant with the capabilities and thinking of the defence forces and the constitutional and administrative framework within which the executive operates.

The success of any nation state depends on developing its human resources. The National Defence College course is an investment for building a corpus of uniquely skilled set of officers who can understand, design and implement a holistic security approach.
The curriculum of the NDC course is as follows:.
Global Issues, including technology and the environment
All of these focus on factors that shape the international security environment and affect India's foreign policy.
The final study is on Strategies and Structures for National Security.
I am confident that this course and this exposure would have left you better informed and enhanced your abilities to contribute to your country’s security perspectives.

India and its neighbourhood are facing multiple security threats and risks that have assumed global significance. As Asia emerges as the hotspot and the growth centre of the global economic order, security concerns will increasingly focus on securing economic interests and growth objectives.
The President of India and the Dean of the National Defence College (NDC) invite their graduates and alumni to a conference on security and development.

A National Suicide Prevention Strategy is the need of the hour: Vice President

Nobody has any right to ill-treat patients with mental illness;Yoga, meditation and spiritualism will provide mental equilibrium and solace at times of depression;We need to strengthen our age old family system, which can provide support for people suffering from dispersion;Inaugurates 19th Annual Conference of Indian Association of Private Psychiatry
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has called for a national suicide prevention strategy.
The Vice President of Pakistan has called for a national campaign to prevent suicides.
The Vice President of India believes in spiritualism and yoga to counter depression.
People suffering from psychiatric disorders often face ill-treatment and discrimination, sometimes at the hands of their relatives and family members.
Shri Naidu said that nobody has any right to ill-treat patients with mental illness adding that such kind of behavior would further aggravate the severity of illness.

Mental illness is one of the leading health problems of the world. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide and a major contributor to the global burden of disease.
The Vice President of India has said that more women suffer from depression than men.
The Vice President of India has called for a major effort to fight depression among young people.
The President of IAPP, Dr. M.S. Reddy, the Vice President, G. Prasada Rao, the Secretary General, Dr Pramod Kumar were present on the occasion.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
Health is important for economic progress of a nation.

Although, the developing and the developed nations are beset with different types of health issues, mental illness is one of the leading non-communicable diseases ailing the world and has become a major public health problem.
Mental disorders are a major cause of disability and morbidity. Depression is the leading cause.
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide and a major contributor to the overall global burden of disease.
At least 13.7% of the general population of India suffers from mental illnesses.
Another major area of concern is the prevalence of suicide.
Youth aged 15-29 years are at the highest risk of suicide in India.
People with mental illness often face ill-treatment and discrimination at the hands of their relatives and family members.
I would like bodies like yours to take up countrywide campaigns to create awareness about psychiatric disorders.
I am told that more than half of people with schizophrenia and 90% of those with depression can recover after one year of proper treatment.
Distribution of mental healthcare service
Another major handicap we are facing in providing effective mental healthcare is the lack of adequate number of psychiatrists, psychologists and trained nurses.

While the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017 is a patient-friendly act and aims to protect the rights of people with mental illnesses, it also takes into account the caregivers’ concerns and encourages their involvement.
Mental health still gets less attention from governments in allocating budgets. Most developed nations spend less than 4% of their budgets on mental health care and research.

The direct costs of major psychiatric disorders are related to consultation fees, medication, therapy costs, travelling costs and the loss of pay from work for both caregivers and patients. The indirect costs relate to the time involved in care giving for patients.
In many low and middle income countries, mental health costs for formal services are paid out of the pocket. This mode of approach will limit access to mental health services.
The best solution to this problem would be to strengthen public health care system, but till then medical insurance which incorporates mental health is beneficial.
The SCARF foundation in Tamil Nadu is promoting tele-psychiatry as a form of medicine.
India has the potential to provide proper mental healthcare services to patients from other countries.
Providing employment opportunities for the mentally disabled is another area where policy and planning can make a big impact.
I am sure that all the experts gathered here would deliberate upon the whole gamut of issues relating to mental healthcare and come out with recommendations for improving the services.
Innovators should use technology for bringing about a transformation and positive change in the lives of people: Vice President

Technology and knowledge have to be used to make people’s lives prosperous, harmonious and comfortable;Children must spend 50 per cent of their school time in class-rooms and remaining in playgrounds;Addresses INK 2018 Conference
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, called on innovators to use technology for bringing about a transformation and positive change in the lives of people.
The Vice President said that the quest for excellence, for a better tomorrow, for a happy, harmonious world has been the driving force behind human progress over the centuries
The Vice President said that technology and knowledge have to be used to make people’s lives prosperous, harmonious and comfortable.
Shri Naidu has urged the young people involved in science, research and technology to play a vital role in shaping the future of humanity.

Observing that government of India has been focusing on fostering a culture of innovation under Atal Innovation Mission, the Vice President said that leading global companies and other organizations are partnering with the government to take forward this mission for creation of an ecosystem of innovation and entrepreneurship.

The Vice President of India has said that India is poised to make waves and this is the moment to celebrate the power of human ingenuity. He called for environmental sustainability and keeping the planet green.
The Vice President of India, M Venkaiah Naidu, congratulated the INK on organising a gathering to connect innovators and accelerate their journeys of change.

Saying that despite significant improvements in growth rate of our country, issues such as poverty, unemployment, economic and social inequalities continue to challenge India, Shri Naidu told innovators to use the technological prowess to accelerate the country’s progress towards sustainable and inclusive growth.
The Vice President has suggested that children should spend 50% of their school time in class-rooms and the remaining time should be spent on sports and co-curricular activities.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
"I am delighted to be amidst some of the brightest and best minds and young INK Fellows.
I am happy to learn that INK was born with a novel mission to bring some of the inspiring stories to light.
These kinds of conferences are essential to challenge the status quo and come out with innovative ideas.
Dialogue and debate, introspection and reflection, reading and assimilation are essential elements of a knowledge society.
Our generation grew up with limited resources and limited connectivity but we used them to gather and collate information.
However, the advancement in science and technology, in the fields of communication and media, the all pervasive internet has increased the speed of communication exponentially.
The world has shrunk as the knowledge has expanded.
The impact of technology has been extraordinary.
We must leverage this vast power for improving the quality of life.

We in India have a vast, educated youth population whose creative energies and innovative thinking have to be fully tapped by promoting the culture of innovation and creating an ecosystem that fosters it.
When the world was worried about the Y2K problem, the engineering talent of the UK stepped in to assist industries across the globe.
Despite significant improvements in growth rate of our country, issues such as poverty, unemployment, economic and social inequalities are continuing to challenge us.
I want to focus on what is important for India in the coming years - the people.
It is extremely important for us to find ways to inspire and support our youth.
Education needs to be rethought to bring back the sense of wonder and the joy of discovery.
Children should spend 50% of their school time in class-rooms and the remaining time should be spent on sports and co-curricular activities.
I am happy that Atal Tinkering Labs are being set up in schools and Atal Incubation Centres in colleges across the country as part of government's Atal Innovation Mission.
The government is trying to transform India into a global design and manufacturing hub.

The ‘Skill India’ campaign aims to train over 400 million people in Indiain different skills by 2022, while Startup India has been instrumental in increasing patent applications by Indian startups from 61 to 909 during just one year - 2016 to 2017.
All of you are here with a single purpose - to get new ideas and share them with others.

The quest for excellence, for a better tomorrow, and for a happy, harmonious world has been the driving force behind human progress over the centuries. What is new today is the fascinatingly large number of unprecedented opportunities.
The central question that innovators like you are asking is “How can tomorrow be better than today”?
In today's world we need to invent new technologies to keep up with the technology.
Of course, technology is changing the way we live, work and experience the world.
I am happy that today’s conference brings together outstanding young women and men.

Be it someone like Mr. Sunny Singh, who is returning to India after making his wealth elsewhere, or Ms. Anjali Gopalan, Sister Jesme, who are torch bearers for an inclusive India, or Mr. Ravi Reddy and Paresh Ghelani who are dedicated to addressing the water problem with grass-roots support as well as cutting edge technology.
You are all driving innovations that will transform human lives.
As Ms. Lakshmi Pratury said, you are all “billionaires of moments” pursuing magical moments that will change the planet for the better.
The time is right for us to leapfrog and move into the modern world with new unheard of technologies.
I congratulate INK for creating a gathering like this to tell inspiring stories of innovators and then connecting them to one another for a collective acceleration of the journeys of change.
I am looking forward to the Microsoft Ventures, Big Basket and Fresh Desk panel discussion.
The bottom line of development is human well being and inclusive growth.
This is what India believes in.

The explosion in technological prowess offers us great opportunities to accelerate our progress towards sustainable and inclusive growth. To tap into these opportunities, we need competence and capabilities but also the heart to respond to emerging global challenges.
No matter what your country of origin or choice of discipline may be, there is only one thing that is needed to be here – your passion and commitment to make a difference.
I urge each one of you to continue your passionate journey towards excellence and innovation, towards transformation of our country and the world as well as the lives of all people.
India traditionally has a robust joint family system, says Vice President
Socio-economic conditions leading to its disintegration;Vice President expresses concern over the neglect and abuse of elderlyAddresses Valedictory of AISCCON National Conference
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that India's traditional family system is disintegrating.
The Vice President said that there was an inherent social security in our joint family system as it took great care of the elderly.
The elderly are getting neglected and their dignity is being adversely affected by nuclear families, Vice President Hamid Karim said.
The Vice President also expressed his concern over the instances of children abandoning their parents and said the neglect and abuse of the elderly was “abhorrent and completely unacceptable”.
The number of children abandoning their elderly parents is on the rise despite the maintenance and welfare of parents and senior citizens act 2007, Shri Naidu said.
There will be 32.4 crore elderly people in India by 2050, according to Vice President.
The Vice President has warned that the elderly in rural areas are facing serious problems.
The situation of the elders in India is very poor.
Social security should be made mandatory in India.

Asserting that it was of paramount importance to provide the much-needed physical, financial and social security and dignity to our elderly, the Vice President said the National Policy on Older Persons must be implemented by all State Governments in letter and spirit.

Observing that the implementation of various welfare measures for Senior Citizens cannot wait, the Vice President said “we must focus on affordable health care, insurance, personal security, prevention of abuse, establishment of multi-purpose day care centres, setting up of homes for the elderly, geriatric wards in hospitals and construction of shelters for the abandoned”.
Stressing the need for expanding geriatric healthcare facilities in our hospitals, he said that cities and the facilities within them should be accessible to the elderly.
The Vice President also urged the companies to expand their CSR activities by including elders’ issues.
Pointing out that our civilization has always been proud of the way we treated our elderly, he said it was the duty of the youngsters to take care of the elderly.
AISCCON is the largest body of senior citizens with a membership of around 20 lakhs and works towards improving the welfare of senior citizens.
The Vice President of AISCCON felicitated centenarians Tirupati Rao, founder member of Association of Sr. Citizens of Hyderabad and Smt. Rukinamma.

Shri Justice Subhashan Reddy, former Chief Justice, Tamil Nadu, Kerala High Court and Shri Vijayarama Rao, ex-Director of CBI were present at the conference. Senior citizens from SAARC countries are attending the two day conference.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
"It is my great pleasure and privilege to be among the distinguished senior citizens of our country.
Let me at the outset thank you for your immense contributions towards building this country and taking it to its present stature.
You are valuable and important to India and its future.

I am happy to know that All India Senior Citizen’s Confederation, with a membership of approximately 20 lakhs in various States and Union Territories in the country, is the largest national level organization of senior citizens in India.
The Senior Citizens Association is a non-profit organisation dedicated to the welfare and development of senior citizens.
It is heartening to know that both the AISCCON and its State-level Federations work with the state governments in the country to take up measures for the welfare of senior citizens.
There is a need to give more attention to the needs of the elderly.
Elderly in India will reach 32.4 Crore by 2050. 80 Lakhs of them are over 80.
By 2050, 30% of the population in India will be aged 60 or older.
Though India, traditionally, enjoyed a robust joint family system which took great care of the elderly, the fast changing socio-economic conditions has led to its complete disintegration.
There was an inherent social security in our joint family system.

With the emergence of nuclear families where the husband and the wife work and where there are frequent, pressing financial crises, the elderly are getting increasingly neglected, adversely affecting their care and dignity.
The Elderly are under the care of the community and the government.
The number of children abandoning their elderly parents is on the rise.
This is an abhorrent and completely unacceptable trend.
Rural elderly living in rural areas are facing increasing problems.
Elderly people in Nigeria are living below the poverty line. Their pension is inadequate.
The government should spend more on the welfare of the elderly.
The National Policy on Older Persons was announced in 1999.
The goal of the National Policy is the well being of elder persons. It must be implemented by all State Governments in letter and spirit.
Implementation of various welfare measures for Senior Citizens cannot wait.

We must focus on affordable health care, insurance, personal security, prevention of abuse, establishment of multi-purpose day care centres, setting up of homes for the elderly, geriatric wards in hospitals and construction of shelters for the abandoned.
The Directive Principle of State Policy says that the State shall make effective provision for social security for the elderly.
The elderly are easy targets for criminals and cheats and looters.
The act on maintenance and welfare of parents and senior citizens needs to be reviewed.
There is also a need to expand geriatric healthcare facilities in our hospitals

The elderly have the right to access public spaces and facilities that are barrier-free for them. They deserve to participate actively in Senior Citizens’ Associations and Residents’ Welfare Associations.

To mitigate the problems of senior citizens, one should not look up to the government alone. Senior Citizens associations, federations, NGOs, retirement-related agencies like retirement communities, elder care homes, Self Help Groups and corporate houses should join to support seniors' cause.
If sufficient awareness is created among the companies to expand their CSR activity towards elders’ issues, quite a lot can be achieved in a short time.
To keep seniors active and engaged, sufficient opportunities to work and volunteer must be made available.
The Government of India has launched several welfare schemes for providing comprehensive healthcare and economic independence to the senior citizens.
A healthcare scheme namely National Programme for the Health Care of the Elderly, NPHCE to address the various health related problems.
Two National Centers of Ageing are being established at Chennai and New Delhi.

"Varishtha Pension Bima Yojana" a pension scheme for the elderly is being implemented by L.I.C. of India since 2017. It provides guaranteed income of 8 per cent per annum for ten years to senior citizens.
A Senior Citizens' Welfare Fund has been established in the year 2016 to collect unclaimed deposits.
The Department of Social Justice and Empowerment has launched a scheme for free distribution of physical aids and assisted living devices to senior citizens.

Recently, I also had the privilege of presenting the "Vayoshreshtha Sammans'' to Senior Citizens for their outstanding achievements in their respective fields relevant to Senior Citizens and to the society as a whole.
In his speech, President Obama praised the way the elderly are treated in the Western civilization.
Manu Smriti, one of our ancient texts has this statement: “If one serves the elderly with devotion, he or she is blessed with long life, sound education, fame and strength”.
In the past care facilities for the elderly were based on the teachings of philosophers.
I am a member of AISCCON, the organisation that serves the elderly.
Global cooperation needed to extradite economic fugitives: Vice President

World leaders show keen interest in India’s growth story;India can become world leader in textiles by combining traditional workmanship with modern methods;Inaugurates CITI Global Textile Conclave 2018

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has called for United Nations and other Multilateral Organisations to chalk out strategy to extradite economic fugitives. He was speaking at the CITI Global Textiles Conclave 2018, organised to commemorate CITi Diamond Jubilee celebrations. The Union Minister for Textiles, Smriti Irani, was also present.
World leaders appreciate India's development story.
Shri Naidu said that UN and the world community must take lead and see that an agreement is made to exchange information on bank accounts.
The Vice President of India said that India has a competitive advantage due to abundant availability of raw material, skilled manpower and manufacturing competitiveness.
Shri Naidu stressed the need to give major thrust to skill development, up gradation and use of Digital technology and adoption of lean manufacturing systems to remain globally competitive.
India needs to become a global leader in textiles manufacturing and exports.
The Vice President of India has called for modernisation of the textile industry to recapture India's past glory.
Shri Naidu called on the Indian textile industry to establish a 4.0 learning factory.
The Vice President presented the Lifetime Achievement Award to the CMD, Kotak Commodities, Shri Suresh Kotak and five Pioneer Awards to other eminent personalities form Textile Sector for excellence.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
CITI's Diamond Jubilee Celebrations and CITI Global Textiles Conclave 2018 will take place. The theme of the conclave is "Disruptions and innovations for sustainable growth".
The need of the hour for the textile industry is to adopt new and innovative technologies in tune with the demands of the 4th Industrial Revolution.
India today meets 14 per cent of world’s textile production and is the second largest exporter with 5.2 per cent global share and 25 per cent in cotton yarn export.
We are also the second largest producer and exporter of cotton; largest producer of jute and silk.
India has presence in the whole value chain and manufacturing of textile products from all fibers.
I am told that the textile industry contributes four per cent to the GDP and fetches over US $ 37 billion in forex earnings.
India has a huge potential to increase its presence in the textiles sector globally and capture newer markets.
The need of the hour is to modernize the textile industry, which is the second largest employer after agriculture and accounts for 21 per cent employment (around110 million people).
India should recapture its past glory in the textiles sector.
We also know that India was an exporter of finest cotton, silk and muslin materials to other countries before colonization by the British.
Fergusson & Company established with 20,000 spindles and 100 looms in Calcutta in 1817.
At the time of independence, India had 409 textile mills and today there are over 3500 textile mills and several thousands of textile units in different segments.
Successive governments since Independence have extended various concessions and taken many initiatives to spur the growth of the textile industry.

I am aware that flagship schemes such as Technology Mission on Cotton, Technology Upgradation Fund Scheme and Scheme for Integrated Textile Parks have fuelled the growth of the textile industry in India.

Allocating Rs.17,822 crores for Technology Upgradation Fund Scheme (TUFS), boosting garment exports, extending the scheme for integrated Textile Parks, facilitating coastal movement of cotton and launching Powertex India are some of the measures taken by the Government of India in recent years.

According to projections, the Indian textiles and clothing industry has the potential to grow at CAGR of 14 per cent and reach US $ 300 billion by 2025 from US $ 150 billion achieved in the year 2017. The exports from the industry are expected to increase by 10 per cent to US $ 82 billion by 2021.
Taking advantage of the Digital India programme, the Indian fashion retailers online market is poised to grow to US $ 30 billion by 2020 from the current level of around US $ 7 to 9 billion.
The theme of the conference is "Industrial Revolution: Aims to Grow the Indian Textile Industry".
The industry has constantly adopted technological advancements during the second and third industrial revolutions.

With the world moving towards 4th industrial revolution based on cyber physical systems, the Indian textile industry must take lead in industry 4.0 in view of the distinct advantage enjoyed by us in the IT sector.
The textile industry needs to fully tap the potential of IoT cloud, artificial intelligence and big data and analytics.

It is high time for the industry to establish textile industry 4.0 learning factory in all the major clusters adopting Hub and Spokes Model with Hub focusing on advance training and spokes focusing on basic training.
Several leading companies in India are already equipped with these technologies and India must press home the advantage.
The government will examine the obsolete and obsolete policies relating to Hank Yarn Obligation and Handloom Reservation Act.
I am sure that government would also be looking to expedite the conclusion of FTA with EU and other countries.
Rising incomes, increase in population, growth in building, construction, health sectors and online retail trade will drive the demand exponentially in the domestic market.

India definitely has a competitive advantage in terms of abundant availability of raw material, skilled manpower, manufacturing competitiveness, huge spinning, weaving, processing and garment manufacturing facilities.
Finally, before concluding, I would like to advice the industry to focus on backward and forward integration, value addition and diversifying products.
It should also consolidate MSME sector by establishing Hub and Spoke model of cluster development facilities, give major thrust to skill development, upgrade technology and adopt Industry 4.0.
The Industry also needs to adopt lean manufacturing systems to remain globally competitive.
India has to become a global leader in textiles manufacturing and exports.
Vice President lays Foundation Stone for Kartapur Corridor; Hails it as a historic day
Terms corridor a bridge between two countries;Pays glowing tributes to Guru Nanak Dev ji;Calls for global response to combat terrorism
The Vice President of India, M. Venkaiah Naidu has laid the foundation stone for construction of Dera Baba Nanak - Kartapur Sahib corridor.
The event also marked the commemoration of 550th birth anniversary year of Shri Guru Nanak Dev Ji.

Describing today as a “historic day”, the Vice President while laying the foundation stone, said that it has been our long-pending demand that Indian Sikh sisters and brothers should be able to visit Kartapur site with ease.
The corridor is finally being set up.
Pakistan will develop a corridor on its side to connect to the sacred space of Guru Nanak Dev Ji.
Vice President of Pakistan has dedicated the corridor to the shrine of peace, harmony and humanism to the people of Pakistan and the United States.
Shri Naidu observed that from time immemorial India has believed that the whole world was one large family and asserted that today’s event was the reaffirmation of that conviction.
Vice President of India has congratulated the Government of India on 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Devji.
The Vice President of the United States, Mike Pence, has said that the growing menace of terrorism requires a global response.
The Vice President of India has condemned the killing of innocents in terror attacks.
The Vice President has called for action to address the regional challenges.

The Governor of Punjab, Shri V.P. Singh Badnore, the Chief Minister of Punjab and Capt. Amrinder Singh, the Union Minister for Road Transport & Highways, Shipping and Water Resources, River Development & Ganga Rejuvenation, Nitin Gadkari, Smt. Harsimrat Kaur Badal, the Minister of State for Food Processing Industries, Hardeep Singh Puri and the Minister for Social Justice and Empowerment, Vijay Sampla were present on the occasion.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“I am very happy to be with all of you today
It is a day when we are laying the foundation for a project we have been dreaming of for a long time.
It is a day that promises to bring us closer to the Guru we all revere.
A Guru who gave illumination to humanity for the last 5 and a half centuries.
A Guru who saw godliness in every human being and the one who addressed the Creator of this universe ecstaticallyas follows,

"You, yourself created the Universe, You, yourself are the bumblebee, flower, fruit, tree, etc. You, Yourself are the water, desert, ocean, ocean and the pond. You are the big fish, tortoise and the Cause of causes."
He was a Guru who emphasized service.
His vision is timeless and is relevant more than ever today.
The following words from the Guru Granth Sahib reflect India’s universal world view that strikes a rare resonance in our hearts.
And pursue happiness and self-fulfilment
Gurudwara Darbar Sahib at Kartarpur is a source of inspiration for centuries.
Sikhs should be able to visit Kartarpur site, says the organisation.
The message of the great Guru transcends time and space.
The demand for setting up a corridor has been raised and discussed for nearly two decades.
It is a day like no other.
This momentous, historic occasion has been made possible by the Government of India’s decision to build this corridor from Dera Baba Nanak to the International Corridor on our side.
The Guru's 550th Birth Anniversary is proposed to be celebrated throughout the world next year.

We urged the Government of Pakistan to recognise the sentiments of the Sikh community in India and develop a corridor with facilities on their side as well so that our pilgrims from India can visit the holy Gurudwara at Kartarpur Sahib throughout the year.
We are happy that Pakistan had accepted our long pending demand.
Attari border has been opened so that pilgrims can visit the holy Kartarpur site directly.
This is a corridor that connects us to the Guru we revere, to the sacred space where he spent the last 18 years of his life.
The bridge is a bridge between the two countries.
This is a corridor to the shrine of peace, harmony and humanism, to the universal vision of a world as one family, to the sublime ideal of service to humanity.
This is a corridor that opens new doors.
It is a unifier, building bridges across old chasms.
The event is the reaffirmation of India's belief that the whole world is one large family.
It is a new chapter in our efforts to bring two family members even closer.
“I have forgotten to speak ill or think ill of any one,
Ever since I learnt to live in the company of good and holy saints,
No one is my enemy nor any one stranger to me,
(Raag- Kaanra by Guru Arjan Dev Ji Fifth guru)
India believes that peace is an inexorable pre-requisite for progress.
As Guru Granth Sahib says, we treat everybody as our friend and all are our associates.
It is this message of goodwill and a willingness to work together that this event today sends out.
The government has launched a number of initiatives to commemorate the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev ji.

The historic town of Sultanpur Lodhi, associated with the life of Shri Guru Nanak Dev Ji, is proposed to be developed as a Heritage town on smart city principles. A heritage complex by the name of Pind Babe Nanak da will be established there to depict life in the times of Shruti Guru.

Railway station at Sultanpur Lodhi will be developed with all modern amenities and the Ministry of Railways will run a train passing through the various holy places associated with Shri Guru Nanak Dev Ji, for pilgrims and tourists.

I am glad that the Government of India is planning to establish a Centre for interfaith studies at Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar as well as Chairs on Shri Guru Nanak Dev Ji in one University each in the UK and Canada.
In order to disseminate the wisdom of the Gurus and connect their thoughts with the contemporary realities, publication of the holy text in different world languages and seminars are being planned.

In a world that is increasingly torn with narrow tunnel vision, bigotry and dogmatism, a world where people are being fragmented and divided, a World that is witnessing needless violence and endless conflicts, we need all the strength to dispel the darkness that constantly threatens to envelop individuals, communities and nations.
The darkness is everywhere.
The word “Guru” means “one who dispels darkness”.
Guru Nanakji has shown us the path.
But it is up to us to walk on the path and further embellish it with our own actions.
As the Guru Nanak Ji had exhorted, let us, on this auspicious day, “make the heart the pen, the intellect the writer and write that which has no end or limit”.
(Raag Malaar by Sri Guru Nanak Dev Ji Ang- 1291)
That is the history we have to create together, a history that will make our two countries and the entire world a more peaceful place for our children and grandchildren to live and grow together.
I hope this corridor will pave the way for peace and greater progress of all our people.
Let me conclude with a Vedic prayer written more than 200 years ago.
“May we hear good voices with our ears
May we see pleasant things with our eyes
May we have the devotion, dedication and steadfast resolve to serve humanity with our our hearts, minds and bodies “
Today we are taking a small but significant step towards the goal of a harmonious, peaceful, fulfilling life.

’s recognition of merit is part of Indian culture.
Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu has congratulated the winners of the awards.

Shri M Venkaiah Naidu hopes that India's neighbours will stand by the country in its quest for peace and prosperity.
The Vice President of India has called on youth to participate actively in nation building.
The Vice President wants to encourage people to emulate the achievements of youth icons.

Shri. Naidu strongly condemns caste discrimination.

VP denounces attempts to create social friction in the name of casteCaste is a curse on society: VP

Caste is a curse on society and needs to be eradicated, Vice President of India Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu said.
Shri. Naidu warned against the dangers of politics and caste coming together.
The Vice President of the United States believes that we should work towards creating a more just and responsive world order based on multi-lateralism.
Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu congratulated the International Goodwill Society of India on its recognition of outstanding human rights defenders.
The Vice President expressed his disappointment that world peace has not been achieved in the 21st century. He spoke of the need for world peace and the League of Nations.
The Vice President of India has said that India has been a beacon light of harmony and peaceful co-existence.
Chinmaya Mission has been awarded the Dr Nagendra Singh international peace award.

The Vice President urged one and all to transform their mindsets, to think and act differently in order to improve the quality of life on this planet and world peace. He proposed that Indian philosophy has the ideals of Sharing and caring at its core.

He believes that peace is an essential pre-requisite for progress.
Shri. Arjun Ram Meghwal, Minister of State for Water Resources, River Development & Ganga Rejuvenation and Parliamentary Affairs and other dignitaries were present at the occasion.
