Sri Sathya Sai Baba is giving the Sri Sthya Sai Awards for Human Excellence in Bengaluru today.
The Vice President of India Shri M Venkaiah Naidu has said that youth must aim high and strive hard, be rooted in the Indian ethos but willing to learn from the best in the world.
He presented the Sri Sathya Sai Award for Human Excellence at World Youth Meet in Bangalore today.
Shri Naidu praised the people of Sri Sathya Sai Baba's LokaSeva Group for their service to humanity.
Vice President of India, Shri Venkata Sathya Sai Baba, is an inspiration to millions.
’s path is through knowledge, wisdom, understanding and love.
Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu believes that everyone should work towards building India that is free from discrimination, poverty and hunger.
The Vice President of Sathya Sai Trust said that education system must lay a strong foundation based on Indian values and ethos to realize the demographic advantage.
Youth represent the energy that will drive India of the future.
India is on the cusp of a major transformation and is emerging as a strong economic force.
Vice President of India, Arun Jaitley, has called for active participation of civil society, the private sector and charitable organisations like PrashantiBalamandira Trust to transform India.
The Governor of Karnataka Shri. VajubhaiVala presided over the ceremony.
Do not settle for short-term populist measures; focus on long term economic model: Vice President tells States
Political differences must end with polls, there after all parties must work for the welfare of people;Cooperative federalism is the way forward;Presents India Today State of State Awards 2018
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that states must focus on long-term economic development.
The relationship between the states and the centre must be built on trust, transparency and mutual respect.
Shri Naidu said both political parties should practice openness and should not be limited by narrow political divisiveness.

The Vice President of India has said that political differences must end before the elections and after that the ruling party must not be bogged down by dilatory tactics and the opposition parties must be given the space to offer constructive criticism.

Vice President of India has said that federalism and co-operative federalism are vital for political system of India. Sardar Vallabhai Patel's political manoeuvring inspired the spirit of cooperative federalism that inspired him to unite all the princely states of India into the Indian Union.
Shri Naidu believes that devolution of powers to states will pave the way to fulfil the development needs of India.
The Vice President said that development is a collective process and several factors determine the pace of it.
He stressed the importance of building a ‘Team India’.

The Vice President has released a special edition of India Today on ‘India's Best States’ on this occasion. Chief Ministers of Tamil Nadu, Puducherry, Assam, Gujarat and Sarbananda Sonowal are among the Awardees.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“I am delighted to be with such a group of distinguished persons who have an enduring interest in the unravelling growth story of the States of our country.”
I congratulate India Today Group for doing the annual survey on the development of states.
India is progressing at a very fast pace and at the centre of this growth story are the states.
The Chief Ministers of the states have worked hard for the development of their states.

Sixteen years ago, when India Today recognized the increasing role of states in India's transformation and started this ambitious task of measuring the pace of their growth, the emphasis was still on a centralized planning for the entire country.
The Centre-state relationship has moved from that of a donor and receiver to one of a promoter and producer of federalism and cooperative federalism.
According to Granville Austin, the first constituent body of India embraced what was called cooperative federalism. Chief Justice Beg called the Constitution 'amphibian'.
The spirit of cooperative federalism inspired Sardar Vallabhai Patel's political manoeuvring.
Friends, I believe that we live in the times of pragmatic federalism. Indian society is complex and diverse.

This is the reason why ‘Delhi dictated’ dole outs fail to work. Decentralization of decision making and devolution of resources to states and local self governments is the only way to fulfil the development needs of India.
The disbanding of the Planning Commission and the creation of the NITI Aayog was a right step to empower the states.
The NEPT acts as a think tank for the states in their quest for growth and development.
Development is a collective process and several factors determine the pace.
Take organic agriculture, for instance. India has around 30% of the world's organic farmers.
Sikkim has just won a major United Nations award for its status as an organic food-only destination.
India’s development story has some worrying trends, specially the socio-economic disparity among the states.
In the past few decades, the main drivers of growth have been the west and south.

The prosperous south and west have a relatively high per capita GDP and higher population growth, while the poor northern region has a lower per-capita GDP and a lower population growth. The northern region gets trapped in a vicious cycle of poor infrastructure.
The new revenue sharing model between the Centre and the states is helping the states to break free from central taxes.

The states, which were relatively more dependent on Central government grants, were expected to face the heat but a World Bank report published in July 2016 estimated that overall effect of this new revenue sharing model on state finances in 2015-16 had been positive, as the reduction in grants was smaller than expected.
The states increased their spending by more than 30% in 2015-16.
The need now is to bring an end to the disparity in the tax net.
India will need about 100 million jobs till 2026. Around 80% or 78 million jobs will have to be generated in 10 states.
Uttar Pradesh has always played a key role in India’s political destiny. Now is the time for the state to transform the country's economic fortune.
As I was examining the winners in both “best performing” and “most improved” categories, I found that the traditionally laggard states are the ones showing fastest growth.

BIMARU states such as Bihar and Madhya Pradesh are clocking nearly 10 per cent growth rate, often higher than economic behemoths such as Maharashtra and Punjab. Even Puducherry has been consistently growing at over 10%.

In the story of economic development, the higher you climb the steeper the climb, which slows down the pace for the traditional table toppers. 27 out of 31 states and UTs examined for the India Today State of the States survey have been awarded across multiple categories.
Federalism is no longer the fault line of Centre-State relations but the definition of a new partnership of Team India.
In his speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi stressed the need for constructive consensus between the states.
The relationship between the states and the centre must be based on trust, transparency and mutual respect.
Political differences should end after the elections. The opposition should be allowed to express its views.
Once again, congratulations to all the winners and best of luck for next year to all who could not make it to the top this time.
Advancement of Science & Technology, inclusive approach is crucial to become a developed nation: VP

Science & Technology to make people’s lives better; Scientists must address challenges such as climate change and global warming; This is the most appropriate time for India to leverage the many opportunities before it & leap frog in development parameters; Step up investments in Science & Technology to support innovations; Presents NASI-Scopus Young Scientist Awards 2018.

Vice President of India, Shri M Venkaiah Naidu said that the nation must leverage the talents and skills of the young and educated by realizing the demographic advantage of having 65 per cent of the population below the age of 35 years.

This is the most appropriate time for India to leverage the opportunity and leap frog in development parameters by overcoming challenges such as poverty, hidden hunger and economic inequalities, he said, while addressing the gathering after presenting the National Academy of Sciences, India (NASI) and Elsevier awards 2018 aimed at promoting scientific excellence among youngsters, at Vigyan Bhawan in New Delhi, today.
Shri Naidu said that the Indian Science fraternity must play a pivotal role and make India one of the top nations in Science & Technology to improve people’s lives.

‘Advancement of Science and Technology and an inclusive approach to development is crucial in addressing challenges such as poverty, illiteracy, gender discrimination and others’, he said and added that a nation cannot become developed unless these issues are addressed.

Vice President called upon the young scientists to find solutions to the present and emerging challenges faced by the world such as climate change, global warming, sustainable development, clean energy and water and diseases.
The young scientists should look for solutions to the present and emerging problems in the years to come, according to the president of the European Union.

Vice President appealed to various corporate bodies and industries to promote scientific research in the country in a big way by creating an exclusive corpus for encouraging innovative R & D projects and disruptive technologies that could provide long-lasting answers to problems faced by the people.

At the same time, he also called for enhanced investments in Science & Technology to support innovations which would address issues relating to agriculture, environment, health, housing, clean drinking water and security, among others.
The Vice President of Pakistan has called for promoting scientific education in schools.
India's universities are still not able to feature in the top 100 rankings.

He said that one must understand that there is a direct correlation between competitiveness and excellence, at the same time we need to focus on the societal impact of the scientific activities as well.
The Scopus Young Scientist Awards are part of Elsevier’s global initiative to support early career researchers. In 2009, India officially adopted the program.

These awards are given in five categories - Women in Science, agriculture, Plant Sciences and Rural Development, Environmentally Sound Sustainable Development, Biomedical Research and Healthcare and Innovation in Engineering and Physical Sciences.
Shri. Saurabh Sharma, Vice President, APAC, Elsevier, Shri. Gino Ussi, Executive Vice President of Elsevier BV were present at the ceremony.
Vice president cautions against disturbing equilibrium between executive, judiciary and legislature
Encroachment will weaken institutions.
The Vice-President, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has warned against disturbing the delicate balance of powers between the executive, judiciary and legislature.

He presented Life-Time Achievement Award to former Union Minister, Dr. Murli Manohar Joshi, Justice Kuldip Singh Award to a former Supreme Court Judge, Vikramjit Sen and National Award to Dr. Gunna Rajender Reddy.
He said: “ While much can be said for and against judicial activism, I feel that the delicate balance of powers between different wings should not be disturbed”.
The Vice President has said that the roles and responsibilities of the executive, judiciary and the legislature are clearly defined in the constitution.

Expressing confidence that the same healthy trend would continue in future, Shri Naidu stated that any confrontation, interference or overstepping by any organ would be detrimental to the growth and progress of our country.

The Vice President quoted Justice Krishna Iyer, who in 2007 had said that there is a case for amity among the trinity of state instrumentalities and better coordination among them in civilizing the justice process.
Mn. Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu wants to strengthen the judiciary, legislature and the executive.

The institutional structures established over the years were intended to translate the vision of the Constitution-makers into tangible reality, but they need to be constantly nourished through liberal leadership.

Stating that we are at the cusp of India’s transformation into a major economic power, he affirmed that the judiciary can play a critical role in accelerating India’s transformation and in ensuring that justice is delivered speedily, transparently and dispassionately.
The judiciary is overburdened because of vacancies.

Calling for stepping up the pace of reforming the legal system, Shri Naidu suggested that the judiciary and the legislature must get together to ensure “ there is a hastened, transparent process of filling up all the vacancies by recruiting persons with the right credentials”.
Vice President honours the distinguished jurisprudence of Justice Krishna Iyer.
Shri. Naidu praised Justice Krishna Iyer for his jurisprudence and political career.
Eminent jurist Fali S Nariman presided over the event, attended by legal luminaries and others.
Vice President Greets people on the eve of Milad-un-Nabi
The Vice President of India, M. Venkaiah Naidu, has congratulated people on the auspicious occasion of Milad-un-Nabi/Id-E-Milad.
Following is the text of Vice President’s message:
“I convey my warm greetings and best wishes to the people of our country on the occasion of Milad-un-Nabi/Id-E-Milad – celebrated as the Birthday of Prophet Mohammad.
Prophet Mohammad showed humanity the righteous path of compassion and universal brotherhood.
May the eternal teachings of Prophet Mohammad continue to guide people in building a peaceful and harmonious society.”
Mahatma Gandhi is one of the greatest revolutionaries the world has ever seen, only his revolutions were bloodless and peaceful; VP

Gandhi Ji yearned to build self- sufficient ‘Adarsh Villages’; It is time we honor his wishes & go back to our villages;Policy makers of India have to place gender equality and women’s empowerment at the centre of our development agenda;Addresses Commemorative Event of 150th Birth Anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that Mahatma Gandhi is one of the greatest revolutionaries.
The Vice President congratulated FICCI and Indian Industry on organising an event to celebrate the life and times of Mahatma Gandhi.

Gandhi's teachings have universal applicability and timeless value, and they inspired India's great struggle for freedom and gave new impetus to civil rights movements all over the world, M Venkaiah Naidu says.
The Vice President of India, M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that the designing and implementing programs and policies for development should be based on the vision of Mahatma Gandhi.
The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was started by Mahatma Gandhi.
Shri Naidu paid tribute to Gandhiji who was a great supporter of equality and women's empowerment.
Mahatma Gandhi's mission of uplifting the poor was close to his heart. His philosophy influenced leaders like Deen Dayal Upadhyay.
Vice President Arunachala Yousaf Rizvi has paid tribute to Mahatma Gandhi.
The FICCI, KVIC, Vinai Kumar Saxena, the Secretary, Ministry of Drinking Water & Sanitation, Shri Parameshwaran Iyer and other dignitaries were present on the occasion.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
Mahatma Gandhi's 150th birthday is celebrated today.
Gandhi is India’s spiritual leader.
The Federation of Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry organises an event to celebrate the life and times of Mahatma.
Gandhiji's principles of liberty, dignity and equality have universal applicability and timeless value.
Gandhi's philosophy of life is based on his love for mankind.
Mahatma Gandhi's revolutions were bloodless and peaceful.
He was a great believer in non violence and non-aggression.
He believed that non-violence is the greatest force at the disposal of mankind.
Martin Luther King Jr. adopted non-violence as the weapon of choice to help millions of African Americans fight for their rights.
Nelson Mandela often cited Gandji ji as one of his great teachers and acknowledged that Gandhi’s ideas had played a vital role in South Africa’s transformation, aiding in the overthrow of apartheid.
Friends, Gandhiji envisioned a self-reliant India. It has been the endeavour of various governments to fulfil the dreams of their forefathers.
The current government has launched several ambitious nation building initiatives in line with the Mahatma's vision.
Mahatma Gandhi's vision for an India free from poverty, discrimination and social evils was central to his teachings.
Gandhi Ji was an ardent believer in self-reliance. Gandhi Ji wanted to build self-sufficient and harmonious “Adarsh Villages”. Khadi was an icon of India.
Mahatma Gandhi wanted India to go back to its villages.
Gandhi ji believed that cleanliness was more important than political independence.
The whole country united for the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.
The government and private sector have built close to 9 crore toilets in the last 4 years.

Gandhi ji was a great believer in developing higher and higher skills. Today, when we talk about the gap between what industry demands and what education system provides, the necessity for skills training becomes evident.
In order to reap the demographic dividend, we need to undertake massive skilling drives to make people, especially the youth more employable and productive.
Gandhiji was an ardent believer in equality and relentlessly spoke of women empowerment. His mother Pultibai, his wife Kasturba and other women influenced him greatly.
Gandhi ji once said that women are equal to men. Indian women continue to lead in different walks of life but the country still lags behind on gender equality.
I urge all the planners and policy makes of our country to place gender equality and women’s empowerment at the center of every single social and economic development plan.
Gandhiji stood for principles of equality, justice and brotherhood.
In his famous Talisman, he said that he will give you a talisman whenever you are in doubt or when the self gets too much with you.
Antyodaya or the uplifting of the poorest, most deprived groups of people was a mission close to the Mahatma's heart. His philosophy influenced leaders like Deen Dayal Upadhyay.
Let us all strive together to realise Gandhiji’s dreams and usher in a ‘Ram Rajya’ where all are equal and there is no discrimination.
The Mahatma believes in Ramrajya of his dream that guarantees equal rights for prince and pauper.
I congratulate FICCI on its initiative to promote the message of Mahatma Gandhi.
Rajashree Birla, the daughter of Aditya Birlas, received a donation from the Adityas for distribution of Charkhas.
We need to re-engineer our entire education system; the ‘One Size Fits All’ approach will not take us anywhere: Vice President

Take the benefits of education and the opportunities it opens up to the last mile;Universities have responsibility of moulding our young people into productive and enlightened citizens;Private sector should cross subsidise education for the poor and the needy;Addresses the 95th Annual Convocation of University of Delhi
The Vice President of India Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu was addressing the convocation of the University of Delhi.

The Vice President congratulated the University and said that the vision and mission of the University truly reflect its long-term commitment to nation building and an unflinching adherence to universal human values.

Shri Naidu observed that India had undertaken a long and arduous, yet rewarding journey in the field of education, from the “Guru –Shishya parampara” of learning under the shadow of a tree in the ancient times, to becoming the third largest in the world in the field of higher education.
The Vice President of India has asked the universities of India to prepare young people into productive citizens.

The Vice President of India has said that the rise in the number of educational institutions in India has not resulted in an improvement in the quality of education granted in the country. He warned that the ‘One size fits all’ approach to education will not take us anywhere.
Shri Naidu urged students not to limit themselves by their degrees and mark lists.
The Vice President of India wants to restore India’s ancient glory as a prime destination of quality higher education.
The Vice President of India warned that India is on the cusp of a demographic dividend, as 65% of its population is below 35 years of age.

The minister of state for human resources development, Shri Satyapal Singh, the Vice Chancellor of the University, Prof. Yogesh Tyagi, students, faculty and staff of Delhi University attended the graduation ceremony.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
The convocation of the University of Delhi is taking place.
It is a privilege to be among the brightest young minds of India.
The University of Delhi was established in 1922. It is a premier educational body of India. It has been ranked No. 1 by US News Global Top University Ranking.
The University of Hyderabad was established in 1891. It is a premier institution of higher education catering to the needs of more than 6 lakh students.
The well-structured education programmes of the University are widely acknowledged both within India and globally for their innovative teaching-learning pedagogies and modern infrastructural support.
The University's mission is to promote national building and an unflinching adherence to universal human values.
On this 95th Convocation, I congratulate the University of Delhi when it celebrates one more year of success in delivering meaningful and quality education.
Convocation is an important event for academic institutions.
It is a moment of pride and joy for the degree holders and medal and prize winners present here today.
It is a proud moment for you to graduate from high school.
This is a great day for you. It's time for you to leave the University and find your own place in the world.
Friends, India has undertaken a long and arduous journey in the field of education.
India has more than 33,000 colleges and 659 universities.
India is on the cusp of a demographic dividend. 65% of its population is below 35 years of age.
The responsibility to mould young people into productive, enlightened citizens lies with universities such as this one.
The path to reach this goal has to be paved by the enterprising, intelligent and resourceful youth of the country who are well educated and capable of leading the country forward.
Education is the main instrument for socio-economic transformation of the nation.
Education is the process by which character is formed, strength of mind is increased and intellect sharpened.
The rise in the number of educational institutions in this country does not correspond with an improvement in the quality of education.
There is a need to re-imagine and re-engineer the entire education system.
Our current system of education fails to recognize the innate potential that exists within each student and fails to nurture and develop these unique qualities and capabilities.
This ‘One size fits all’ approach got us so far, but will not take us any further.
I would like to urge my young friends not to limit themselves by their degrees and mark lists.
On this day, spare a thought for those young people who did not get an education despite of their merit.
Education is a human right.
India was once known as “Vishwaguru” and its universities were international centers of excellence.
The private sector must play a vital role in meeting the demands of higher education.
It is concerning that there is very little original research coming out of India.
The research profile of the University of Delhi has seen an upward shift in the last years thanks to quality research driven by the eminent faculty.
I am happy to learn that women make up a good percentage of student population in University of Delhi. It is important that young women have more access to the portals of colleges and universities.
The institutions of higher learning play an important role in inculcating the sense of responsibility, honesty, conscience, justice and above all human values in students.

Today as you leave the portals of this institution, I am confident that you will use the intellectual, social and technical skills that you have acquired from the teachers and members of the faculty for the betterment of the nation.
In his parting wishes, the Vice Chancellor of the University of Delhi extends his regards to the students and faculty of the university.
Innovation is for the betterment of mankind: Vice President

India is encouraging the spirit of innovation among the educated enterprising youth; India has an effective and robust intellectual property protection regime; Inaugurates International Conference ‘Asian Patent Attorneys Association’

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that Innovation is for the betterment of mankind. He was addressing the gathering after inaugurating the International Conference ‘Asian Patent Attorneys Association’ here today. The Minister for Law & Justice, Ravi Shankar Prasad, the Minister for Commerce and Industry, Suresh Prabhu were present on the occasion.
The Vice President has called for sustained efforts to improve the well-being of the poor.
The Vice President of the United Nations has said that Intellectual Property Rights are important in the knowledge economy.
India fully recognizes the importance of effective and robust intellectual property protection regime.

The Vice President said that as the communities’ transit to new phase of Intellectual Property based economy, no conversation on intellectual property rights can be complete without considering the balance of the rights and obligations of IP holders and define what constitutes a genuine, path-breaking intellectual property?
India's patent system is consistent with the global regime.
The Vice President of India has said that India is promoting innovation and manufacturing.

Saying that Government aims to make India a major hub for end-to-end indigenous drug manufacturing in the next few years, the Vice President said that the IP sensitive, Indian pharmaceuticals industry is expected to expand at a compounded annual growth rate of over 15 per cent to 55 billion US dollars in the next three years.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
There are more than 1350 participants from over 65 countries attending the annual conference of law professionals.
Being a lawyer myself, and given my background in legislature and public policy, it is a pleasure to share my views with this gathering of intellectual property experts.
The issue of intellectual property rights is of great significance for India as India is the fastest growing economy in the world.
Intellectual Property is one of the most hotly debated topics among policy makers, Governments, legal fraternity, NGOs, academia and research institutions.
According to Buddha, knowledge is a treasure that cannot be stolen nor divided among siblings nor can it be confiscated by the State. It increases when we share it with others.
In ancient India, knowledge was considered sacrosanct and free.
However, now the world market has begun to realise the value of knowledge and intellect, the most critical ingredients in development.
The world has undergone a profound change in the last century.
But like every phase of evolution, the new regime of intellectual Property Rights brings paradigm shift in social exchanges and cultural ethos in communities.
The key success factors in all economies have changed. They include intangible soft assets and intellectual properties.
We in India fully recognize that an effective and robust intellectual property protection regime is essential to attract technology, investment, incentivise innovation and creation of IP assets.
’s Make in India programme aims to increase manufacturing production to 25% of the GDP by 2025.
The government is promoting the spirit of innovation among under-35s by skilling them and supporting schemes like Start-Up and MUDRA.
The government has identified key areas for innovation and manufacturing.

For example, With 900 million mobile telephony subscribers and almost 500 million internet users, Indian market is expected to grow to 400 million US $ market by 2020. There are around 100 mobile and accessories manufacturing units in the country. The policy to digitize economy has led to 300 $ increase in digital transactions over the past few years.
The IP sensitive, Indian pharmaceuticals industry is expected to expand at a compounded annual growth rate of over 15 per cent to 55 billion US dollars in the next three years.
The Government of India aims to boost the indigenous drug manufacturing industry.
To mitigate climate change and global warming, India is focusing on green growth strategies to encourage sustainable development.
The transition to a “green economy” is also an attractive and lucrative business opportunity.

Along with rapid industrial development, there have been a number of initiatives and reforms like GST and the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, as a result of which India’s rankings in the World Bank’s “Ease of Doing Business” have improved from 130 in 2016 to 77 in 2018.

As the communities transit to new phase of Intellectual property based economy, I am aware that no conversation on intellectual property rights can be complete without a reference to the question: how to balance the rights and obligations of IP holders? What constitutes a genuine, path-breaking intellectual property? One can do a costing of a finished farm/factory product but how to put a realistic price to a research product and for how long?

The TRIPS Agreement envisages a “mutual advantage of producers and users of technological knowledge and in a manner conducive to social and economic welfare, and to a balance of rights and obligations.” The TRIP Agreement permits its members to adopt appropriate measures “necessary to protect public health and nutrition and to promote the public interest in sectors of vital importance to their socio-economic and technological development”.
Efforts must be made to give meaningful effect to the socio-economic and technological development needs of the poorest of the poor by adopting innovative and creative balancing mechanisms.
Indian patent system contains some built-in safeguards to bring about a balance between rights and obligations. National IPR Policy has been approved and published by the government in May 2016.
The Indian government’s “Act East” policy seeks to deepen existing relationships with our neighbours in Asia-Pacific region.
I wish you to continue with your good work of promoting and enhancing intellectual property rights worldwide with objectives of serving the interests of owners and users of IP.
I congratulate APAA (Indian Group) for hosting the meeting in India.
Need to re-imagine and reconstruct the higher education system: Vice President

Government should play the role of a strong facilitator for education; Private sector should come forward in the field of education; Universities should become hubs for innovation; Launches Krea University
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, launched Krea University.
The Vice President of Krea University has called for effective coordination of Public-Private Sector in providing education system.
The Vice President of India, M Venkatesh Naidu, has said that there are not enough high quality researchers in universities.
American and European universities dominate the list of the world’s best universities.
The Vice President of Indian Universities has said that Indian universities face a lot of problems.
India needs to create a skilled workforce to meet the growing demand for manpower, Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu said.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
Krea University was launched today.
As I have said before, India cannot afford to be mediocre. Excellence should be the goal of the nation.

Institutions like the Krea University with sights set firmly on the achievement of brilliance and distinction at the global platform will doubtlessly serve us in good stead in our quest for fast track progress and all round development.
According to the philosopher, we are at an inflexion point in human history.
Amidst such flux, institutions like Krea University must emerge as fountainheads of innovation, laying the pathway to a secure and prosperous future for humanity.

India is uniquely poised to be at the epicenter of these developments. If India wants to tap the full potential of its young and expanding workforce, it must fundamentally re-imagine its approach to higher education.
The regulatory environment in India is conducive to the establishment of great universities.
In such an environment, new institutions of excellence such as Krea University may be established and encouraged to set global benchmarks of excellence and innovation.
Krea University is one such groundbreaking initiative. All students will undergo an inter-disciplinary core curriculum in the first year.
Krea is a leading private university. It offers scholarships to students without means to pay fees.

It is truly noteworthy that Krea University, in partnership with the Dalai Lama Center for Ethics, aims to instill in its graduates a sense of purpose and a moral compass that keeps them steadfast as they navigate the complexities of the 21st century.

The education system in India has been facing a number of challenges. India is set to become one of the youngest nations in the world by 2030 with close to 140 million people set to enter college-age group.
The government of India has ambitious plans for higher education.
Indian Universities face a number of problems starting from shortage funds to inadequate number of teachers to falling enrollment numbers.

The profusion more rewarding career choices, lack of adequate facilities for post graduate education and the retirement of the current generation of professors and teachers has created a staff crunch in our centers of higher education.
Krea University is a great institution dedicated to teaching.
The country's enrolment rate in higher education is much lower than China and USA.

The indulgent system which regulates higher educational institutions in India has also lead to the mushrooming of hundreds of privately set-up colleges offering a poor quality education in India in order to turn a profit.
Universities and colleges should work towards improving employability among their students.

The demand for skilled manpower in India is estimated to be 700 million by 2022. Disruptive new technologies like artificial intelligence, robotics and machine learning will alter business prototypes. Firms will have to develop an astute technology orientation or perish.

Accordingly, India has every opportunity to be the future ‘skilling capital’ of the world. Krea University’s curriculum is designed in conjunction with industry to prepare students for the jobs and lives of the future.
It is important to promote student exchanges and host international students from around the world.
The collaborative learning environment created under such circumstances will benefit students and boost India's soft power.
There are many schemes to attract foreign students to study in India.
Future relationships and strong friendships between nations would be created and cemented and world peace and brotherhood would be forged right here in our universities.

The autonomy of universities should not be compromised. They should be allowed to develop their own curricula and their own system of examinations. A strong, accomplished and professional management body for universities coupled with adequate funding is the need of the hour.
It is a cause for concern that India does not have enough high quality researchers.
The objective of a university should not just be restricted to imparting quality education, but to ensure all round development of an individual.
Universities should not be breeding grounds for resentment or discrimination.
A university should be a place of enlightenment, a sanctuary of positive thoughts and safe haven of wisdom and knowledge.
It should be a melting pot of cultures and traditions, an oasis of youthful energy and vitality and an asylum for vibrant dreams.
Krea University promises to be all these and more.
World Nations should arrive at a consensus in refusing shelter to economic fugitives and create a framework for Extradition Treaties and exchange of information on black money: Vice President

While our economy is poised for unprecedented growth we should not lose sight of ‘equity’ and ‘ethics’; Bad loans have crippled many banks, this needs to be fixed quickly;Corporate ethics and value-based business should be given prominence;Focus on revitalizing agriculture; bring in an inter-disciplinary approach to make agriculture sustainable and profitable;Delivers keynote address and Presents Economic Times Awards for Corporate Excellence

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that world nations should come up with a plan to stop giving refuge to economic fugitives and create a framework for Extradition Treaties.
Vice President of India congratulates the winners of the Corporate India and Banks Award.

Expressing great optimism in India’s dream of becoming a $ 10 trillion economy soon, the Vice President highlighted several indicators of policy success such as the rise in the Direct Tax collection from Rs.6.38 lakh crore in 2013-14, to Rs.10.02 lakh crore in 2017-18, an increase of 57 per cent in four years.
The Vice President has called for vigilantism and effective supervision to restore the financial system in the country.
The Vice President said that while our economy is poised for unprecedented growth, there are two important dimensions that we should not lose sight of
Demonetization and Goods and Service Tax have ushered in digitalization and formalization and integration of the economy.
The Vice President of India has urged industrial groups and various companies to adopt an inclusive approach in order to create an inclusive ecosystem.
The Vice President of India has said that a level playing field, institutional structure and a sound regulatory framework are the key ingredients for success.
The Vice President of India has asked corporate India to focus on revitalizing agriculture.
The Vice President of India has said that world is looking towards India with confidence for investment, technology and innovations.
The Vice President has urged private companies and business houses to increase their CSR activities and earmark funds beyond what is stipulated by the government for social good.
The Vice President presented awards to business leaders and politicians.
India is witnessing an Urban Renaissance: Vice President
India and the US should come together and strengthen the existing relationship.
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, met with the Mayor of Houston, USA, Sylvester Turner.
The Vice President of India has said that Government’s initiatives are changing the urban landscape by providing amenities to common man at an affordable price.

Shri Naidu said that the ultimate aim of the Government is to recast the urban landscape of our country and to ensure decent living for the rapidly growing urban citizens besides making our cities and towns dynamic engines of economic growth.

The Vice President informed the delegation about the transformative changes brought into governance by the government, and said it empowered state and city governments in respect of project formulation and appraisal under new urban missions in conjunction with capacity building.

The Vice President said that as 70% of our urban population are residing in 500 cities and towns a comprehensive five year action plans for addressing infrastructure deficit in a focused manner are being prepared for the first time to have an affordable and sustainable urban infrastructure that is inclusive in nature.
The Vice President of India said that 100 Smart Cities are being built now in India and they act as lighthouses to inspire others to build more Smart Cities.
The Vice President said that India and United States being the largest and oldest democracies in the world should come together and strengthen the existing relationship to foster new ties.
The Mayor of Mumbai is visiting India. He wants to strengthen the existing cooperation with India in education, IT, health, urban planning, transfer of technologies and various sectors.
Every citizen must become change agents in building a more empathetic, caring and harmonious society: Vice President
Revamp school curriculum and make it mandatory for children to take part in social service activities;Gandhiji's thoughts are guiding principles for all of us;Gives away Jamnalal Bajaj Awards - 2018
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that every citizen must become change agents in building a more empathetic, caring and harmonious society.
The Vice President of Pakistan congratulates Jamnalal Ji on his felicitation.

Shri Naidu also lauded the contributions of Shri Jamnalal Bajaj and said that he exemplified India’s core philosophy of share and care and strove for women’s empowerment, elimination of untouchability, uplift of the downtrodden and promotion of khadi.
Vice President Arun Jaitley has said that every citizen of the country must draw inspiration from Mahatma Gandhi's teachings.
The Vice President of India wants to preserve and protect the culture and traditions of the nation.
Vice President Mike Pence has stressed the need for citizens to discharge their responsibilities towards society and the country at large.
Shri Naidu is disturbed to learn about the social malaises in India.
The Vice President wants to make it mandatory for children to take part in social service activities in school.
She Naidu also asked private and public sector companies to earmark one day every three months for employees to participate in such activities.
The Vice President presented Jamnalal Bajaj Awards to Gandhian and social activists.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
Jamnalal Bajaj ji is an example of a socially-conscientious leader.

Instances of neglect and abuse of the elderly, growing atrocities on women and lack of tolerance to a contrarian viewpoint are serious social malaises which need to tackled in a concerted manner by all the stakeholders
The school curriculum should be revamped to make it mandatory for children to take part in social service activities.
Similarly, private and public sector companies must earmark one day every three months for employees to participate in such activities.
Mahatma Gandhi believes that all of us need to become change agents in building a more empathetic, caring and harmonious society.
Everyone should observe basic environmental protective measures.
Only a collective effort by every individual will help save the planet from further environmental degradation and preserve its pristine glory for posterity.
My greetings and congratulations to the four recipients of the prestigious award.
Revamp laws governing cooperative sector in view of the changed techno-economic scenario: Vice President

Address challenges such as politicization of cooperatives & bureaucratic control of cooperatives;Take steps to make agriculture viable;Cooperative sector must play key role in strengthening rural economy;Delivers Laxmanrao Inamdar Memorial Lecture on Cooperatives

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has called for a revamp of laws governing cooperative sector in the context of changed techno-economic circumstances. He was delivering the Laxmanrao Inamdar Memorial Lecture on Cooperatives at Sahakar Bharati in Mumbai today. The Governor of Maharashtra, Vidya Sagar Rao, the Minister for Higher and Technical Education, Vinod Tawde and other dignitaries were present on the occasion.

The Vice President said that lack of awareness, vagaries of monsoon, lack of access to market and storage facilities is making agriculture un-viable there by forcing people to migrate from rural areas to urban areas.
The Vice President called up on the cooperative sector to play a key role in strengthening rural economy and help the farmers raise their income.

The Vice President also asked for an increased focus and attention of authorities, politicians, media, and scientists to make united efforts to improve the lives of people dependent of farming and Agriculture.

Shri Naidu said that Cooperatives can help in reducing the cost of production by sensitizing farmers about judicious use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides, by encouraging and training farmers in the use of organic manure and efficient use of water and by collective procurement of capital-intensive equipments and inputs.
The Vice President of India called on Cooperative societies to become important conduit between Government and farmers to deliver benefits of government schemes to farmers.

The Vice President sought for coordinated efforts of Cooperatives, Agriculture Research Institutions, Kisan Vikas Kendras and farmers’ groups in line with government’s resolve to double the farmer’s income by 2022.

The Vice President of Indian Cooperatives Association (ICSA) has said that the country's cooperatives movement has a great history and has made tremendous progress in several sectors of the Indian economy. However, the sector is facing structural challenges and needs to address them.
Shri Naidu has said that Cooperative sector has proven to be a successful model world over.
The Vice President of India's Consumer Cooperative Federation (ICCF) said that 55% of the retail market in Singapore and 36% in Denmark is held by cooperatives.
Following is the text of Vice President’s Lecture:
India’s cooperative movement is the biggest movement in the world and has made tremendous progress in several sectors of the Indian economy.
Thecooperatives command significant share in cotton, fertilizer and sugar production in the country.
The iconic success of Amul has inspired the White Revolution in India with the country becoming the top milk producer in the world today.
The cooperatives sector has a lot of potential but it has to address structural challenges.
Cooperative credit institutions have a number of problems.

Probably the time has come to bring the requisite changes in the relevant laws governing cooperative sector in the context of changed techno-economic and business scenario to make the cooperatives viable and vibrant enterprises.
Today we are self-sufficient in foodgrain production but the sector suffers from structural constraints.
The Government has resolved to double the farmer’s income by 2022.
The Government has raised the Minimum Support Price for most of the crops. Cooperatives can help small and marginal farmers realize the benefit of the higher MSP.

The Cooperatives can help in reducing the cost of production by sensitizing farmers about judicious use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides, by encouraging and training farmers in the use of organic manure and efficient use of water and by collective procurement of capital-intensive equipments and inputs.
Cooperative societies should play an important role in delivering the benefits of the government's flagship schemes to farmers.
This year, the government has allocated Rs 2000 crores for upgrading and building new rural markets/mandis.
The primary agriculture cooperatives should be computerized. They should train farmers to use e-marketing platform E-NAM.
In our country the rural economy is still largely dependent on agriculture. Cooperatives can help farmers diversify into allied vocations.
The Cooperative sector remains a vibrant business model in the world. There are more than one billion members of cooperatives in over 100 countries. The cooperatives account for 100 million jobs.
Even in the service sector, the Cooperative model has been successfully adopted. Consumer cooperatives have prominent presence in Scandinavian countries, Japan and Switzerland.
Countries like Japan, Germany, France and Netherlands provide affordable health care to common people based on cooperative model.
In countries like the US and Bangladesh, Electricity Cooperatives have been successful in making rural electrification a viable enterprise.
In India, the Government is promoting innovation and entrepreneurship in every field. There is immense scope for innovation in cooperative sector especially in rural and agro-economy cooperatives.
Be flexible, adaptable, open & dynamic and strive to reform outdated government practices: Vice President tells civil servants

Harmonize the social, cultural, linguistic, religious & economic differences in the country;Civil Services are the greatest contribution of Sardar Patel;Let common man have a say; include him in decision making & in setting development agendas;Adopt a more empathetic, responsive and inclusive approach;Pandit Nehru saw true nationalism as the collective well being of entire population;Possess the commitment to serve people; It will be dedicated offering to our motherland;Interacts with Civil Service Officers
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has asked Civil Service Officers to be flexible, adaptable and open minded.
Civil service officers have the most important role of translating “Swarajya” to “Surajya.”
Civil servants are the backbone of the country and must not let complacency set in, Shri Naidu has said.
The Vice President has called on government institutions to be more dynamic, adaptable and dynamic.
The Vice President stressed up on the need to adopt corruption free, citizen-centric and business friendly governance so that the fruits of development reach the last man in the line.
The Vice President of India has paid tribute to Sardar Patel, who brainchild the idea of an All India Service.
The Vice President of India, Manmohan Singh, paid tribute to Jawaharlal Nehru, who was India's first Prime Minister.
Pandit Nehru and the iconic leaders who fought for freedom envisaged a resurgent India.

Saying that All India as well as the central services has a crucial role in national integration and national development, Vice President said that they have the unique responsibility of harmonizing the social, cultural, linguistic, religious and economic differences in the country.

Shri Naidu called up on all the civil services officers to work together in unison, complementing and supporting each other with their specific domain experiences and expertise so that India’s growth story gets the much required momentum and direction.
The Vice President asked the officers to adopt, adapt and scale up best practices from the private and public sector.

Saying that enlightened citizenry of today does not want to remain merely recipients of welfare dole outs, Shri Naidu tasked the officers to make citizens have a say in matters that decide their own fate by including the common man in decision making and in setting development agendas.

Asking them to adopt ‘empathy’, efficiency’, ‘impartiality’ and ‘incorruptibility’ as guiding principles to emerge as effective, responsive administrators, Vice President Naidu called on civil service officers to act as ambassadors of progressive thought processes.
The administration has to adopt a more empathetic, responsive and inclusive approach to reach the intended benefits of its policies and programmes on time.
The Home Minister of Telangana, the Director General of the Dr. Marri Channa Reddy Human Resource Development Institute, B.P. Acharya, faculty and 316 officer trainees were present at the venue.
Multilateralism has emerged as the most effective modality for decision-making and conflict resolution: Vice President

India has always believed in the principle of ‘Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam’ which means the World is one family- collective endeavor for collective benefit;Thousands of brave Indian soldiers had sacrificed their lives 100 years ago fighting for the cause of righteousness and in the interest of peace, human liberty and freedom;Vice President Unveils the Indian War Memorial in Villers-Guislain, FranceParticipates in the Global Peace Forum and high level panel discussion titled ‘Dialogue of Continents on Global Governance’ focusingon global governance challenges,Meets world leaders and addresses the Indian Diaspora
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, attended the centenary celebrations of the conclusion of the First World War in Paris, France.
During World War I, Indian soldiers fought with valor and distinction on numerous battle fields. About 74,000 Indians died in this war.
Vice President of India, Shri Ramnath has unveiled the Indian War Memorial in Villers-Guislain.
The Vice President of India, Shri Naidu, is attending the World War I centenary commemoration and World Conference on Multilateralism.
The Paris Peace Forum meet was held.
The Vice President of India participated in a panel discussion on global governance.
The Vice President of India has called for effective multilateralism to solve global problems.
The Vice President of India has told the fellow leaders who attended the Paris events that India will always be willing to play its role in improving the lot of mankind.
Shri Naidu met world leaders during his trip.
Vice President condoles the passing away of Shri Anant Kumar
The Vice President of India, M. Venkaiah Naidu, has condoled the passing away of the Union Minister for Parliamentary Affairs, Shri Anant Kumar.
Following is the text of Vice President's message:
"I am shocked and deeply saddened to learn about the untimely demise of the Minister for Parliamentary Affairs, Shri Anant Kumar.
He has been a valued colleague of mine for years. He was a committed nationalist.
He was a reputed parliamentarian and a captivating speaker.
The demise of a great leader is a big loss to Indian democracy and polity.
The war memorial is a testimony to the valour and sacrifice of Indian soldiers: Vice President
India shares a bond of sacrifice that joins us to French soil and society, says Shri NaiduVice President inaugurates Indian War Memorial at Villers Guislain in France
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has inaugurated the First World War Memorial in France.
The inauguration of a memorial dedicated by the government of India to the fallen soldiers was held in France.

Later the Vice President addressed the gathering at Mayor’s office and said that the Indian memorial in Villers-Guislain would stand tall as a towering manifestation of our continuous efforts to express solidarity with France in remembering the martyrs of the First World War.

The Mayor of Villers Guislain, Gerard Allart, the Ambassador of India to France, Vinay Kwatra, members of the Indian Community were present at the ceremony to recognise the bravery of Indian soldiers.
It was 100 years ago that the Indian Cavalry had charged at German positions during the Battle.

The Vice President said that said that the memorial in Villers-Guislain would stand tall as a towering manifestation of India's continuous efforts to express solidarity with France in remembering the martyrs of the First World War.
He praised the sacrifice of Indian soldiers in the war.
Shri Naidu paid tribute to Indian soldiers who died for human liberty and freedom.
The sons and daughters of India have always stood on the side of righteousness even when confronting the toughest adversities.
Nearly 1.3 Million Indian soldiers fought with valour and distinction during World War I.
The Battle of Cambrai was fought on this very land on November 20, 1917.

The land in Villers-Guislain was donated by the French government to the Government of India for constructing a memorial recognising the sacrifices of Indian soldiers during during the Battle of Cambrai in 1917.
India is a voice for peace and non-violence: Vice President

Connect actively with your roots; participate in India’s developmental process: Vice President tells Diaspora in ParisProgress can be achieved only through dialogue and understanding;Addresses Indian Community Reception
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, was addressing the Indian Diaspora at UNSECO in Paris, France yesterday.
Saying that peace is the only pre-requisite for progress, the Vice President said that in an inter-dependent world, progress can be achieved only through dialogue and understanding.

The Vice President lauded the contributions of the Diaspora in the fields of science and technology, industry, agriculture, art, culture, governance or politics, their strong contributions and successes are as much a matter of pride for France, the country of their settlement, as they are for India, the country of their origin.
People of Indian origin and Indians abroad have excelled in many areas of French public life, with many of them serving in the European Parliament.
Rabindranath Tagore's influence on French thinkers is well known. Indian luminaries like Madame Bhikaji Cama and JRD Tata have strong links with France.
The Vice President of India has said that bold reforms agenda of the Government is transforming the academic landscape of the country.

He said that the introduction of Goods and Service Tax was a major step to have seamless and efficient national market and added that it would make it easier for businesses to establish and grow in India.
Shri Naidu invited the members of Indian Diaspora to take active participation in the creation of New India.
The Vice President of India and the French President talked about the joint efforts of their two countries to promote clean energy.

Vice President of India, Shri Ramachandran, met with Audrey Azoulay, Director General of UNESCO. They discussed India's efforts to achieve the 2030 agenda for Sustainable Development, especially in all the fields including education.
The Vice President is in Paris to attend the centenary year of the end of First World War. He will pay homage to the martyrs of that war at Arc d’ Trionphe.
He will also inaugurate the Indian Armed Forces Memorial at Villers Guislain as a tribute to several thousands of Indian soldiers whose gallantry and dedication have earned worldwide recognition.
Shri Naidu’s visit France assumes significance as India and France are celebrating two decades of strategic partnership this year.
Vice President to embark on a State visit to France
VP to attend Paris Peace Forum held to commemorate the centenary of the end to the First World WarShri Naidu will also unveil the Indian Armed Forces Memorial

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, will visit Paris from 9 to 11 November 2018 to represent Government of India in the activities commemorating the centenary of the Armistice of World War I.
India will take part in the Armistice Centenary ceremony.
The Vice President of France will attend the ceremony to commemorate the armistice of World War I at Arc de Triomphe on 11 November.
As part of the Armistice Centenary, the French Government will also be hosting the Paris Peace Forum, which will take place in Paris from 11-13 November 2018.
The aim of the Paris Peace Forum is to establish a global platform for discussion and debate with special emphasis on civil society initiatives.
The Vice President of the United States will take part in a panel discussion on global governance.
The Vice President will address the Indian community on 9 November 2018 and will inaugurate the Indian War Memorial at Villers Guislain on 10 November 2018.
Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu will attend the Exhibition of Indian Armed Forces during the World War I.
He will also hold a number of bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the Paris Peace Forum.
After completing of his visit to France, the Vice President is scheduled to return to New Delhi on November 12th morning.
Vice President Greets People on the eve of Deepawali
The Vice President of India, M. Venkaiah Naidu, has congratulated people on the festival of Deepawali.
Following is the text of Vice President’s message:
“I extend my warm greetings and good wishes to the people of our country on the auspicious occasion of Deepawali, the festival of lights.
Celebrated with traditional fervor and zeal, Deepawali is a festival celebrating the victory of Good over Evil and reaffirms faith in Lord Rama.
May this festival bring illumination, peace, prosperity and happiness in our lives.”
India’s commitment to support Africa has been unequivocally acknowledged by the African leadership: Vice President

Inaugurates 'India for Humanity' meant to commemorate the 150 birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi in Malawi;Launches the very first Jaipur Foot Camp in this series;Vice President successfully completes 3-nation Africa Visit
Venkaiah Naidu, the Vice President of India has completed his three-nation visit to Botswana, Zimbabwe and Malawi.
The President of Botswana broke protocol and met the Vice President of Mozambique and Zimbabwe at the airport.
The President of Zimbabwe and the Vice President of Malawi met in Zimbabwe. They also had lunch in Malawi.
The Vice President's visit to Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana was the first high level visit to these three countries in 21 years.
India has made 29 visits to Africa at the level of President, Vice President and Prime Minister. Vice President's visit to Africa was part of this initiative.

India’s commitment to support Africa in its developmental process and its efforts in improving diplomatic, bilateral and people-to-people contacts have been unequivocally acknowledged by all the three Presidents, he said.
Zimbabwe, India and the US are grateful for sustained development assistance from India.
During his visit to Botswana, Zimbabwe and Malawi, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi committed a lot of money for development projects.
India, Botswana and Zimbabwe appreciate India's ITEC programme for capacity building. India is deputing 5 experts in various fields to assist Zimbabwe under ITEC.

During his interactions with the Vice President and the leadership of three African Nations crucial issues including capacity building, technological knowledge sharing, opportunities in trading Minerals including uranium, copper, nickel and railways, infrastructure, logistics etc. were discussed. India’s support in providing Skill Development, tele-education and tele-medicine in African region was appreciated.
The Vice President's visit to Malawi, Botswana and Zimbabwe witnessed signing of memorandums of understanding with all three nations.
Other important Agreements included Extradition treaty with Malawi and an agreement in Broadcasting by Prasar Bharati, another one in Arts, Culture, Heritage and an Action Plan on ICT with Zimbabwe.

In the area of health, all three countries were appreciative of medical services provided by India and the private sector hospitals in their respective countries. Vice President of India announced gifting of Bhabhatron Cancer machine in Malawi, ambulances and life saving drugs in all three states.

The Vice President informed them about Indian traditional medicine, particularly ayurveda and yoga, and the leadership was in agreement of the fact that there was considerable scope in these areas since all three countries have their own traditional medicine as well.
The Vice President of India promised to explore the possibility of greater involvement of India in Africa's agriculture sector.
The leaders of India, Zimbabwe and Malawi agreed with Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu that security cooperation, particularly in counter-terrorism needs to be strengthened.
The Vice President of India visited India, China and Japan. He was given the rare honour of inaugurating their prestigious annual Global Expo 2018.
The Vice President visited Botswana and Malawi. He unveiled a plaque to inaugurate the Business Incubation Centre in Malawi built with Indian grant assistance.
Vice President of India has addressed Indian communities in all the three countries.
The Vice President had expressed his happiness for the contribution of the Diaspora in India.
The Vice President thanked the leadership for supporting India at various international fora including the United Nations. All three leaders expressed their desire to work with India on Solar energy.

While Malawi had already signed and ratified the framework agreement on International Solar Alliance, Zimbabwe has signed ISA and, during the Vice President’s visit Botswana, they conveyed to him of their decision to sign it shortly.

The Vice President of India inaugurated the event “India for Humanity” meant to commemorate the 150 birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi in Malawi. India will organise camps of Jaipur Foot in all parts of the world.
The Government is partnering Bhagwan Mahavir Viklang Sahayata Samiti in this “India for Humanity” initiative.

The Vice President was given the honour of launching the very first Jaipur Foot Camp in this series in Malawi in Africa as Mahatma Gandhi spent more than two decades and eventually led a non-violent movement that liberated India from colonialism and inspired African leaders to free their countries as well.
The Vice President was accompanied by a high level delegation that included the Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment, two members of Parliament and senior officials.
Mahatma Gandhi’s experience with truth & his commitment to serve the needy is an inspirational saga: Vice President
Launches ‘India For Humanity’ programme to commemorate 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma GandhiCalls on the President of Malawi
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that Mahatma Gandhi's message of peace resonates around the World.

Shri Naidu said that ‘India For Humanity’ launched in Malawi opens an opportunity to take the message of Mahatma Gandhi to all parts of the world as it seeks to celebrate the great values of humanism which Mahatma Gandhi embodied right through his life.
He said that Mahatama Gandhi’s vision and voice has a rare resonance in numerous hearts around the world because it springs from the timeless humanistic vision of India.

TheVice President said that it was his good fortune to launch the first Jaipur Foot camp on the sidelines of ‘India For Humanity’ in Africa, especially in Africa where Mahatma Gandhi lived for more than twenty years and drew sustenance for his fight against discrimination and colonial domination with nothing but truth and non-violence as his weapons.
The Vice President of India has launched a program named after Mahatma Gandhi.
The Vice President of the Republic of Uganda, Earler, met with the President of Malawi at the State House in Mutharika.

Indian Technical and Economic Cooperation (ITEC), Trade and Commercial Cooperation, support in the fields of Cooperation, Mineral Resources, Health and matters pertaining to international and multilateral issues were discussed.
The Vice President of the United States, Mike Pence, is visiting Malawi today. He will leave for Delhi after his engagements in Malawi.
Continue the mission of carrying India‘s message to the World: VP tells Indians in Malawi
India is witnessing transformation, take advantage of the situation;Addresses Indian Community Reception
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has called on the Indian community in Malawi to continue the mission of carrying India’s message to the World.
The Vice President of India has called on the Indian community to continue building bridges of understanding and empathy with Malawian people.
The Vice President of Malawi appreciates Indian cultural heritage and your involvement in economic activities in Malawi.
The Vice President of India, Shri Narendra Modi, has said that India is marching ahead on the path of reforms.
The Minister of State for Social Justice and Empowerment, the High Commissioner of India to Malawi were present on the occasion.
The Vice President of Malawi, Prof. Peter Mutharika, is scheduled to meet the President and other dignitaries of the Malawian government on November 5, 2018.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
"I bring you the warmest greetings from India.
The Hon’ble Minister Sri Kishan Pal Gurjar and his delegation were received warmly by the members of parliament.
I am in Lilongwe, Malawi. I am meeting with President Prof. Arther Peter Mutharika tomorrow.
Malawians of Indian origin have been living in Malawi for the last 150 years.
I am congratulating the less than 1% of the population on their achievements in the economic activities of the country.
Malawi had an Indian Association and Indian Country Club in the past.
I convey my sincere appreciation to the determination of your leadership, in keeping these Associations alive for more than 100+ years in this distant country.
The Hindu Sewa Samaj in Blantyre is over five decades old and celebrates various Indian festivals.
By promoting cultural and economic activities of Malawi Indians, you help preserve their cultural identity in this distant land.
India is on course to become a 5 trillion economy by 2025.
India is moving fast forward to transform itself into a modern 21st century inclusive economy. The government has taken a number of measures.

An ambitious plan to build next-generation infrastructure including 100 Smart Cities, 10 green-field airports, 7 high-speed train corridors, 5 major ports, highways and nation-wide broadband connectivity linking our villages and urban areas is underway.
Nearly 10 thousand kilometres of national highways were built during the last one year.
To boost the manufacturing sector, India has embarked on the “Make in India” programme. A host of reforms have been initiated, including the transformational tax reform.
The introduction of Goods and Service Tax is a major step to have seamless and efficient national market. This will make it easier for businesses to establish and grow in India.
I would urge you to look at the results from the World Bank’s ‘Doing Business 2019’ report. India has implemented six reforms in the past year and advanced to 77th place in the global ranking.
India is changing rapidly. The business environment is changing for the better. Seamless processes are being introduced.
The President of Malawi and the Prime Minister of India are meeting tomorrow. They are going to sign important agreements.

Malawi is rich in natural resources and India is more than happy to assist in value addition of their rich resources, so that the Malawian economy becomes self-reliant and Malawi is able to finance all their domestic requirements in the years ahead.
The 15th Pravasi Bharatiya Diwas will be held from January 21-23, 2019 in Varanasi.
In concluding, I would like to thank each one of you, who have come here and the larger Indian community spread all over Malawi, for building bridges of understanding and empathy.
In his message to Malawians, President Peter Mutharika asks them to share their prosperity with Malawian brothers and sisters.
In his message to the Indian community in Malawi, President Peter Mutharika wishes them success.
You are India’s cultural ambassadors and the world sees you as the representatives of Indian values and way of life.
I am happy that many of you have done India proud.
In his will, the prime minister asks the people of India to continue carrying India's message to the world and bring back the best from other countries to India.
Vice President lauds Zimbabwe on free and fair elections

Has an excellent, cordial meeting with the President of Zimbabwe;President of Zimbabwe appreciated India's strong and consistent support even in times of isolation;5 MoUs & one Action Plan on ICT were signed in areas ranging from Mining, Visa Waiver, Broadcasting & Culture etc.;Holds delegation level talks with Vice President of Zimbabwe

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu congratulated Zimbabwe for conducting free and fair elections recently. He was meeting with the President of Zimbabwe, Mr. Emmerson Mnangagwa and the Vice President, Kembo Mohadi in Harare today.
Vice President of India requested Zimbabwe to ratify the Frame Work Agreement on International Solar Alliance.
The Vice President of the United States met the Vice-President of Zimbabwe, Mr. Kembo Mohadi, for high level talks.

The Vice President said that India will take up the establishment of the Mahatma Gandhi Convention Centre in Zimbabwe, as a grant assistance, keeping with our celebration of the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi this year.
India is offering 8 slots for Zimbabwe defence personnel for training under ITEC for this year.
The Vice President of India has said that India is committed to working towards fighting and elimination of terrorism.
India extends another LOC of $310 million for extension of life of Hwange Thermal Plant and enhances funds for two LOC projects for Bulawayo for US$23 million and US$19 million.
India will support Zimbabwe in development of Micro & Mini Grid, Smart Grids and Hybrid Renewable Energy Technologies.
