The top 30 innovations were identified from 20 different States and Union territories from across India.
The top 30 teams from ATL's student entrepreneur programme have been awarded with prizes.
The Top 30 innovations are symbolic of a movement which is taking root in every school, in every district across India.

As part of a long-term partnership, during the Children’s Day Week, from today to the World Children’s Day on 20 November, AIM and UNICEF seek to drive extensive forward and backward linkages within the stakeholders in India, to create a paradigm shift in the student mindset and prepare them to become young innovators and entrepreneurs.

AIM and UNICEF have also launched a 72 hour Tinkering Hackathon from 14 to 17 November so that children can come up with innovative solutions for challenges faced by them in school, especially pertaining to quality of education and safety in schools.The winners of the Hackathon will be announced on 20 November, World Children’s Day.
The Fourth NITI Aayog- DRC Dialogue Held in Mumbai
The fourth dialogue of the NITI Aayog and DRC of the State Council, People's Republic of China was held in Mumbai today.

This is the third ministerial dialogue between China and India since the meeting of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Johannesburg during the BRICS summit in July 2018.

In his opening remarks, Dr Rajiv Kumar highlighted that the NITI-DRC Dialogue is a strong platform for continuous intellectual engagement between the two countries, wherein inputs from sectoral experts help identify and collaborate on key areas of India-China economic cooperation.

Senior delegates from China and India Administration, representatives of government, academia and enterprises participated in the deliberations, which included sessions on Global Economy, Globalisation and Macro-Economic Policies in China and India; Innovation and Economic Transformation, and Potential for Sino-India Trade and Economic Cooperation.

As part of the Dialogue, the DRC delegation also participated in technical field visits in Mumbai and Bengaluru where they visited leading industrial leaders, technical universities, research centers and innovation and IT ecosystems established in India.
After detailed presentations and in-depth discussions, both sides affirmed their commitment for a more inclusive and truly global world order, with multilateralism as the preferred way forward.
Emphasis was laid on innovation and digital economy at the meeting.
Both sides also agreed to examine various trade sector related issues, and the need for enhanced policy coordination to facilitate investments.
It was also agreed that NITI Aayog and DRC will undertake joint research in the areas of WTO reforms and urbanization, which would be presented in the next Dialogue.
The Fifth edition of the NITI - DRC Dialogue was agreed to be held in Wuhan, China in November, 2019.
GDP Q2 estimates a reflections of government’s successful policy efforts in maintaining a stable domestic environment despite global uncertainties
GDP at constant prices grew at 7.1% in the second quarter of 2018-19.
India's economic growth is on a positive trend.

He added that despite international trade tensions and volatile crude oil prices, India's strong economic fundamentals continue to provide the needed thrust for it to be a major global driver of economic growth. The robust growth rates in sectors such as manufacturing and constructions show that the growth momentum continues to be broad based.

CCI invites comments from public in respect of the proposed acquisition of the electrical and automation business of Larsen & Toubro Limited by Schneider Electric India Private Limited and MacRitchie Investments Pvt. Limited.

The Competition Commission of India (CCI) received a notice from Schneider Electric India Private Limited and MacRitchie Investments Pvt. Ltd regarding the proposed acquisition of the electrical and automation business of Larsen & Toubro Limited (L&T) but not the Marine Business and Servowatch Business.

The Commission is of the prima facie opinion that the proposed acquisition is likely to have an appreciable adverse effect on competition and, accordingly, has directed the Acquirers, in terms of Section 29(2) of the Competition Act, 2002, to publish details of the combination for bringing the same to the knowledge and information of public and persons affected or likely to be affected by such Acquisition.
The parties have published the details of the proposed combination in 2018/07/586 and the same is also hosted on the respective websites of the parties and the Commission.
The Competition Commission of India invites comments/objections/suggestions in writing from people adversely affected by the proposed combination.
The Commission is not likely to consider unsubstantiated objections.
Jaitley: Fair and Transparent Public Procurement will protect the revenues of the State and make sure that they are used for optimal purpose

CCI Chairperson: CCI designing diagnostic tool for public procurement agencies to detect bid rigging in public procurement and help design tenders that promote fair competitionMCA Secretary: Competitive procurement could result in cost saving to the extent of around 20-30%World Bank Country Director: Contracting with the Government to be new indicator in next round of Ease of Doing Business ranking

Procurement based on the principles of fairness, transparency and public interest will protect the revenues of the State and make sure they are used for optimal purpose, said the Union Minister for Finance and Corporate Affairs Shri Arun Jaitley.

The competition regulator was created to ensure effective competition so that consumer interest could be protected. Public procurement is a large part of the country's GDP and applies to all Statutory Institutions. In some areas tender bids can be global while in others domestic development is desirable.
The chairperson of the Central Procurement Commission (CCI) stressed on the importance of building a culture of competition in Public Procurements Systems in India.

There was a conference on public procurement. Shri Injeti Srinivas, Secretary, Ministry of Corporate Affairs stated that given the sheer volume of public procurement, which accounts for more than 26% of GDP, it has a significant influence on the economy's performance. He said that there is a need to redesign the current PPP model to promote competition.
The World Bank is promoting e-procurement and public procurement system in India.
The session concluded with a vote of thanks.
The Competition Commission of India (CCI) and IICA organised a Conference on public procurement.
The Conference on Public Procurement was held in the presence of policymakers, participants from the industry, legal professionals, academicians and other relevant stakeholders.
CCI to hold national conference on public procurement & competition law tomorrow in Delhi
Infusing competition in public procurement is a priority: CCI Chairperson
A conference on public procurement and competition law is being held in Delhi on 5th November 2018. Union Minister for Finance and Corporate Affairs Shri Arun Jaitley will be the chief guest.
The Competition Commission of India (CCI) is organising a National Conference on competition law and public procurement.
The competition regulator, Competition Authority of India (CAI) is organising a National Conference on public procurement, bid rigging, cartels and leniency.
Some of India's top judges and business leaders will be speaking at the conference.
The National Conference will have two open house sessions on Infusing Competition in Public Procurement and Bid-igging.

President of India Inaugurates Sadhu Vaswani International School and Unveils Statue of Matoshree Ramabai Ambedkar in Pune; says education can promote values and help fight caste, gender and other forms of discrimination
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, inaugurated the Sadhu Vaswani International School in Pune today (May 30, 2018).
The Sadhu Vaswani International School is named after a spiritual leader.
The President of India appreciates the contribution of Pune to education and reform in India.
The President said that values-based education promotes ethics in society.

The President said that in school a child is taught history and geography, language and literature, mathematics and science. In class X and in class XII, children are examined in these and other subjects and given marks and grades.
The President believes that a child who imbibes these values and internalises these values will always be sensitive to the world outside and to those who may be less privileged.
The President unveiled the statue of BR Ambedkar at the Matoshree Ramabai Bhimrao Ambedkar Bhimrtha Ambedrakar Garden in Pune.
President Pranabha Ambedkar has paid tribute to Dr Ambedkhara Ambedkar's wife.
President Pranabha Patnaik said that Dr Ambedkar's life with Ramabai influenced his thinking and made him an advocate of women's rights.
President Pranabhama Ramabai Ambedkar has paid tribute to Dr. Bhimrao Ambedkar.
Address by the hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovindon the occasion of formal opening of Sadhu Vaswani International School
The Sadhu Vaswani International School in Pradhikaran, Pune is officially opened today.
The school of Sadhu Vaswani was established in memory of a great spiritual figure.
Sadhu Vaswani dedicated his life to the cause of humanity for 79 out of 100 years.

Dada J.P. Vaswani sacrificed a promising academic career to immerse himself in spiritual learning, in welfare, in caring for the underprivileged and for defenceless animals. He also set up schools for education.
The school has achieved a significant achievement.
Ladies and Gentlemen and Dear Children
Your school draws inspiration from the works of Sadhu Vaswani and Dada J.P. Vaswania and the history of Pune.
It was in this city that in 1848 Mahatma Jyotiba Phule and Savitribai Phule opened what is believed to be the first modern school exclusively for girls.

They were in Pune that Justice M.G. Ranade and others set up the Maharashtra Girls Education Society in the 19th century. Vasudev Balwant Phadke, Bal Gangadhar Tilak and Gopal Krishna Gokhale established the Deccan Education Society.
Many of the initiatives and educational institutions that prepare children and young people for service to the nation and society are still with us and are still going strong.

The Chief Architect of our Constitution, Dr B.R. Ambedkar, had a long relationship with Pune. He too stressed the importance of education as an instrument for social change and for building a just and egalitarian society. November 7th is Students' Day in Maharashtra.
Shri Lal Krishna Advani is an upholder of values in public life.
Ladies and Gentlemen and Dear Children
The names and examples I cited earlier represent a gamut of our country’s achievers and the spirit of its nation building project.
This is the true attribute of an educated society. Sadhu Vaswani International School is carving out its space in this city.
Education is about shaping children's minds.

In school, children are taught history and geography, language and literature, mathematics and science. In class X and in class XII, they are given marks and grades. However, there are lessons that children learn in school that may not be formally tested in a board examination.
A child who imbibes values and internalises these values will always be sensitive to the world outside and to those who may be less privileged.
With those words I wish the school, I wish the children studying there and I wish teachers and others associated with the school the very best.

Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the 7th convocation of IISER, Mohali
IISER, Mohali is hosting its 7th convocation today. IISER is an important centre of higher education and research in India.
IISER Mohali is a centre for basic and applied scientific research. It serves the Chandigarh-Mohali-Panchkula metropolitan area.
The legacy of IISER is rich in examples of how scientists and technologists contribute to nation building.
The convocation ceremony is taking place at IISER. The students are graduating today.
As you leave this Institute and build your professional careers, do remember all those who have stood by you. Please do give back to society.
There are 66 female students graduating today. Both the gold medals for academic performance and three of the four awards for academic excellence have been won by girl students.
Ladies and Gentlemen, and dear students

The purpose of scientific research is threefold:. First, science and technology must continue to play a role in nation building. Second, they need to find answers to developmental questions. Third, they must be immerse themselves in these tasks.
IISER must strive to play a similar role in Mohali and the neighbouring cities.
Punjab has a long history of technocrats who ventured into successful businesses.
Third, institutions of scientific education and research are important in themselves for blue-sky innovation and for expanding the frontiers of knowledge.
IISER Mohali's graduation ceremony is taking place today.
President of India graces 7th convocationof IISER, Mohali
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, graced and addressed the 7th convocation of Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER) in Mohali.
The President of India congratulated the Institute of Indian Institute of Science and Engineering Research on its foundation.
Mohali is a hub for the knowledge economy. President of India wants IISER to be the fulcrum of the entire ecosystem.
The purpose of scientific research is three-fold: first, national development, second, combating climate change and third, building sustainable cities and houses.
IISER should strive to play a similar role in Mohali and neighbouring cities as it did in Silicon Valley and Bengaluru, President Trump said.
The President said that institutions of scientific education and research are important in themselves for innovation and for expanding the frontiers of knowledge.
The President of IISER urged students to serve their fellow citizens, serve society and country and to serve the larger cause of humanity.

Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind on the Occasion of Presentation of National Geoscience Awards
I am here to present the National Geoscience Awards for the year 2017.
The National Geoscience Awards recognise the contributions of technologists and researchers in this domain.
The Geological Survey of India was founded in 1851.
There have been landmarks on this march.
Today geosciences have many useful applications.

India is one of the fastest growing major economies in the world. The mining and mineral sector is poised to grow as a result of this expansion of the economy. As India builds more cities and houses and commercial centres and creates state-of-the-art infrastructure, the use of key resources will rise. India's per capita consumption of many resources and commodities is still low.
The government is pushing reforms in the mining sector. A number of mineral blocks are being explored and ready for auction.
Mining brings with it the opportunity to exploit mineral resources but it also brings the risk of exploitation of tribal communities.
Mining in India must be sustainable and efficient.
In light of the Award winners today, I am glad that some of them have discovered new mineral deposits.

Geoscientists have an important role to play in enhancing agricultural productivity and farmer incomes, in providing a bedrock to the Smart Cities initiative, and in helping their fellow citizens fight the challenge of water scarcity.
Geoscientists have been honoured for their achievements.
In March 2020, India will host the 36th International Geological Congress.
President of India Presents National Geoscience Awards
The President of India presented the National Geoscience Awards today in New Delhi.
The President of India, Pranabhatsin Hridayensinh Jayant Sinha, congratulated on the growing economy of India.
The President of Guinea has announced that a number of mineral blocks are being identified for auction.
The President has called on geoscientists to continue to contribute towards the development of the country and the fight against water scarcity.

The President of India is pleased to appoint Shri Om Prakash Kohli, Governor of Gujarat to discharge the functions of the Governor of Madhya Pradesh, in addition to his own duties, during the absence, on leave, of Smt Anandiben Patel, Governor of Madhya Pradesh.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind on the occasion of Inauguration of Department of Atomic Energy Facilities at Bhabha Atomic Research Centre
Dr Homi Jehangir Bhabha inaugurated some facilities of Department of Atomic Energy today.
India is recognised as one of the leading nations in the use of nuclear technologies across multiple disciplines.
The vision of the Department of Atomic Energy is to make the nation energy independent.

At times, such vision statements only serve as lofty ideas and don't bear testimony to the actual work of an organisation. In this case, the work of the Nuclear Power Corporation bears testimony to its declared vision. Now the organisation must work to establish a robust nuclear energy program based on using thorium deposits.
The work of the Department of Atomic Energy is well-known. The work of this department is involved in research and development of nuclear medicine.

Research in nuclear science has benefited the food processing and agriculture sector. It has helped develop 43 crop varieties that are more efficient and productive. One of them was inaugurated today. It also has helped extend the shelf life of fruits such as mangoes, papaya, and lichi.

There are many areas in which your contribution helps the agenda for national development. For instance, you have developed technologies that have helped in purification of water, radiation treatment of municipal waste, conversion of kitchen bio-waste into bio-gas for cooking purposes and in organic manure conversion. I compliment you for your initiatives that have direct relevance to the defence and security of the nation and the effectiveness of the armed forces.

The Department of Atomic Energy has an important responsibility in national development. The government has set out an ambitious agenda of enhancing power generation through nuclear sources and it is for you to make that possible.
The gathering is full of scientists. They must use their minds to solve the problems of the country and contribute towards economic growth and social justice.
To conclude, I wish each of you the very best for your future endeavours.
President of India Visits an Exhibition on Department of Atomic Energy Technologies at the Bhabha Atomic Research Centre and Inaugurates DAE Facilities

The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, visited an exhibition on Department of Atomic Energy (DAE) technologies at the Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC) in Trombay, Mumbai and inaugurated facilities there.
The President of India congratulated the Department of Atomic Energy on its 60th anniversary.
The President congratulated Indian scientists on their achievements in using nuclear technology.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind on the occasion of launch of 12 champion services sectors and inauguration of 4th Edition of Global Exhibition on Services

I am here for the inauguration of the Fourth Global Exhibition on Services. I warmly welcome the approximately 500 international delegates who, according to organisers, have come from about 100 countries. I commend the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, Government of India and the Government of Maharashtra for their initiative.
The Chief Minister of Maharashtra, Shri Devendra Fadnavis, co-hosts an event.
The services sector is growing and becoming increasingly important to the global economy.

In India, the services sector contributes 61 per cent of gross value added. India's global services exports stood at 3.4 per cent in 2016. The government's target is a 4.2 per cent share of global services by 2022.

India's economy has grown at an impressive 6.9% in the past four years. For 2018-19, the International Monetary Fund expects the economy to grow at 7.4%. The services sector is a key driver of this growth.
By 2025, India hopes to double the size of its GDP to US$ 5 trillion. The services sector could be a US$ 3 trillion contributor. The Internet economy could be as high as US$ 1 trillion.

In the early Industrial Age and the traditional manufacturing economy created jobs in factories and encouraged entrepreneurship. Today, we are looking at small but exciting start-ups in the services space.
In India, government programmes such as Start-up India and Mudra Yojana have seeded a culture of entrepreneurship, largely in services.

In my opinion, India's recent economic reforms have unleashed creative and commercial energies. They have re-emphasised how important India is as a supplier to and a market for global services sector businesses.

The government of India is doing its best to ease foreign investment regulations in several sectors. Services like financial services, business and professional services, and R&D accounted for almost two-thirds of cumulative FDI inflows since April 2000.
The introduction of Goods and Services Tax in July 2017 transformed India into a single market.

On Ease of Doing Business, the Government has taken major steps. It has made it easier to start a business and obtaining permits. The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code and the national Intellectual Property Rights Policy have also made it simpler.
The launch of the 12 Champion Services scheme comes with the preparation and background.
President of India in Maharashtra; Inaugurates 4th Global Exhibition on Services; says India’s large talent pool gives it natural advantages in Services
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, inaugurated the 4th Global Exhibition on Services and launched a portal on 12 Champion Sectors in Services in Mumbai today (May 15, 2018).
The President of India has congratulated the organisers of the Global Exhibition on the launch of 12 Champion Sectors.
The President said that the services sector represents a vibrant and expanding component of the global economy.
The President of India, Narendra Modi, has said that India is set to become a provider of services to the world.

The President said that the traditional manufacturing economy created jobs in factories and encouraged entrepreneurship in the form of ancillary units and workshops. Today, we are looking at start-ups in the services space. Technology has become an enabler and allowed local services companies to go national or even global. In India, which is the third largest centre of start-up companies, there is a generation of young entrepreneurs with hunger and ambition.
The President of India, Narendra Modi, believes that Government programmes such as Start-up India and Mudra Yojana have seeded a culture of entrepreneurship.

Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind on the Occasion of National Technology Day Celebrations
It was on this day two decades ago that the Pokhran nuclear tests took place.
The Pokhran nuclear tests of May 1998 were a demonstration of both scientific capacity and political will. They had a profound impact on India's foreign policy and strategic relations.
Today, India remembers the leadership and courage of Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam and Atal Bihari Vajpayee.
National Technology Day is celebrated to celebrate the achievements of scientists and innovators.

The achievements that we have applauded today range from a vaccine that will help defeat rotavirus to a low-cost diagnostic machine for kidney and other non-communicable illnesses. There are also companies that have won technology start-up awards.
New technologies offer solutions that are necessary in the Indian context and contribute to the social and economic needs of our people at competitive price points.
Today's award winners are examples of how we are moving ahead with daring, with risk-taking ability and with ingenuity in technology.

After Independence, India began to climb the value chain in technology production. Today, India has expanded to best-in-class capacities in communication technology, IT, pharmaceuticals and biotechnology. In the past year, India launched the Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System and is preparing for the Chandrayaan-2 mission to the moon.

The government has proposed to establish Centres of Excellence to train young technologists in robotics, artificial intelligence, digital manufacture, Big Data Analytics, quantum communication, Internet of Things and in the clean energy options.
In his speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi talked about the need for technology as a force multiplier for national programmes.
In order to improve the situation of women working in technology and innovation, more needs to be done to encourage them to get involved.

With those words, and with the confidence that the almost magical synthesis of curiosity and experiment, of science and innovation, and of technology and change, is set to revolutionise India, I wish you all the best for your future endeavours.
President of India Addresses the National Technology Day Celebrations

Address by the Hon’ble President of IndiaShri Ram Nath Kovindon the occasion the Centenary Celebrations of Medical Education programme of Christian Medical College
I am in Vellore for the event to mark the Centenary of Medical Education at the Christian Medical College.
CMC is celebrating 100 years. In honour of its founder, Ida Sophia Scudder, CMC must draw inspiration from her values and idealism.
In 1918, India was in a very poor condition. Ida Sophia Scudder devoted her life to healthcare and she set up a medical school that was only for women.

India has come a long way since then. Revolutions in our economy, in agriculture and in technology have changed how we act, think and live. Health outcomes have also improved. Average life expectancy is now above 68 years. Diseases such as polio and smallpox have been defeated. The government has launched Mission Indradhanush to immunise all children.
Tamil Nadu has exceptional health indicators. Institutions such as CMC Vellore have contributed to this.
CMC's mission is to improve public health and address regional, rural and urban imbalances.
As societies evolve, economies develop and population patterns change, countries go through epidemiological transitions. India is experiencing such a transition.

India has three main priorities: to reduce maternal and infant mortality, to prevent communicable diseases, non-communicable or lifestyle diseases like diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and many cancers, and to develop systems to detect and cope with new and re-emerging infectious diseases.

This three-pronged challenge calls for interventions across the continuum of care. It calls for prevention of disease, promotion of good health practices and treatment and cure in case of an illness. The impact of a health problem is cross-cutting and it affects a variety of sectors.

The National Health Mission, the National Health Policy and the Ayushman Bharat insurance scheme aim to provide a broad-based approach to public health. They aim to ensure that nobody is deprived of healthcare due to the absence of financial resources.
There is an urgent need to fill the gap in healthcare professionals in India.
CMC Vellore is proud of its medical achievements and research.
CMC Vellore trains doctors and nurses with a sharp mind and a warm heart. It is commendable that the training is complemented by placements in villages and underserved areas.
May this be your mission for the next 100 years and more!

President of India chairs the first meeting of the National Committee for Commemoration of 150th Birth Anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, chaired the first meeting of the National Committee for the Commemoration of the 150th Birth Anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi at Rashtrapati Bhavan today.
The President of India will address the Commemoration meeting.
President Kovind paid tribute to Mahatma Gandhi.
The 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi is being celebrated.
The President wants the 150th Birth Anniversary Commemoration to be elevated to a global celebration.
The President then called upon those present to share their ideas and suggestions on how we may commemorate the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi.
The Commemoration of Mahatma Gandhi will be held from October 2, 2018 to October2, 2020.

Since it would not be feasible for the entire National Committee to be convened frequently, the meeting resolved to set up a smaller Executive Committee, headed by the Prime Minister, to take forward the commemoration of the 150th birth anniversary of Gandhiji.
The Prime Minister, Shri Narendra Modi, thanked various members of the Committee for their constructive suggestions and recommendations.
The Prime Minister wants all programmes associated with the celebration of Mahatma Gandhi's birthday to be based on the theme of Karyanjali - or “Gandhi in action”.
The Prime Minister wants the celebrations to take the shape of a mass movement.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India Shri Ram Nath Kovind
On the occasion of presentation of the 4th Visitor’s Award and meet of Vice-Chancellors of Central Universities
The Vice-Chancellors of Central Universities are meeting in Rashtrapati Bhavan today.
Education is the key for the development of our nation and people.
The Visitor’s Awards, 2018 recognise the outstanding contribution and single-minded devotion of the award winners in the pursuit of knowledge.
Research and Innovation is the bedrock of advancing knowledge and finding solutions to the problems we face in our world, nation and society.
The research and teaching profession offers unique benefits that no other career offers.

It is due to this appreciation about the importance of research that the meeting with Vice-Chancellors today focuses on issues universities are facing in the promotion of research and innovation. Minister for HRD, Shri Prakash Javadekar and Minister of State, Dr Satya Pal Singh are present here today. To help the Vice-chancellors on issues concerning research, Professor K. Vijay Raghavan is also present.
The government has a responsibility to promote research and innovation in its centres of education. The responsibility lies with the researchers.
This year's Visitor's Awards recognise outstanding research work of Prof. Sanjay K. Jain, Prof. Ashwani Pareek, Prof Pramod K. Nayar and Prof. ashis Kumar Mukherjee.
The goal of central universities is to constantly grow and upgrade themselves as per the best of global standards.
As an immediate goal you should strive to become the best in the country and compete with each other in a healthy way. Then you should work towards competing with the world’s best.

Universities are public institutions powered with the energy and dynamism of their students. They must use this energy to engage with the communities near to their campuses and with the government of the state that hosts them. They should also engage purposefully with the respective state governments on projects of mutual interest.
I congratulate the winners of the Visitor’s Awards 2018.
Address by the Hon’ble President of India
Shri Ram Nath Kovind at the closing session of the meet of Vice-Chancellors of Central Universities
Vice-Chancellors from 24 central universities met today to discuss issues concerning promotion of research and innovation in their campuses.
The universities are making significant contributions to research. However, they are facing challenges.

The meeting was held in the presence of the Minister for HRD, the Minister of State and other officials from the Ministry of State, the University Grants Commission, and the Science and Technology Ministry.
The Vice-Chancellors of Nigerian universities are responsible for their own performance.
There are a lot of faculty vacancies in higher education institutes.
There is a shortage of faculty in universities. To address it, universities need to develop a robust visiting faculty program, use online teaching tools and re-employ retired professors.
All of you must invest in Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC) to enhance your capacities and reach beyond your physical campuses.
Universities should play a leading role in addressing the specific challenges faced by the nation.
Universities should integrate community-oriented projects as part of their curriculum.
Today, we have discussed problems and made some progress in identifying the way forward. I propose to meet again in 6 months or so to review progress.
The president of the university thanks the participants for participating in the discussions.

Committee to review rules and business of Rajya Sabha likely to submit report next month: Vice President
Need to ponder if legislatures are sending right message to people;Releases Book ‘Straight Talk’
The committee which is reviewing the rules of procedure and business of Rajya Sabha is likely to submit its interim report next month.
According to him, Dr. Singhvi's suggestion for automatic suspension of allowances for law makers per day or per hour lost due to disruptions will be considered by the committee.
The Vice President has questioned whether the messages sent by legislatures are accurate.
In Indian parliamentary democracy, political parties have an important role to play. Politics should not be the be all and end all of political activities.
The Vice President called for a new political approach based on ‘Less Fission (division) and more Fusion’.
The Vice President called on ruling and opposition parties to discharge specific responsibilities in Parliament.
The Vice President has said that political parties should be guided by the distinction between rivals and enemies.

The Vice President said that law makers should be elected based on four Cs-- Capacity, Caliber, Character and Conduct and not on the basis of the other four Cs-- Caste, Community, Cash and Criminal Prowess.
According to the book, special tribunals or courts should be set up to hear election related cases within six months.
The Vice President of India, Abhishek Singhvi, has said that India is an aspirational country.
He said the themes and sub-themes addressed in the book are timeless and transcend politics, political parties, governments and current events.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“Respected former Prime Minister Dr.Manmohan Singh ji, the man of this evening Shri Abhishek Manu Singhvi, Member of Rajya Sabha, distinguished invitees, friends from the media, Brothers and Sisters!
It is a pleasure for me to be associated with the release of the book ‘Straight Talk’ by Shri Abhishek Manu Singhvi.
Shri Abhishek is one of the leading lawyers and a politician.
Abhishek ji is a great thinker and a great parliamentarian.
He has moved on from “Candid Corner” to “Straight Talk” now. Candid Corner was a collection of his writings for which forward was also written by Dr. Manmohan Singh.
Abhishek's new collection of writings is titled ‘India of My Dreams’. It is based on facts about the India on the rise.
Shri Singhvi argues for a Better India by harnessing it's full potential to realize its potential.
Shri Raja Mani Shanker Singhvi's book is an excellent collection of articles on India.
Shri Singhvi's aim is to nudge this great country closer and closer to the India of his dreams.
Abhishek ji lists eight challenges to make a Better India.
Shri Singhvi's book contains nine important suggestions relating to functioning of legislatures, judiciary, elections, media, promoting excellence etc.
1. Automatic suspension of allowances for law makers per day or per hour, lost due to disruptions, and suspension of named members for a prolonged period without revocation.
Shri Singhvi's suggestion will be considered by the Committee on Rules of Procedure and Business of Rajya Sabha.

2. Amending the law to see that Whip does not apply to legislative voting and at the time of introduction of Bills so that bipartisan legislative proposals can be made that have a chance of becoming law.
Shri Singhvi’s argument is that this encourages flexibility in voting and legislative creativity since proposing laws is now in the sole domain of governments.
The government losing a vote in the House on any legislation should not be treated as having lost the confidence of the House.
This suggestion is in line with the recommendation of giving liberty to MPs on voting on Bills.
4. Disqualifying law makers with criminal antecedents at the stage of framing of charges by the Courts.
This is in line with my long-held belief that law makers should be elected based on four Cs i.e. Capacity, Caliber, Character and Conduct.
5. Announcing the successor Judge a month before a Judge retires.
Being a part of the system, Shri Singhvi clinically analyzed the reasons for huge pendency of cases and made this suggestion worthy of serious consideration.
6. Mandatory Judicial Impact assessment of all legislations.
The government should conduct a law-making exercise to assess the potential for litigation.
7. Fast Track Courts for election related cases.
The law maker meriting disqualification would have completed the term availing all benefits by now.
There is a call to instil operational excellence at all levels.
9. Lawmakers should take action to ensure fair playing field and unbiased news and reporting by media.
The topic of subjectivity and noise dominating the TV space with truth becoming a victim of the media is raised.
Besides such specific suggestions, the learned Shri Abhishek Manu Singhvi has made some observations which are equally important for public debate.
Judicial activism is a basic and undeniable truth in India.
Shri Singhvi is concerned about judicial overreach.
Other major concerns voiced by Shri Singhvi include the rising money power in elections and our legislatures becoming more and more hereditary.

In the context of complaints by the losers against Electronic Voting Machine (EVMs), this ‘Straight Talk’ has this to say, “Despite periodic taunts and criticism of EVM, there is a near unanimity that it yields a remarkably accurate and virtually unassailable results.”
The author's comments on the functioning of various institutions of India's polity need to be widely discussed.
Shri Singhvi dreams of a Better India. Prime Minister Narendra Modi wants a New India.
The principal issue of political parties in India is realizing the New and Better India.
The political division in legislatures is worrying people.
The ruling and opposition parties have specific responsibilities to discharge. The opposition is mandated with ensuring the best possible scrutiny.
Political parties are at the best only rivals and not enemies.
The themes and sub-themes addressed in the book are timeless and transcend politics, political parties, governments and current events.
Shri Singhvi's book talks about India being described as a soft power rather than a hard power.

Mr.Abhishek Manu Singhvi, in this Council of informed members who have the ability to further amplify the message that you seek to give out, I admit your motion for an informed debate on Better India.
Scientific research is of no use if it does not improve life of people: Vice President
ISRO is proud of its work.

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, was interacting with students of Delhi Public School, R.K. Puram, who won Asian Regional Space Settlement Design Competition 2018 and are scheduled to participate in the world final at NASA, USA.
The Vice President congratulated the students for designing a space settlement.
The Vice President of the University of Michigan is giving students a trip to space.

Describing the achievements of our country in fields of science and technology, the Vice President said that India is one of the leading space research nations and we are Proud of our Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), which is now preparing satellites for other nations including SAARC countries.

On this occasion, the Vice President talked about the history and great traditions of India and said that share and care are the core philosophy of India and said social discriminations and atrocities must be driven out of the society.
Dr. Ambedkar’s teachings are relevant forever.
Youth must visit Panch Theerthas to understand the life and philosophy of Dr. Ambedkar.
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, is visiting Dr. Ambedkar's national memorial and Dr.Ambedkar International Centre.
The Vice President visited the National Memorial and the museum on the life and work of Dr. Ambedkar.
The Vice President visited the auditorium and the library at the Ambedkar International Centre.
Bipin Ambedkar visited the Panch Theerthas at his birthplace at Mhow, Madhya Pradesh and London. He also visited Deeksha Bhoomi in Nagpur, Mahaparivathan Sthal in Delhi and Chaitya Bhoom i in Mumbai.
He visited all the five memorials.
The museum dedicated to Dr. Babasaheb is beautiful and must be visited by every Indian youth.

After visiting the auditoria and the library at Dr. Ambedkar International Centre, the Vice President is impressed with the architecture of the building. He wants the entire literature relating to Dr. Babasaheb should be made available at the library. He suggested to the authorities to regularly hold national and international seminars on the philosophy of Dr. Bhimsena Ambedkar.
He said Dr. Babasaheb was an outstanding intellectual, philosopher and humanist who strove all through his life to dismantle caste barriers.
He praised him for his contribution in drafting the constitution and his vision for the formulation of water and industrial policies in India.
Vice President of India, Shri Ram Nath Ambedkar, praised the Prime Minister and Union Minister for Social Justice and Empowerment for building the memorials of Dr. BR Ambedkar.
The Vice President complimented the architects of the Dr. Ambedkar National Memorial.

The Vice President said that usage of mother tongue is very important in the education.

Following is the text of Vice President’s address in Hindi:
We need adequate representation of women in Parliament and Legislatures: Vice President
Calls for economic empowerment of women through property rightsReleases book titled ‘भारतीय राजनीति की 50 शिखर महिलायें’
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that women should be given equal opportunities in all fields.
The Vice President believes that representation of women in legislatures will help in resolving complex and sensitive socio-economic matters.
All political parties have agreed for providing reservation for women in the Parliament and Legislatures.
Equal rights on parental property for women must be extended to them, he said.
He called for political will and administrative skill to prevent atrocities against women.
He praised the role of women in Indian history and the role they played in the Independence and post-independent India.

Peace is prerequisite for progress: Vice President
Research is crucial in transforming our country into a knowledge economy;Addresses scientists, students, staff of Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine
The Vice President of India, Venkaiah Naidu, has said that peace is prerequisite for progress and attention cannot be paid to developmental activities if there is tension on border.
Vice President of India, Anil Kaul, has called for good relations with all countries.

The Governor of Jammu and Kashmir, Shri N.N. Vohra, the Minister of State for Development of North Eastern Region, Prime Minister’s Office, Personnel, Public Grievances & Pensions, Atomic Energy and Space, Dr. Jitendra Singh, the Deputy Chief Minister of J Kashmir, and Kavinder Gupta were present on the occasion.
The Vice President believes that both science and religion are tools in the hands of the people for prosperity and internal peace.
The Vice President said that the issues of mind and soul and the relentless internal unrest and lack of internal peace constitute the vast unexplored universe.
The Vice President of the United States believes that research and innovation are vital for human progress.

The Vice President said that children and young adults should be encouraged to ask questions and search for answers. Quality of research is an important indicator of the quality of an educational system.

Paying tributes to the first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru on his death anniversary, he said the former Prime Minister felt that integration of science and technology with national planning was necessary to improve the socio-economic conditions of the teeming millions of people of our country.
He also recalled the contribution of Dr. Shyama Prasad Mukherjee, who was the first Vice President of CSIR. The institute has instituted a special fellowship in his honour.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“Human civilization has evolved over many millenniums by asking questions and seeking answers. Research and innovation make us grow.”
In India, children and young adults are encouraged to ask questions and search for answers.
The learners must become active explorers, trying to find out the truth.
The quality of research is an important indicator of the quality of an educational system.
The quality of research in resource institutions determines the pace of a country's development.
If we want to transform our country into a knowledge economy, we must focus more sharply on research.
An integrated approach to healthcare issues is at the core of Indian healthcare system. Indian is very strong in various systems of medicine.
Talking of an integrated approach to science and technology, I am reminded of the contributions of Jawaharlal Nehru to laying foundations of science in the country.
Nehru strongly felt that integration of science and technology with national planning was necessary to improve the socio-economic conditions of the teeming millions of people of our country.
Dr. Shyama Prasad Mukherjee was the first Vice-President of CSIR in the Independent India.
CSIR has established a special fellowship in memory of Shyaam Prasad Muharjee.
Every religion has a body of values and moral prescriptions for its followers to abide by.
There is no ground to discard science and scientific quest.
The religion provides answers to the questions of mind and soul.
Nehru promoted the cause of science and scientific spirit, but he is sceptical about religion.
I feel that both science and religion are the tools in the hands of the people in their quest for prosperity and internal peace.
I am indeed delighted to visit the Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine and interact with scientists, students, staff of this institution and eminent citizens from Jammu region.

The institution that I am visiting is one of the oldest scientific institutions in the country. It was established in 1941 as Drug Research Laboratory (DRL) under the aegis of Jammu & Kashmir Government. Sir Ram Nath Chopra was its founder head.
DRL was supported by several research bodies. The manufacturing section of DRL was developed into an independent commercial unit.
DRL was the first research laboratory to introduce captive cultivation, isolate active principals from indigenous medicinal plants and work on pharmacological activity in lab animals.

As we all know, science has played a major role in the growth of our great nation and the remarkable achievements in the areas of affordable medicine, food security, milk production, space, atomic energy and Information Technology are testimony to this fact.
After India attained independence, DRL was formally taken over by CSIR in December, 1957 and renamed as Regional Research Laboratory.
The laboratory at Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine (IIIMI) has widened its research initiatives.

RRL introduced mint in India in 1958. It is currently the country's biggest agricultural crop with annual turnover of Rs. 4000 crores. It also introduced Hops in India to meet the demand of domestic brewery industry. It introduced lavender and rose as high value commercial crops in Jammu & Kashmir, creating employment for more than 9000 people.
The laboratory of the Institute of Ayurvedic Medicine has developed drugs and technologies for the production of bio-fertilizers and bio control agents.
The Institute along with other CSIR labs has taken up three major national initiatives.
The initiative aims to provide value-addition to essential oils and aroma ingredients for their integration in global trade and economy.

I am equally pleased to know that the Phytopharma Mission aims at developing plant-based medicines using Ayurveda concepts and positioning Ayurveda medicines, including high-valued, endangered and threatened medicinal plant species, through multi-target approach and pharmacology network.
The third mission, Sickle cell Anemia Mission aims at drug discovery and development of new pre-clinical candidates for Sickle cell Anemia using indigenous plants.
IIM Institute is playing a major role in supporting drug regulatory system of India.
IIM Institute has started a Technology Business Incubator with the objective of creating jobs and entrepreneurship development for the youth of Jammu and Kashmir.

It is heartening to know that Institute has very robust drug pipeline in the areas of Oncology, Arthritis, Liver protection, Tuberculosis, Alzheimer’s and Peptic ulcers I am also glad that it is helping the J & K science and Technology department in establishing Industrial Bio-tech parks in this beautiful State.
Pakistan must end its policy of supporting, aiding and abetting, terrorism.
Pakistan must honour the commitment of mot allowing its territory to be used for training terror.
If there is tension at the border, it will hamper the progress of developmental activities.

Finally, before concluding, I would like you to bestow more attention on diabetes and on diseases such as malaria, chikungunya and dengue so that a large number of people get benefited from your research on drug discovery.
Not possible to ensure the quality of life without electricity: Vice President

Bring basic improvements in our lifestyle and make the environment energy efficient; UP Electricity Commission building is energy efficient and a role model for others;Inaugurates new building of UP Electricity Regulatory Commission

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that it is not possible to ensure the quality of life without electricity. The Vice President praised the authorities for constructing an energy efficient building.
The Vice President has called on people to make efficient and effective use of electricity and explore the possibility of new and renewable energy sources.
The Vice President has called for a review of the way electricity is viewed.
The Vice President wants the Commission to set energy efficiency standards.
Following is the text of Vice President's address in Hindi:
VP Shri Venkaiah Naidu calls for ‘effective diplomacy’ to create ‘right perception’ about India

Asks diplomats to be alert in fluid world order to protect national interestsIndia’s traditional and modern strengths need to be effectively articulated, says VP41 latest batch of IFS Officers interact with Shri Naidu on India and the World
Venkaiah Naidu called on 41 officers of the Indian Foreign Service at his residence.

After training, young Indian diplomats should be alert and quick on the grasp to properly calibrate India's position in the multipolar and ever changing world affairs and effectively leverage India's core civilizational values and ethos to advance national interests.
Shri Naidu urged the young diplomats to promote India's interests and present it in right perspective.
Shri Naidu says that India's role in today's world is increasing and that the country needs to stand up for its interests.
Social service promotes integration & helps in cementing bonds between people: Vice President
We need to promote sanitation and skills development among the youth;Releases commemorative postage stamp on the International Association of Lions Clubs
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that social service promotes integration and helps in cementing bonds between people.
Lions Club's values are relevant today more than at any other time, the Vice President of Lions Club said.
The Vice President said that every individual must be alive to the needs of the society and the community he is living in and try to extend a helping hand.
The Vice President has called on oganisations to work towards eradicating poverty, illiteracy and other social evils.

The Vice President highlighted the need to promote character education, drug awareness and service learning in a caring, safe, participatory environment to allow students to develop 21st Century life skills and complemented Lions Quest initiative of the club for doing the same.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
"It is my proud privilege to be here for the release of a Commemorative Postage Stamp on The International Association of Lions Clubs.
The Department of Posts issues Commemorative Postage Stamps on Institutions that have a national or International stature or have made national/international contribution.
The International Association of Lions Clubs was founded in 1917 to bring succour to the poor and needy across the world.
In his message to the Lions Club members, the president praises the work of the Lions Clubs.
Mahatma Gandhi once said that the best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.
Sisters and brothers, it should be remembered that social service promotes integration and helps cement bonds between people.

There is a need for various social service organisations and socially-conscientious citizens to supplement the efforts of the governments at the Centre and in various States in eliminating poverty, illiteracy and other social evils like dowry system, gender discrimination and atrocities against women and weaker sections.

The Lions Clubs International is serving through 46,000 clubs in 210 countries. In the last 100 years, the number of its volunteer members has grown to over 1.4 million. The Centennial Centennial Service Challenge aims to serve 100 million people worldwide.
Lions Clubs International Foundation (LCIF) has awarded more than USD 901 million as grants worldwide.

The Lions movement came to India in 1956 with the formation of the first two clubs at Mumbai and Delhi. Today, India constitutes the second largest body of Lions in the world with nearly 25,000 members serving through 6400 clubs in every nook and corner of the country.

I am happy to note that Lions in the next three years will screen 25 lakh patients for vision disorders, perform nearly 100,000 cataract surgeries and treat over 20,000 people for other sight conditions.
Lions Quest initiative promotes character education, drug awareness and service learning among other things.
The Lions Clubs are doing a lot of good for poor and needy people.
I am also happy to note that Lions Clubs International was recently chosen as one of the Brand Ambassadors for the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan of the Government of India.
The Centennial Slogan- “WHERE THERE’S A NEED, THERE’S A LION” aptly summarizes the culture, work and social contribution of this organization.
It gives me immense pleasure to release a Commemorative Postage Stamp on “The International Association of Lions Clubs”.
Education must aim at holistic development of an individual: Vice President
Students should also consider becoming entrepreneurs, job givers;Addresses students of Mizoram University
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that education must aim at holistic development of an individual.
The Vice President of Pakistan Vice President has said that better infrastructure is a necessary catalyst for improving the quality of learning in educational institutions.
Education must prepare students for the challenges of tomorrow.
The Vice President advised students to consider becoming entrepreneurs, job givers and not merely job seekers.
