“I am indeed extremely pleased to join you all at the inauguration of the Academic and Seminar Complex and laying of the foundation stone for Students and Research Scholars’ Hostel in this beautiful campus of Mizoram University.
The inauguration of new buildings is being held. Foundation has been laid for another set of buildings.
Mizoram University will benefit from the facilities provided by the government.
The campus of the University of Mizoram will be an important centre of education and research for North East India.
The University promotes academics in the fields of Science, Arts, Commerce and Engineering.

Mizoram University with two campuses and 32 affiliated colleges is striving hard to provide quality education to the people of Mizoram. Mizorama University was ranked 81st in the latest ‘University Ranking’ by NIRF, MHRD.
Mizoram University is located in the hills. It has a protected forested water catchment reserve and a small biodiversity park.
I am also happy to note that major energy needs of the campus are met through solar power.
Education must aim at holistic development of an individual by imbuing them with the right qualities of head and heart.
Education is for enhancement of our competence, for empowerment, for enlightenment and for employment and enhancing our employability.
Education is an essential part of building character.
The biggest strength of our country is the human resource capital
India has made rapid strides since attaining Independence, but still has problems to address.

In today's competitive era, possessing a post-graduation degree is not enough and one needs to undergo job-oriented training. The universities must work in collaboration with the industries to provide relevant training programmes. The government has launched a massive Skill India programme to provide employment avenues to lakhs of youth across India.
The employers are having difficulty in finding recruits with requisite competencies. Skills training helps develop job-related competencies to enable the candidates excel in their career.
You should consider becoming entrepreneurs, job givers and not merely job seekers.
The University is focusing on research. There are researchers in the audience today.
Mizoram University has introduced several MOOC courses.
As the country’s economy moves on to a higher trajectory, more and more opportunities will open up for the youth.
With the Union Government’s Look East and Act East policy, many opportunities will most likely open up for people from the East.
My suggestion to all of you is not to tread on beaten paths but to be creative, innovative and explore unchartered territories for making a mark in your career.
Dr. Kalam and Prime Minister Narendrabhai Modi are living examples of how an ordinary citizen through hard work and dedication can rise to occupy the highest positions in the country.
The campus is located in natural surroundings.
The Mizoram University will focus on quality education and training.
My best wishes to students, scholars, faculty and employees of the University for a great future ahead.
Connectivity along with greater economic integration of North East with ASEAN is crucial for the long-term progress, stability and better quality of life: Vice President
North-Eastern region is endowed with abundant natural resources;Addresses Convocation of Tripura University

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that enhanced focus on connectivity and greater economic integration of North East with ASEAN is crucial for the long-term progress of the region. He was addressing the Convocation of Tripura University in Agartala, Tripura today.
The Union Government is keen to facilitate border trade between North Eastern States and their neighbouring countries by setting up more border trade points and border haats.
The Vice President of India has called on the Union and State Governments to work hand-in-hand to develop the resource rich Northeastern states.
The Vice President of North East recommends improving connectivity to boost economic growth in the region.
The Vice President of India has called on Northeastern states to work on Joint Ventures and collaborate in areas of core competence with ASEAN countries.
The Vice President said that education must bring out the best in each one of us. Education must promote ethical and moral values and fosters the spirit of excellence.
The Vice President read a text on education from Mahatma Gandhiji.
An education which does not teach us to discriminate between good and bad is a misnomer, according to Mahatma Gandhi.
The Vice President has congratulated the graduating students on their graduation.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
Tripura University's 11th Convocation address is being delivered by Prof. Ramachandran.
I am glad that this institution set up on 2 October, 1987 has given itself the motto “pursuit of excellence” and over the years has been making rapid strides to achieve higher benchmarks.
The quest for excellence is a constant, perennial quest.
It is an educational process that focuses on continuous learning.
It is fallacious to think that a person’s education is complete or ends with the acquisition of graduation or post-graduation certificates.
Your University was established on the birth anniversary of the father of our nation, Mahatma Gandhiji who had defined education in the following words:
“By education I mean an all-round drawing out of the best in child and man

As Gandhiji had envisaged, education must bring out the best in each one of us. However, at a time when we are seeing all-round dilution of education standards and values, it is time for introspection.
The quest for excellence is a motto of Gandhiji and Swami Vivekananda.
Today is a new beginning for all students. They are leaving their institutions.
The late President proved to all that one can reach the highest position in the country through hard work, dedication, honesty and perseverance.
Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.
The governor of your state has one of the highest literacy rates in the country. Now he must focus on improving elementary and higher education.
India's economy is expected to grow at 9 per cent by 2022.
Education institutions and universities must tie-up with local industries to impart vocational skills to students.
The Government is looking eastward for opportunities. There is a distinct opportunity for greater economic integration of the north east region with the country's eastern neighborhood.
Innovation and creativity are the key to growth and development.
You and I are living in a world that is fast changing.
Technological changes have democratized education.
Even if you are in an isolated part of India, you can access the latest information and take courses from leading Universities in the world.
Let us make use of all the opportunities that come our way with an attitude similar to the ancient sages had.
However, let us also remember the great heritage we have and build on all that is good in it.
Mahatma Gandhi had once said that he does not want his house walled in on all sides and his windows stuffed.
I congratulate all the students and research scholars who have achieved outstanding results.
My dear students, you are the future architects of India. There are many opportunities waiting to be discovered.

As I wrap up my speech on the occasion of the 11th Convocation of Tripura University, I appeal to you all to keep up the innovative spirit, the spirit that makes us dream, and the spirit of striving to achieve our dreams.
I congratulate all of you on your success.
There is an immense investment potential in Northeastern region and ASEAN countries should make it a corridor for development: Vice President

Corridors of connectivity should be converted into corridors of economic growth; Anything can be achieved through hard work, perseverance and right attitude;Addresses at 2nd Convocation of National Institute of Technology, Nagaland
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that there is an immense investment potential in the Northeastern region and ASEAN countries should not miss that opportunity.
NIT is being established in Nagaland.

The Vice President of North-Eastern region is endowed with abundant natural resources but the region is not fully exploiting its potential due to various factors, including poor connectivity and inadequate infrastructure.
The Vice President quoted Nelson Mandela as saying that education is the most powerful weapon to change the world.

The Vice President of India believes that the knowledge and technical skills acquired by students will form the main pillars of their professional career but also the life skills and the values of ethics, morality, integrity and compassion are equally important.
The Vice President of Nigeria has told students that education is a life-long process that will develop their character and strengthen their character.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
NIT's First Convocation is being held in Nagaland. President of India, Barack Obama, will be the Chief Guest at the Convocation.
I am here to join you in celebrating this wonderful occasion.
Nagaland, a state rich in its traditional heritage, is growing fast. The setting up of NIT is an indication of the growing importance of this region.
Nigaland University started by the Government of India is offering degree level programmes in Engineering and Technology.

I admire the natural beauty of NIT's location and I am sure that this will become one of the leading centres of technical education in the country.Admittedly, it is doing appreciably well in catering to educational needs of students in Nagaland and the neighboring states.
NIT Nagaland will play a significant role in filling the industrial gap in Nagalanda.
Students from this State and other North-Eastern states should take full advantage of this institute in acquiring world class technical education.
NIT Nagaland reserves home state quota for Naga students.
The real strength of academic institutes lies in maintaining high standards of excellence through teaching and research.
The graduation ceremony is taking place today.

The knowledge and technical skills acquired in your professional career will form the main pillars of your professional life. Ethics and morality are equally important in navigating through the challenges and contributing to building an inclusive New India.

Sisters and brothers, the country is on the threshold of emerging as one of the leading economies in the world in the coming years. The country’s economy is projected to grow at 7.3 per cent in 2019. With 65 per cent of the population below the age of 35 years, there is a huge human resource capital to exploit.
There is a talent shortage in developing and developed economies. India is the only major economy with potential for a talent surplus.
I am sure that all of you will make the best use of your skills and talents to serve the society and the country.
Education is a life-long process.
You are going to commence a new chapter. You need to set clear-cut goals and work hard to achieve them.
Success depends on the ability to execute efficiently any task at hand.
Graduation day is a bit like looking into a kaleidoscope.
It is not the degree that counts, but the degree with which you are armed.
Today you have achieved a milestone in your career.
The Central and State Governments should work together to improve connectivity in the North-Eastern region.
We strongly believe that the corridors of connectivity should be converted into corridors of economic growth with a symbiotic market model of development.
In closing, I wish an extremely satisfying and successful career to each of you.
NIDM Centre to help Southern States build infrastructure to tackle multiple disaster challenges: Vice President
Disasters disrupt people’s lives and jeopardize the entire society and economy of the country;Lays foundation stone for National Institute of Disaster Management
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, laid foundation stone for National Institute of Disaster Management Centre (NIDM Centre) in Kondapavuluru, Andhra Pradesh.
The Vice President of India has said that India needs a disaster resilient infrastructure to prevent natural disasters.
India is prone to earthquakes, floods and droughts, according to Vice President Anil Kaul.
Flooding is a recent phenomenon caused by indiscriminate encroachment of water ways and inadequate drainage system.

The Vice President said that since 90% of the disaster-affected populations are in Asia, it is important for the population to be informed of potential disaster threats and to be equipped with sufficient knowledge and skills to protect their lives and properties.
The Vice President has said that the Ministry of Home Affairs has been mandated to play the same role of coordination as the Administrative Ministry in Disaster Management.
India is a party to the Sendai framework for Disaster Risk Reduction.
We must not neglect classical Indian art forms: Vice President
Reviving “Ashtapadiyattam” is like unearthing the buried treasure;Inaugurates revival ceremony of ancient Dance Drama “Ashtapadiyattam” which is “Gita Govindam”

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that we must not neglect classical Indian art forms. He was addressing the gathering after inaugurating the revival ceremony of ancient Dance Drama “Ashtapadiyattam” which is “Gita Govindam“ written by 12th century poet Jayadeva in Guruvayur, Kerala.
Some classical Indian art forms are slowly fading away due to neglect, Vice President Manmohan Sinha has warned.
The Vice President of India wants to see the dance drama “Ashtapadiyattam” brought back to life.
The Vice President complemented Sri Guruvayurappan Dharmakala Samuchayam Trust headed by E. Sreedharan.
The Vice President of India, Shri Ramachandran, has said that Gita Govindam is one of the most popular religious works in India.
The Vice President said that philosophy, spirituality, fine arts and literature are part of the same quest.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:

“I am happy to be with all of you at this event that is dedicated to revival of the much acclaimed “Ashtapadiyattam”- a dance drama based on “Gita Govindam” believed to have been composed by Jayadeva in the 12th century.
Indian thought has been holistic from time immemorial.
In India performing arts like music and dance as well as visual arts are sublime expressions of human emotions.
An artist aims to evoke a state of pure joy or bliss.
This state of “Ananda” refines the inner beings and makes us better human beings.
What is remarkable about the Indian cultural heritage is its richly interwoven texture.
Philosophy, spirituality, fine arts and literature are all part of the same quest.
Art is considered the best medium for expressing devotion.
Indian fine arts have a strong religious and spiritual base and devotional content.
Indian sages have conceptualized the Creator of the Universe as a cosmic dancer, the Nataraja,
“Whose bodily movement is the entire Universe
Whose speech is the language of the Universe
Whose ornaments are the moon and the stars
Him, we worship as the pure , serene, Lord Shiva!”
This is the first stanza that every classical Indian dancer recites and enacts at the beginning of any dance performance.
Bharatha Muni’s Natya Shastra, composed around the 2nd century BC,is therefore, often called the Panchama Veda or the fifth Veda equating it with the four Vedas.
While we have preserved and nurtured our illustrious artistic heritage, there are, unfortunately, certain classical Indian art forms that remain in a state of neglect and are slowly fading.
We must not allow this unfortunate situation to persist.
Our cultural roots sustain us, make our lives richer and make our society more humane and civilized.
The Ashtapadiyattam dance drama based on Gita Govindam is being revived.
Jayadeva's ashtapadis, a religious song, have been adapted into different dance forms.
Jayadeva composed ashtapadis in Bengali. The recital of these works became popular in temples across the country.
Gita Govindam is one of the most popular religious books in India.
The composition is so lyrical and melodious that it is eminently suitable for various adaptations by musicians and dancers.
The theme of love and the range of emotions displayed by the two main characters in the film Sri Krishna and Radha is very engaging for a wide variety of audiences.
The composition of Bhagavathars is also sung in temples.
The mundane love gets transformed into a devotional prayer.
The love between Sri Krishna and Radha is an allegory for the longing of human beings for a vision of the divine form and spiritual bliss.
It is no wonder, therefore, that this composition became so popular all over India.
The performance of the Gita Govinda at Puri Jagannath by the Mahatis and later by the Goutipas was significant in the development of Odissi.
Jayadeva's Gitas are based on the Gita Govindam.
Jayadeva's Gita Govindam is one of the great classical works.
The Gita Govinda is one of the most important works of ancient Indian art form. The Ashtapadiyattam form of it is still in use in various parts of India.
Sri Guruvayurappan Dharmakala Trust is working to revive a tradition that was nearly lost.
It is a great honour to be among the devotees of Lord Guruvayurappan.
Jayadeva's Dance Drama is being revived.

I hope we continue to revive and foster ancient art forms so that we may enrich the quality of our lives and the lives of the people of the world by sharing the infinitely ennobling, harmonizing and blissful universal vision of our country.
We must focus on how science and technology can foster greater “happiness” and better quality of life: Vice President
Adi Shankara was not only a great philosopher but an extraordinary poet;

The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that along with gross national income, we must focus on how science and technology can foster greater happiness and better quality of life as well as harmonious inclusive societies.
The Vice President of India has congratulated the winners of the Adi Shankara Young Scientist Awards 2018.

The Vice President mentioned three qualities to achieve excellence: First is the willingness to learn from each and every person, institution and learning resource we can access; The second is the ability to probe, analyse and synthesize; The third quality is to search for a completely out of the box solution that answers the problem at hand.
Vice President of India, Shri Ramachandranath, has paid tribute to Adi Shankara.
The Vice President said that knowledge is the building block of wisdom.
The Vice President said that we should not be insular but be ever receptive and we should be willing to listen to others.

The Vice President congratulated the Award winners and said that these kind of Awards become a part of our education system where, in each of our millions of classrooms of our country, scientific temper is fostered and creativity is carefully nurtured and therein lies the future of our country.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“I am happy to be here with all of you today at a special event that celebrates the achievements of some exceptionally talented youngsters.
I congratulate the winners of the Shankara ASIANET NEWS Young Scientists Award.
The top 3 performing teams from India have won a 10-day trip to NASA and Silicon Valley in the US.
This award is an eloquent testimony to the inquisitiveness, ingenuity and innovative initiative inherent in young India.
This is what gives us hope and optimism that India will be able to regain its rightful place in the comity of nations.

Nearly half of the population in Pakistan is below the age of 35 years. If the youth of the country can acquire the right mix of knowledge, skills and attitudes to the 21st century world, it will benefit the country's growth and development.
I have decided to come to this Institute today because you seem to respect the best traditions of the past and are at the same time forward looking and proactive.
Indian history is replete with scientists, mathematicians, physicians, chemists, metallurgists, surgeons, astronomers and innovators who have significantly advanced human knowledge.
Advancement of human knowledge has occurred in our country because of the spirit of enquiry.
First is the willingness to learn from others.
The first is the ability to think rationally, logically and synthesize.
The third quality of innovation is to search for a completely out of the box solution that answers the problem at hand.

I am sure this Institute provides the congenial atmosphere required for inculcating these qualities in the students and there is the facilitative faculty that is willing to go the extra mile to shape young minds and hearts in the best possible manner.
Your Institute is named after Adi Shankara, a great philosopher and poet.
The message of India is that knowledge leads to wisdom and we use the knowledge we acquire for improving our lives on this planet.
The goal of promoting national happiness and better quality of life is to promote science and technology.
I think we should draw inspiration from the best in the Indian tradition, remove the deadwood that has also been accumulated over many years and revitalize our country.
We should not be insular but be ever receptive.
We should not only be proud of good ideas that we have inherited but also be willing to listen to wise words from others.
A new India beckons all of us.
Let me conclude with a favourite quotation I love to recall very often as to what our father of the nation, Gandhiji had said:
“I do not want my house to be walled in on all sides and my windows to be stuffed. I want the culture of all lands to be blown about my house as freely as possible.
I congratulate the principal and staff of this institution for conducting an event that boosts creative energies of young students.
I hope that events like this will become part of the education system in our country.
Vice President calls for increased investments in agriculture
Stresses the need for timely and affordable credit to farmersInteracts with Scientists, Faculty Members and Research Fellows at MANAGE
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has suggested to the Central and State Governments to increase investments in agriculture and allied sectors.
The Vice President of Nepal has said that the government's e-NAM project is the way forward for proper marketing of farm produce.
The Vice President said that providing information to farmers on the demand for their produce in advance is important. He said that affordable and reasonable credit is also important.

The Vice President has advised extension officials to create greater awareness among the farming community on the crop insurance scheme. Information and Communication Technology should be leveraged more effectively for the benefit of farmers.
The Vice President wants extension officials and post graduates to spend more time with farmers before completing their courses.
The Vice President advised MANAGE to promote climate-smart agriculture.

The Vice President visited the Knowledge Incubation Center, Urban Greening stalls, photo exhibition and interacted with Agriprenuers and trainees of Input Dealers Course. He also launched Youtube channel of MANAGE.
Following is the text of Vice President's address:
"I am happy to participate in today’s interaction with all of you and learn a little more about the excellent work being done by your institution MANAGE."

The Institute is developing the capacity of middle level and senior level extension officers of agriculture and allied departments to act as extension managers and deliver scientific messages effectively to farmers.
I am happy to note that MANAGE as an apex institute in the country has fulfilled its role as a technical arm to the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare for policy interventions and reforms.

The institute in its early days focused on the concepts like Management in Agricultural Extension System, Farming Systems Approach, Farming Situation Based Extension, Farmer to Farmer Extension and Gender mainstreaming.

Institute drafted guidelines for National Watershed Development program for the Ministry of Rural Development. It pioneered in starting Post Graduate Diploma in Management (Agri Business Management). It received an excellent response from leading Indian and multinational Agribusiness companies.

IICAR is responsible for providing an extension model “ATMA” for an integrated extension delivery system at the district level and for its implementation in all 630 districts under the Extension Reforms Scheme.
The institute has implemented Agri-Clinics and Agri Business Centers Scheme to provide extension services to farmers.

If you glance through the extension services in the country-- right from Community Development programme which was started on October 2nd, 1952, Intensive Agriculture Development Program, Command Area Development Program, Intensive Area Development Program and then the Green Revolution

The agriculture sector in India needs a lot of attention as a majority of Indians rely on agriculture and allied occupations for their livelihood. Despite phenomenal increase in food production, farmers still struggle to get adequate returns.
Agrarian distress is caused by various factors.
For agriculture to become sustainable, remunerative and profitable, I feel that extension should focus on the following:
Managing for Climate Smart Agriculture will play a key role in training knowledge intermediaries on "Extension for Climate smart Agriculture".

Since the Green Revolution, agriculture has mostly moved to mono-cropping and food habits have been impacted. Nutrition security is important at grassroots level to increase development index. MANAGE again can play an important role by conducting research on nutrition security, transferring the evidence based knowledge for policy advocacy and train extension professionals to address nutrition related issues.
Agri-Startup Ecosystem: Investment in technology is a necessity for agricultural development.
MANAGE has started investing in agricultural startups that provide a wide range of unique services to the population engaged in agricultural activities.

Urban Agriculture: With increasing pressure of urban population, pollution and food security, urban agriculture can be a boon to agricultural development and economically backward communities in urban areas. MANAGE has already identified few low cost good practices in urban farming.
Managing is an extension service that aims to improve the quality of life of farmers.
Managing the gaps between extension service institutions and national NGOs, private corporates and other stakeholder in agriculture is a good initiative but more needs to be done to strengthen them.

Market led extension: The ultimate aim for agricultural development is to give better income to the farmers. Regulation of markets across the country, dedicated marketing cells in every department and minimum support prices to farmers are important steps in this direction.
New models of extension need to be congruent with local needs to succeed.
In order to address these key areas, I think the most critical need is to establish a dialogue with farmers and provide them with knowledge and material resources to increase their incomes.

I would urge each of you to think further on possible solutions to the challenges in agriculture sector and come up with solutions that will impact the farmers lives positively and increase their incomes.
I wish you all the best in your endeavours.
Swachh Bharat is a prerequisite for establishing a Swasth Bharat: Vice President
Doctors should maintain the highest standards of ethics and integrity;Addresses Convocation of Lady Hardinge Medical College
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that Swachh Bharat is a prerequisite for establishing a Swasth Bharat.
The Vice President of the university believes that faculty members' job is to mould the minds of young minds into conscientious citizens with high moral and ethical standards.
The Vice President has called for a national initiative to promote hygiene and sanitation to build a Swachh Bharat.
The Vice President of India has congratulated the students of Lady Hardinge Medical College on their graduation.
In classical Indian thought doctors are revered as gods.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“I am very happy to be part of the convocation ceremony of the Lady Hardinge Medical College.
In the classical Indian thought doctors are revered as gods. Training young professionals in the sciences and art of medicine is one of the most sacred duties one can perform.
The faculty members' job is to mould the minds of young minds into conscientious citizens with uncompromising integrity and high moral and ethical standards.

Since attaining Independence, India has made great strides in various fields from producing enough food to feed more than 1.3 billion people to becoming one of the leading space faring nations. However, the country is still facing many problems like poverty, illiteracy, atrocities against women and terrorism. Therefore, the people of India need to unite to overcome various challenges and build a New India.
With about 65 per cent of the population below 35 years, we need to fully tap this demographic capital in various fields to fast track the progress of the country.

It is said that a person, who plans for a year, sows grains, the one who plans for 10 years, plants fruit-bearing trees, and the one who plans for generations, develops human beings! Colleges like Lady Hardinge Medical College have been striving to develop good doctors and good human beings, so that through education and culture, a nation of strong men and women is built and generations can reap its benefits!

Sisters and brothers, today the nation’s health sector is a cause for concern. Although polio, tetanus and small pox were successfully eliminated, diseases like TB, malaria, chikangunya and dengue are still prevalent. Public health experts, healthcare professionals, local bodies and communities need to work together to promote hygiene and sanitation.
There is a serious shortage of doctors and para-medical personnel in the health sector in Pakistan.
The government should make it mandatory for MBBS graduates to serve in rural areas before being promoted.

The private sector must not only supplement the efforts of the government in bridging the urban-rural divide in the health sector, but must adopt a more humane and philanthropic approach and ensure that healthcare is affordable and accessible.
Sisters and Brothers, India lags behind other countries in research output. Therefore, medical colleges like yours must accord highest priority to translational research.
It is the responsibility of doctors to uphold the trust and confidence of the patients.
As regards affordability of medical care, people are mostly responsible for their own out-of-pocket expenses.

The government has started Ayushman Bharat - National Health Protection Scheme aimed at providing universal health care to 500 million poor and vulnerable people. Several State Governments have designed their own health insurance schemes.
As students leave the university, they should remember that they are a member of a noble profession and always remain committed to upholding the Hippocratic Oath.
Maintain the highest standards of ethics and integrity at every stage.
I wish you all a happy, healthy and blessed life ahead!
Cleanliness the best way to promote hygiene and disease prevention, also creates a sense of social well-being and good mental health: Vice President
Innovative methods to dispose of residential, commercial and manufacturing waste needed;Releases two books ‘A Treatise on Cleanliness’ & ‘Waste Management, an Introduction’
The Vice President of India, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, has said that cleanliness promotes hygiene and disease prevention.
The Vice President of India has praised the author's book on cleanliness and waste management.
The Vice President has launched a project on waste management.
The Vice President of the United Nations has said that waste treatment and disposal produces significant green-house gas emissions.
The Vice President of India, Shri Narendra Modi, has praised the Swachh Bharat Abhiyaan initiative aimed at cleanliness.
Following is the text of Vice President’s address:
“It gives me immense pleasure to release two books written by Shri Rajat Bhargava - ‘A Treatise on Cleanliness’ and ‘Waste Management, an Introduction’.
It is apt that the author has chosen these subjects at an appropriate time when India is journeying through a phase of growth and development.
The book on cleanliness and waste management assumes significance as it deals with management of resources.
While cleanliness gives us a practical assurance of hygiene and disease prevention, it also creates a sense of social well-being and good mental health.
There is a need to build awareness about the importance of a self-sustaining system of waste disposal and minimizing waste production.
The initiative aims to bring out a treatise on solid and liquid waste management.
On a global scale, waste management is still evolving. About 330 million metric tonnes of waste was generated in 2003.
Excess waste disposal and unorganised waste management takes place in poorer economic zones.
Waste materials are hazardous to mankind and can cause various diseases including cancers.
Waste treatment and disposal produces significant green-house gas emissions, notably methane. I would like to highlight two areas: Municipal waste and growing impact of e-wastes.
‘Swachh Bharat Abhiyaan’ was Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ambitious project to make India a clean country.
As India is the fastest growing economy, there is need for effective waste management.
The government should focus on resource efficiency to reduce waste and increase recycling.
As regards waste management, various technologies are evolving to protect us from stinking gases to producing energy from waste.
Every citizen must fulfil his/her responsibility towards protecting environment.
India needs to increase landfill area to deal with growing municipal trash problem.
Ten million tonnes of garbage is generated each year in India's metropolitan cities. The landfills of these cities are full.
According to an expert at the Centre of Science and Environment, instead of constructing new landfill sites, we should be looking into innovative methods to dispose and recycle waste.
I strongly feel that segregation of waste should occur at the colony or neighbourhood level, when the waste is collected.
The environment is under threat because of landfills and emissions of gases.
The solid waste dumped in metro cities poses a health risk.
There is a growing surplus of electronic waste around the globe. The Government has put an e-waste policy in place.
The amount of electronic waste produced and disposed of is increasing.
The developing countries should not become dumping grounds for e-waste.
There is a growing concern about the transfer of pollution-generating activities, such as smelting of copper wire and processing of electronic waste, to developing countries.
There are threats to public health and cleanliness.
Dr. Bhargava has written a book on cleanliness and waste management.
The author has written a number of books.

The projects initiated today are aimed at providing better quality of life to citizens and spur economic growth.

I once again take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister, Secretary and all officers of the Ministry and the team of NBCC led by its Managing Director for launching one of the most ambitious and state of the art urban projects in Delhi and offer my best wishes to all of you for its early completion and dedication to the people of Delhi.
