Ministry of Civil Aviation Notifies Draft Passenger Charter Defining Rights for air Passengers for Public Consultation
The Draft Passenger Charter defining rights for air passengers is being notified today for public consultation.
The following initiatives are proposed:
The draft passenger charter defining rights for air passengers is being notified today for public consultation.
If the airline is found to be at fault, passengers will be entitled to the following benefits:

When flight is expected to be delayed for more than 4 hrs from the published scheduled time departure or previously revised departure time (communicated more than 24 hours prior to original scheduled departure time), airlines to offer an option of full refund of ticket to the passenger
When flight delays are more than 24 hours, passenger is offered free-of-charge hotel accommodation.
Airlines to compensate passengers for missing connecting flights:
If delay more than 3 hours: INR 5,000
If delay between 4 and 12 hours: INR 10,000
If delay more than 12 hours: INR 20,000

When the flight is stationed on the tarmac for more than 60 minutes, sufficient and free-of-charge hot snacks and beverages are to be provided to the passengers, and b) when the flight is stationed on the tarmac for more than 90 minutes plus no possibility of departure in next 30 minutes, passengers must be de-boarded

In case of flight cancellation and when passenger is informed of the flight cancellation less than two weeks before and up to 24 hrs of the scheduled departure time, the airline must offer an alternate flight allowing the passenger to depart within two hours of the booked scheduled departure time or refund the ticket, as acceptable to the passenger, and b) in case the passenger is not informed up to 24 hours of the scheduled departure time, the airlines must refund the full value of the air ticket
Passenger dies or undergoes bodily injuries onboard an aircraft: Limit of liability to be paid by the airline must be same for both international and domestic passengers
Baggage lost, delayed or damaged will be compensated as follows: Rs. 3,000 per kg for loss, Rs. 1,000 for delay and Rs. 0.01 per kg  for damage.

In case of ticket cancellation, airline not to levy any additional charge for correction in name of the same person when name correction is required up to three characters only and when error in the name spelling is pointed out by the passenger to the airline within 24 hours of making a reservation
Cancellation charges must be printed prominently in the ticket itself and not as fine print. They must also be provided as part of the reservation and ticket documentation.
Under no circumstance will the airline (including the online or offline agent) levy cancellation charges that total more than the basic fare plus fuel surcharge
Passenger allowed Lock-in option for 24 hours(after booking ticket) in which the passenger can cancel or amend the ticket without any additional charges.
Airlines to have seats that are designated as acceptable for persons with disabilities free of charge, which will remain blocked until close to the time of departure

All airports must provide the following medical facilities at the airport: Medical doctor – available at all hours the airport is operational, Ambulance, minimum medical support (including oxygen cylinders and defibrillators), trained medical personnel, Standard Operating Procedures to care for medical emergencies for both inbound and outbound passengers
Airports must provide meet-and-greet facilities for all passengers
Airports must provide toilets outside departure and arrival terminals
Airports/ airlines must provide minimum one Helpdesk for passengers
Airports must provide passengers with free 30-minutes Wi-Fi services
Airports must provide affordable F&B outlets
The consultation process or public consultation will be open for 30 days from today and the results will be notified in 2 months.
The key features of DigiYatra are as follows:.
Digitize air-travel experience: Use of digital technology for enhanced and seamless passenger experience all the way from ticket booking to airport entry check, security check and aircraft boarding
Single-point verification: Passengers enrol in to DigiYatra program through AirSewa and get hassle free entry at airport through E-Gates.
Value-added services for passengers will also be delivered through the DigiYatra programme.
Enhanced security: The programme also enhances security while providing convenience to the passenger
The technical standards for DigiYatra will be published shortly. Airports such as Bangalore, Hyderabad, Kolkata, Varanasi and Vijayawada will roll out this programme by January 2019.
3. AirSewa app: AirSEWA app brings together all the stakeholders on a common platform to ensure timely and effective handling of customer grievances and to disseminate real-time data.
AirSewa v1.5 to be launched by July 2018
Registered Traveller Program - Registration of DigiYatra ID
Redesigned Mobile App and Web application for AirSewa including UI/UX refresh to make it service friendly
Social Media Login enabled that allows users of Facebook and Google to access AirSewa
Grievance Reporting on Social Media platformssuch as Twitter and Facebook using AirSewa
Comprehensive FAQs and Chat-bot interface
Updated Flight Status and Flight Schedule Information
Information on facilities and services available across all airports in India
Ability to update the airport information content and publish approved content to Mobile and Web app
Both domestic and international airlines are allowed to offer internet services and mobile services on-board an aircraft in Indian airspace provided certain security requirements are met:
Internet services can be provided from the moment a plane takes off and personal electronic devices (PED) have to be put on flight mode
Mobile services can be allowed only when an aircraft is over an altitude of 3,000 metres
All approvals have been recently provided and now interested stakeholders need to apply for licenses and regulatory clearances.
The Ministry of Civil Aviation has launched several initiatives aimed at improving the passenger air travel experience.
Shri Suresh Prabhu reviews Skill Development in Aviation Sector and the progress being made on developing National Air Cargo Policy
The minister for civil aviation has ordered the concerned to prepare a comprehensive development plan for skilling people in the aviation sector.

During the review meeting, the Minister stated that the demand for aviation skilled personnel has been rising commensurately with the boom in the civil aviation sector witnessed in the last 3-4 years Recognizing this demand and to bolster the Skill India Mission, Shri Suresh Prabhu made the following observations:
There is a need for more skill development centres across all States.
The business model of the Aviation University should be re-looked in light of the growing demand for human skilled resources in the Indian Civil Aviation sector.
Training process re-engineering – outline actionable ideas to modify the existing training process to enhance the quality of the output as well as to make the system more efficient
A comprehensive development plan on skill development should be prepared along with funding related strategies that will aid the capacity building required in the sector
Shri Suresh Prabhu reviewed the progress on developing National Air Cargo Policy.
Sufficient land should be earmarked in the upcoming airports for cargo operations.
Should create air cargo trans-shipment hubs in India – sourcing cargo from neighbouring states and partner countries.
The policy should aim at creating inter-modal hubs and should have air-sea, air-road, air-inland waterways connectivity
Geographical location and distinct products related to that location should be kept in mind while developing the cargo policy

Stressing on the need for skilling the people in aviation sector and to have national air cargo policy in place, Shri Prabhu directed the concerned in the Ministry to work on the observations made in the review meeting and come up with actionable items soon.
Committed to augmentation of Airport capacity through NABH (Nextgen Airports For Bharat) Nirman initiative : Suresh Prabhu

Site Clearance Approval for setting up of Greenfield International Airport at Purander, Pune grantedIn-principle approval accorded to Govt of Uttar Pradesh for setting up of Noida International Greenfield Airport at Jewar

The government is committed to building airport capacity. Suresh Prabhu, Minister for Civil Aviation, will focus on improving passenger amenities, promoting cargo handling facilities and early operationalisation of 56 new airports under UDAN scheme.

The Minister of Transport Suresh Prabhu has given site clearance approval to the Greenfield International Airport at Purander, Pune and Noida International Greenfield Airport at the North of Jewar Village, Utta Pradesh.

The site clearance approval has been granted to Pune Greenfield Airport. The agency executing the project will try not to close the existing Pune airport and will take up the matter with Ministry of Defence.

MoCA had granted site clearance to the Noida International Greenfield Airport on July 06, 2017. The U. P. Government appointed Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority (YEIDA) as the implementing agency on its behalf. YEIDA obtained the No Objection Certificate (NOC) from the Ministry of Defence on January 11, 2018. The Minister of Defence has given in-principle approval for setting up the airport at North of Jewar village, Uttar Pradesh.
Biggest Airport, after Mumbai, to be developed in Mopa, Goa

A joint team of the Airports Authority of India and Commerce Logistics Department will visit Goa on 7th-8th May 2018 to facilitate the development of cargo hubs at the new airport to be constructed at Mopa in Goa.
Goa will become a logistics hub of India after a second airport becomes functional in 2020.
Mopa airport will be upgraded with an investment of about 1.5 trillion rupees.
Boost to Airport Infrastructure in Lucknow, Chennai and Guwahati
Cabinet approves Upgradation and Expansion of airport infrastructure at Lucknow, Chennai & Guwahati Airport

Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs has approved the expansion and upgradation of integrated terminals at Chennai, Guwahati and Lucknow Airports at a cost of Rs.2467 crore, Rs.1383 crore and Rs.1232 crore.
Highlights of the three projects are as follows:
Lucknow Airport is planning to build a new integrated terminal building.
Chennai Airport: Total built up area of the proposed terminal building is 336000 sqm with annual capacity to handle 35 mppa.
Guwahati Airport will build a new terminal building to accommodate passenger growth up to 2026-27.

In the Union Budget 2018-19, the government of India has given more importance to infrastructure sector. The government has brought out National Civil Aviation Policy (NCAP). The policy aims to provide robust air connectivity throughout the length and breadth of the country. It also envisages to create an ecosystem which encourages economic growth of India.
India's domestic aviation sector is growing at the highest rate in the world.

To meet the growing demand, Government of India has launched a new initiative of NABH Nirman (NextGen Airports for Bharat), wherein systems and processes are geared to provide enhanced airport capacity to handle 1 billion trips in the next 10 to 15 years.
Airport capacity upgradation and expansion require both development of new greenfield airports and expansion of existing brownfield airports.
Airports Authority of India (AAI) is planning to invest up to Rs.20178 Crores in the next 4 to 5 years.
AAI has already awarded the works at Agartala, Calicut, Port Blair and Chennai. It is in the process of approving the works for upgradation and expansion of capacity at Lucknow and Guwahati Airports.

The government has approved new greenfield airports for Noida International Airport (Jewar), Mopa Airport (Goa), Purandar Airport (Pune), Bhogapuram Airport (Visakhapatnam), Dholera Airport (Ahmedabad), Hirasar Airport (Rajkot). Capex outlay of up to Rs.50000 crores is expected in the development of New Greenfield Airports.
Suresh Prabhu lauds Telecom Commission’s decision to allow in-flight connectivity
Promises earliest implementation with close Follow-Up
The Telecom Commission has approved the proposal for in-flight connectivity within Indian airspace.
He said that connectivity to the ground and smart phones and tablets mean that airlines are able to bring dramatic and cost effective enhancements to the passenger experience.
Sh. Prabhu is happy with the government's decision to improve air services.
Sindhudurg Airport will be a boost for Aviation Sector in Maharashtra
Commerce Minister reviews work of Sindhudurg Airport
Construction of airport building and runway for airport at Sindhudurg, Maharashtra
Maharashtra will get a new airport at ParuleChipi in 2018. Work on the project will be completed in June this year.
Sindhudurg airport is being built at an estimated cost of 520 crores.
Sindhudurg airport will have the capacity to handle 200 departing and 200 arriving passengers per day. It will also be able to accommodate International charter flights.
Sindhudurg airport will be built. The Ministry of Civil Aviation has given in-principle approval.

The construction of taxi way, apron and isolation bay has been completed and work on the airfield ground lighting is on. Construction of passenger terminal building, ATC tower and technical building is on in full swing.
Maharashtra needs an airport in Sindhudurg to improve connectivity to Konkan region of Maharashtra, Goa, North Karnataka and Western Maharashtra.
Shri Piyush Goyal Reviews Coal Production and Dispatches to Generate Adequate Power Supply for the Country

Stressed on the Necessity for Pithead Power Plants to Run at 100 % PLF.Urged States to Use Provisions Under “Flexibility of Utilization of Coal” Rules.Emphasized the need to Improve the Turnaround Time of RakesOfficials of Railways, Coal and Power Ministries to Work in Close Coordination with Chief Secretaries and Power Secretaries of States.Urged that Team Work and Better Coordination among Ministries to Ensure 24X7 Power Supply for the People of India.
Piyush Goyal chaired a review meeting with R.K. Singh, Minister of State (IC) Power and New & Renewable Energy and with top officials of Ministries of Coal, Railways and Power in New Delhi today.
In the meeting, review of Power supply requirement during the ongoing summer and forthcoming winter season and measures to improve the coal stock position in Power Plants were discussed.
A comprehensive review of targets for coal production and dispatches by the coal companies takes place.

Shri Piyush Goyal wants to increase Plant Load Factor (PLF) of various Power Plants of the country. He wants to hold fortnightly meeting of the ministries involved to review the power situation in the country
He stressed on the need for States located far from coal mines to use provisions under "Flexibility of Utilisation of Coal" rules. Gujarat and Maharashtra have already been using these provisions.

He gave clear instructions to the officials of the three ministries to keep a close vigil on the power production and supply situation in the country and to keep in close touch with Chief Secretaries and Power Secretaries of the States for this purpose.
Shri Goyal wants to improve the turnaround time of rakes by better scheduling of trains and optimum utilization of traffic blocks.
He stressed on reducing terminal detention of wagons inside Power Plants and Coal sidings to generate extra capacity.

Last but not the least, he stressed that team effort, better coordination between Ministries involved and the rationalization of work procedures will lead to generation of extra capacity within the existing system and ensure 24X7 power supply for the people of India.
Methodology for Linkage Rationalization for Independent Power Producers (IPPs)
The recommendation of the inter-ministerial task force on rationalizing coal sources of Independent Power Producers (IPPs) having linkages has been approved by the Competent Authority.

1. Coal linkage rationalization shall be an exercise in which the coal linkage of a Thermal Power Plant (TPP) of an Independent Power Producer (IPP) may be transferred from one Coal Company to another based on the availability of coal.
The aim of the exercise is to reduce the landed cost of coal due to reduction in transportation cost and pass on this cost to the consumers.
The exercise aims to reduce the distance by which coal travels on the Railway.
4. The one time process of calling for the requests of the IPP for linkage rationalization shall be undertaken jointly by CIL, SCCL and CEA in a transparent manner.
The IPPs having linkages through allotment route shall inform the regulator about the linkage rationalization.

The fuel supply agreement (FSA) of the rationalized source from any coal company would be signed/implemented only after the appropriate Electricity Regulatory Commission approves the supplementary agreement.
7. Any dispute would be resolved as per the provisions of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act.
Implementation strategy and targets :
The proposed rationalization of linkages is transparent, objective and creates a level playing field for IPPs in each domain.
The reduced landed price of coal shall lead to savings in cost of power generated and shall reduce transportation cost of coal.
The savings achieved due to reduction in the landed price of coal shall be passed on to the Discom/consumers of power.
The exercise shall also help in reducing the load on the transportation infrastructure.

International Conference on the TRIPS CBD Linkage 7-8 June 2018 in Geneva
India is organising an International Conference on TRIPS- CBD Linkage in Geneva on 7-8 June 2018.
India, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, Peru, Philippines, New Zealand, South Africa, Switzerland and the US are joining hands with India on an international conference on indigenous rights.
The Convention on Biological Diversity is a multilateral agreement on sustainable development and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resource.

The Doha Ministerial Declaration in 2001 had tasked the TRIPS Council of the WTO to examine the relationship between the TRIP Agreement and the Convention on Biological Diversity and the protection of traditional knowledge and folklore.

Patents should not be granted for traditional knowledge and associated genetic resources. Developing countries seek to address bio-piracy by requiring disclosure of source or origin of genetic resource by patent applicants.

The Nagoya Protocol to the Convention on Biological Diversity on Access to Genetic Resources and the Fair and Equitable Sharing of Benefits arising from their Utilisation for Research and Commercialization was signed by more than 100 countries.
India is optimistic that during the forthcoming international conference on TRIPs CBD issues the proponents will agree on a clear roadmap for pursuing this issue at the WTO.
5th India CLMV Business Conclave held at Phnom Penh, Cambodia on 21-22 May 2018
Union Minister of Commerce & Industry and Civil Aviation at the 5thIndia CLMV Business Conclave at Phnom Penh
The 5th India-CLMV Business Conclave took place in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
The inaugural session of the 5th India CLMV Conclave was held in Bangkok. The conference was attended by ministers from India, Cambodia, Myanmar, Vietnam and Laos.
Suresh Prabhu, Minister of Commerce & Industry, was accompanied by a business delegation led by Dr. Naushad Forbes, President of the Confederation of Indian Industry.

In his inaugural address, Deputy Prime Ministerof Cambodia, appreciated India’s efforts in organising the 5th India CLMV Business conclave in Cambodia and called for collaboration of CLMV countries and India on agriculture, health, tourism, education and connectivity for promoting regional integration and creation of value chain.
Suresh Prabhu in his address emphasised the need for strengthening India CLMV business and trade relations.
The Indian Commerce Minister proposed setting up of an India Cambodia Chamber of Commerce.
Suresh Prabhu proposed setting up of similar bilateral business forums in Vietnam and Laos.
The inaugural session of the business conclave was held in India.

Creation of Directorate General of Trade Remedies (DGTR) in Department of Commerce
Department of Commerce has created Directorate General of Trade Remedies (DGTR) in the Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

The DGTR will be the apex National Authority for administering all trade remedial measures including anti-dumping, countervailing duties and safeguard measures. It will bring Directorate General of Anti-Dumping and Allied Duties (DGAD), Directorate General Safeguards (DGS), and Safeguard functions of DGFT into its fold.

DGTR has been approved with a sanctioned strength of 112 posts drawn from Directorate General of Anti-dumping and Allied Duties of Department of Commerce and CBEC. The creation of DGTR will result in savings of 49 posts to the Government on account of merging DGAD and DGS.
Sh. Suresh Prabhu, Commerce and Industry Minister has expressed satisfaction over creation of DGTR.
Suresh Prabhu launches Intellectual Property mascot – IP Nani

The Minister of Commerce and Industry launched the Intellectual Property mascot - IP Nani - at the conference on National Intellectual Property Rights Policy in New Delhi today. An anti-piracy video featuring Amitabh Bachchan was also launched by the Minister at the event.
The Minister of Culture and Sports has called for strict implementation of Intellectual Property Rights.
Mascot IP Nani will help the government and enforcement agencies in combating IP crimes with the help of her grandson Aditya.
This character is in line with the World Intellectual Property Organization’s (WIPO) campaign for the World IP Day which celebrates the brilliance, ingenuity, curiosity and courage of women.
The National IPR Policy was approved by the Union Cabinet on 12th May 2016.

In this context, the Cell for IPR Promotion and Management (CIPAM) collaborated with the European Union Intellectual Property Office (EU-IPO) to produce a series of animated videos on IPRs for children.

CIPAM has been conducting IPR awareness workshops for school students since April 2017. It has reached out to over 100 schools sensitizing over 8,000 students on IPRs. CIPAM also engaged with the National Council of Educational Research & Training (NCERT) to curate content on I PRs exclusively for Class 12 school syllabus.
Clarification on Import of Sugar from Pakistan
There have been some misinformed news reports about import of sugar from Pakistan.
The import of sugar from Pakistan has been 1908 MT for a value of USD 0.657 million in 2018-19 and 13,110 MT in 2017-18.
Pakistan imported about 1.5 million MT of sugar in April-May 2018.
Sugar import to Pakistan is free with a customs duty of 100%.
India is under WTO obligation of MFN treatment (equal and non discriminatory treatment to all countries) for all WTO member countries including Pakistan.
The import of sugar from Pakistan has declined in the last two years.
The total import of sugar in the year 2016-17 was 2.14 million MT, which has increased to 2.40 million MT in 2017-18. During April-May 2018, it was 116,512 MT.
Sugar is mostly imported from Brazil.
Sugar if imported under Advanced Authorisation is meant for export only and not for domestic sale.
For making customs duty payment, importers can use MEIS (merchandise Exports from India) scrips.
Quality checks on import of sugar from Pakistan
Custodians should carry out rigorous inspections and sampling for quality testing of sugar imports at Mumbai and Wagha.
The export of sugar in the year 2016-17 amounted to 2.54 million MT, whereas in 2017-18 it amounted to 1.75 million MT. During April-May 2018, the total export amounted to 240,093 MT.
The export of sugar in the year 2016-17 amounted to USD 1,285 million and in 2017-18 to USD 805 million. During April-May 2018, the total export amounted to $91 million.
Statement of country wise imports and exports of sugar during last two years and 2018-19 (Till 14May) is annexed.

The Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs, chaired by the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi has given its approval to the following proposal of the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion:-

II. Investment of Rs. 763.49 crore by National Industrial Corridor Development and Implementation Trust (NICDIT) as equity and debt.
iv. Bidding for trunk infrastructure development by SPV on EPC basis.
The project has enormous economic value in terms of direct and indirect benefits and multiplier effects on the economy.
The proposed development of a Freight Village as Multi Modal Logistics Hub is estimated to generate over four thousand direct and six thousand indirect employment.
The construction of trunk infrastructure will be undertaken in two phases. Phase I will be implemented by financial year 2020-21.
The award of various construction packages will be made in a manner so that the entire construction of trunk infrastructure gets completed simultaneously.
Phase-ll of the project will be reappraised in 2028 or earlier, if so required, for suitable financial sanctions.

The Freight Village will be connected to the Dabla Dedicated Freight Corridor.

CIPAM-DIPP organizes a conference on National IPR Policy
The Cell for IPR Promotion and Management (CIPAM) is organizing a conference on successful completion of two years of the National Intellectual Property Rights Policy (IPR) in New Delhi today.
Shri Suresh Prabhu, Minister of Commerce and Industry and Civil Aviation will launch the IP Mascot at the event. Amitabh Bachchan will also launch an anti-piracy video.
The National IPR Policy aims to create and exploit synergies between all forms of intellectual property. It sets in place an institutional mechanism for implementation, monitoring and review.
The Cell for IPR Promotion and Management (CIPAM) was created by DIPP in the year 2016 as a professional body under the aegis of DIPP to take forward the implementation of the National IPR Policy.
This conference will mark two years of the National IPR Policy. It will highlight the progress and the way forward.
30 States and Union Territories participate in State Startup Ranking Framework 2018 launched by DIPP
The States Startup Ranking Framework was launched by Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion on 6th February 2018.
DIPP engaged with State and UT Governments over the past weeks to help them prepare and participate in the States Startup Ranking exercise.
There are 30 States and UTs participating in the first ever State Startup Ranking exercise.
The participating States and UTs shall be evaluated on a score of 100, against 38 action points.
The launch of the ranking framework has galvanized the States into action, which has created an impetus for the Startup movement across the country.

Constitution of State Startup nodal team
Provision of financial support to State Incubators
Design of guidelines for Seed Funding for Startups
Launch of State chapters of angel networks
Hosting discussions/workshops to identify Startups in disruptive technologies
Conducting State Startup Yatras - a series of boot camps in colleges/ universities to generate ideas

Index Numbers of Wholesale Price in India (Base: 2011-12=100)
The official Wholesale Price Index for ‘All Commodities’ (Base: 2011-12=100) for the month of April, 2018 rose by 0.7 percent to 116.8 (provisional) from 116.0 (provisional) for the previous month.
The annual rate of inflation was 3.18% for the month of April, 2018 (over April, 2017).
Inflation for important commodities / commodity groups is indicated in Annex-1 and Annex-II.
The movement of the index for the various commodity groups is summarized below:-
The index for this major group rose by 1.4 percent to 129.2 (provisional) from 127.4 (previously) for the previous month.
The food prices rose last month.

The index for ‘Non-Food Articles’ group declined last month due to lower prices of raw silk, floriculture, niger seed, gaur seed, groundnut seed, linseed, cotton seed, castor seed, sardine, gingelly seed, hides, safflower, kardi seed, coir fibre, raw cotton and copra.

The index for ‘Minerals’ group rose by 1.6 percent to 121.6 for the previous month due to higher prices of manganese ore, copper concentrate, limestone, zinc concentrate, lead concentrate and chromite.

The index for ‘Crude Petroleum & Natural Gas’ group rose by 2.4 percent to 82.1 (provisional) from 80.2 (provisional) for the previous month due to higher price of natural gas (4%) and crude petroleum (2%).
The index for this major group rose by 0.9 percent to 98.9 (provisional) from 98.0 for the previous month.
The index for ‘Coal’ group rose by 0.3 percent to 123.0 (provisional) from 122.6 (provisional) for the previous month due to higher price of lignite (8%).
The price of mineral oils rose last month due to higher prices of naphtha and petroleum coke, furnace oil, HSD, kerosene and petrol, but the price of LPG declined.
MANUFACTURED PRODUCTS (Weight 64.23%)
The index for this major group rose by 0.3 percent to 116.1 (provisional) from 115.7 (previously) for the previous month.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Food Products’ group declined last month due to lower prices of molasses, sugar, honey,   honey, agar, coffee powder with chicory, cocoa, chocolate, sugar confectionery, instant coffee and castor oil, sooji, gur, etc.
The price of spirits and beer fell last month, but bottled mineral water went up.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Tobacco Products’ group declined by 4.0 percent to 146.0 (provisional) from 152.1 (provisional) for the previous month due to lower price of other tobacco products (9%) and cigarette (1%).

The index for ‘Manufacture of Textiles’ group rose last month due to higher prices of viscose yarn, weaving & finishing of textiles, cotton yarn and synthetic yarn. However, the prices of cordage, rope, twine & netting, woollen yarn and manufacture of made-up textile articles declined.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Wearing Apparel’ group rose by 1.1 percent to 139.3 (provisional) from 137.8 (provisional) for the previous month due to higher price of manufacture of wearing apparel (woven), except fur apparel (1%).
The index for the manufacturing of leather and related products rose last month due to higher prices.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Wood and of Products of wood and Cork’ group declined last month due to lower prices of plywood block boards and wooden box/crate, but the price of particle boards, wood cutting, processed/sized and wooden block-compressed or not moved up.

The index for manufacturing of paper and paper products declined last month due to lower prices of paper bag, kraft paper, carton/box, base paper, duplex paper and laminated plastic sheet. Newsprint prices went up.
The index for ‘Printing and Reproduction of Recorded Media’ group rose last month due to higher prices of printed books and printed labels/posters/calendars.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Chemicals and Chemical Products’ group rose by 1.0 percent to 116.4 (provisional) from 115.2 for the previous month due to higher prices of sulphuric acid, phthalic anhydride, paint, paint thinner, aromatic chemicals, nitric acid, creams & lotions for external application, poly propylene (pp), camphor, ethylene oxide, carbon black, organic solvent, fungicide, liquid, toilet soap and aniline.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Pharmaceuticals, Medicinal Chemical and Botanical Products’ group declined by 0.5 percent to 120.4 (provisional) from 121.0 for the previous month due to lower prices of antibiotics, preparations and medical accessories.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Rubber and Plastics Products’ group rose by 0.4 percent to 108.2 (provisional) from 107.8 for the previous month due to higher prices of conveyer belt (fibre based), polyester film, V belt, processed rubber, medium & heavy commercial vehicle tyre, condoms, rubber cloth/sheet and tractor tyre.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Other Non-Metallic Mineral Products’ group rose by 1.2 percent to 115.2 for the previous month due to higher prices of graphite rod, porcelain sanitary ware, non ceramic tiles, asbestos corrugated sheet, clinker, slag cement, ceramic tiles (vitrified tiles), plain bricks and glass bottle.
The index for ‘Manufacture of Basic Metals’ group rose by 0.5 percent to 110.1 (provisional) last month.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Fabricated Metal Products, Except Machinery and Equipment’ group declined by 0.4 percent to 111.7 (provisional) from 112.2 for the previous month due to lower prices of stainless steel tank, electrical stamping- laminated or otherwise, steel door and cylinders, jigs & fixture and boilers, etc. However, the prices of metal cutting tools & accessories increased.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Computer, Electronic and Optical Products’ group rose last month due to higher prices of scientific time keeping device, meter, non-electrical meters, telephone sets, capacitors, electronic printed circuit board, PCB/micro circuit and colour TV. However, the prices of electro-diagnostic apparatus, microscope and sunglasses declined.
The index for ‘Manufacture of Electrical Equipment’ group rose by 1.2 percent to 110.8 (provisional) last month.

The index for ‘Manufacture of Machinery and Equipment’ group rose last month due to higher prices of excavator, loader, hydraulic pump, roller mill, pneumatic tools, hydraulic equipment and moulding machine.
The index for ‘Manufacture of Motor Vehicles, Trailers and Semi-Trailers’ group rose by 0.2 percent to 111.2 for the previous month due to higher prices of a number of products.
The index for ‘Manufacture of Other Transport Equipment’ group declined last month, mainly due to lower prices of railway brake gear and motor cycles. The price of bicycles went up.
The price of foam & rubber mattress fell last month, but the prices of hospital furniture and steel shutter gate went up.

The index for ‘ Other Manufacturing’ group rose by 1.2 percent to 105.3 (provisional) from 104.1 for the previous month due to higher prices of table tennis table, cricket ball and non mechanical toys.

The rate of inflation based on WPI Food Index consisting of ‘Food Articles’ from Primary Articles group and ‘Food Product’ from Manufactured Products group increased from (-) 0.07% in March, 2018 to 0.67% in April, 2018.
FINAL INDEX FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 2018 (BASE YEAR: 2011-12=100)

For the month of February, 2018, the final Wholesale Price Index for ‘All Commodities’ (Base: 2011-12=100) stood at 116.1 as compared to 115.8 (provisional) and annual rate of inflation based on final index stood at 2.74 percent as compared to 2.48 percent (provisional) respectively as reported on 14.03.2018.
Next date of press release: 14/06/2018 for the month of May, 2018

Creation of Directorate General of Trade Remedies (DGTR) in Department of Commerce.
The government of India has created a new National Authority for trade protection.
The government of India plans to reorganise the trade defence mechanism in India.
The DGTR will function as an attached office of Department of Commerce.
The DGTR will be a professionally integrated organisation with officers drawn from different services and specialisations.
The proposal of creation of DGTR, which was pending since 1997, has been approved by the Prime Minister.
CIM addresses First Inter-Ministerial meeting on Sectoral Export Promotion Strategy
The minister of commerce and industry and civil aviation, Suresh Prabhu, addressed a meeting on Sectoral Export Promotion Strategy.
Commerce Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has said that promoting exports is a combined and joint mission of all ministries and departments of the Government.

The Union Cabinet has approved a grant of Rs. 5000 crores to promote export of services in champion sectors. The Department of Commerce organises the next Global Exhibition on export of Services at Mumbai on 15th May 2018.

The Department of Commerce (DoC) has engaged with 150 countries in the last few months. A task force on SEZs has been set up to ensure that export potential from these zones is fully exploited. The respective Ministries and Departments can organize road-shows and exhibitions for their sectors and products.
The Minister advised the EXIM bank and NABARD to prepare action plans to ease the financial difficulties of exporters.
The meeting was held to discuss ways to boost exports.
The government needs to focus more on exports to China, Latin America and Africa to increase its share in global trade.
The Department of Commerce has great expectations from today's meeting.
Goverment Committed to get Access to Indian Pharma in Key Markets: Suresh Prabhu
Commerce & Industry and Civil Aviation Minister, Suresh Prabhu speaking at the inauguration of iPHEX, International Exhibition of Pharma and Healthcare
The 6th annual International Exhibition of Pharma and Healthcare (iPHEX) is being held in New Delhi. It is attended by 650 delegates from 130 countries, including scores of regulators.

Shri Prabhu, the Minister of State for Pharmaceuticals, has given an overview of the Indian pharmaceutical industry. He stressed on the need for both competitive and complementary strategies to boost the pharmaceutical sector.
The Commerce Secretary Rita Teaotia said that effort is on to ensure uniform quality in the pharmaceutical sector.
The validity of GMP (Good Manufacturing Practices) certificate is to be extended from 2 to 3 years. The protocol for clinical trials approval has been changed to 45 days.
The chairman of the Pharmaceuticals Export Promotion Council of India (PHARMEXCIL) expressed confidence that the global business will be retained in India.
PHARMEXCIL Vice Chairman Mr Dinesh Dua said besides generics, India will soon emerge as a force to reckon with in the area of innovative drugs.
DGFT has to Evolve from a Regulator to Facilitator – Suresh Prabhu
Union Minister of Commerce & Industry and Civil Aviation, Shri Suresh Prabhu, speaking at the Port Officers’ Meeting in New Delhi.
The Union Minister of Commerce and Industry, Shri Suresh Prabhu, addressed the regional port officers from different parts of the country.
The Indian Minister for Regional Offices has asked DGFT to set up a committee headed by the chief secretary of states to promote exports.
The Minister of Trade and Industry has asked DGFT to identify districts with potential to export products and reward those who achieve their targets.
Regional authorities of DGFT will conduct outreach programmes with exporters.
India- South Africa Business Summit Concludes in Johannesburg
Union Minister of Commerce and Industry and Civil Aviation, Suresh Prabhu, speaking at the India- South Africa Business Summit
Suresh Prabhu is on a two-day business summit in Johannesburg, South Africa. He met Dr. Rob Davies, Minister of Trade and Industry of South Africa, and ministers from Swaziland, Botswana and Lesotho.
The Minister highlighted the historical relations between India and these countries and pledged to take the economic partnership forward.

The Minister also met members of India-South Africa CEOs forum who expressed confidence in the Government of India’s efforts to strengthen India-Africa relations and pledged their support in furthering these relations

Suresh Prabhu also met ministers from Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) and participated in the India-SADC Dialogue attended by ministers and business leaders who pledged their effort for achieving prosperity through trade, investment and economic cooperation
The Indian and South African Prime Minister attended the business summit.
Suresh Prabhu, the Indian Minister of Commerce and Industry, has inaugurated a multi-sectoral exhibition at Johannesburg.
The Indian and South African governments will work on a time bound action plan to benefit from the summit for business between India and South Africa.
The Minister of State visited the Tata Motors assembly plant in South Africa.

At the end of the tour the Minister met the Indian diaspora and said that they are a bridge between the two countries for more than 150 years and the diaspora is a great hope for the future of economic and commercial cooperation.
Cabinet approves Cadre review and formation of Group ‘A’ service of the technical cadre of Petroleum & Safety Organization (PESO) in thename of Indian Petroleum & Explosives Safety Service (IPESS)

The Union Cabinet chaired by chaired by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi has approved the Cadre review and formation of Group ‘A’ service of the technical cadre of Petroleum & Safety Organization (PESO) in the name of Indian Petroleum & Explosives Safety Service (IPESS).
The organization will introduce a new initiative aimed at enhancing the capacity and efficiency of the organization and enhancing career progression of its Group ‘A’ officers.
PESO is a nodal agency for regulating safety of substances such as explosives, compressed gases and petroleum.

The present sanctioned strength of Technical Group ‘A’ cadre of PESO is 137 having 60 Junior Time Scale (JTS) level officers, 46 Senior Time Scale (STS) level officers, 23 Junior Administrative Grade (JAG) level officers (Level 12), 7 JAG level officers (Level 13) and 1 Senior Administrative Grade (SAG) level post of Chief Controller of Explosives.

There is a shortage of posts at Level-13 and Level-12 in PESO. To address this situation, it has been decided to form Group ‘A’ Service of the technical cadre of PESo in the name of IPESS and restructure the service by increasing 5 posts and reducing 8 posts.
Index of Eight Core Industries (Base: 2011-12=100) March, 2018
The summary of the Index of Eight Core Industries (base: 2011-12) is given at the Annexure.

The Eight Core Industries constitute 40.27% of the weight of items included in the Index of Industrial Production (IIP). The combined Index of Eight Core industries stood at 138.0 in March 2018, which was 4.1% higher than in March 2017.
Coal production (weight: 10.33 per cent) increased by 9.1 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
Crude Oil production (weight: 8.98 per cent) declined by 1.6 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
The Natural Gas production increased by 1.3 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017. The cumulative index increased by 2.9 per cent from April to March 2018.
Petroleum Refinery production increased by 1.0 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
Fertilizers production (weight: 2.63 per cent) increased by 3.2 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
Steel production increased by 4.7 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
Cement production increased by 13.0 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
Electricity generation (weight: 19.85 per cent) increased by 4.5 per cent in March, 2018 over March, 2017.
The data for January, 2018, February, 2018 and March, 2018 are provisional.
Note 2: Since April, 2014, Electricity generation data from Renewable sources are also included.
Note 3: The industry-wise weights indicated above are individual industry weight derived from IIP and blown up on pro rata basis to a combined weight of ICI equal to 100.
Note 4: Release of the index for April, 2018 will be on Thursday, 31st May, 2018.

NDCP 2018: Public can give comments till 1st June
The deadline for submission of comments on the draft National Digital Communications Policy has been extended.
The deadline for giving input on draft Policy is extended to 25th May 2018.
The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) has released the draft of the National Digital Communications Policy (NDCP).
Cabinet approves provision of mobile connectivity in Left Wing Extremism Areas

The Union Cabinet has approved the scheme to provide mobile services at 4072 tower locations identified by MHA in inhabited uncovered areas affected by left wing extremism. The total project cost is Rs.7.330 Crore.
The project aims to provide a mobile network for security personnel deployed in LWE affected areas and for the e-Governance activities in the backward and LWE areas.
The numbers of Tower locations proposed in the 10 States are as follows:
The LWE phase-l project for providing the mobile services using 2G technology in LWE Areas with a total sanctioned cost of Rs, 4080.78 Cr is on completion.
There are 2335 sites radiating out of total 2355 as on date.
MHA has provided DoT with 4072 tower locations for the communication need of security personnels deployed in 96 districts of 10 states.

Technology proposed in the Phase-ll project has been upgraded according to the requirement of Stakeholders. Now 2G and 4G technology is being deployed in this project for providing the mobile connectivity.
Cabinet approves USOF scheme for provision of mobile services in Meghalaya under CTDP for North Eastern Region

The Union Cabinet has approved Implementation of a Comprehensive Telecom Development Plan (CTDP) for the North Eastern Region (NER) in Meghalaya at a total estimated project cost of Rs. 3911.81 crore.
Provision of 2G+4G mobile coverage in identified uncovered areas of the State of Meghalaya; and
Provision of 2G+4G seamless mobile coverage along the National Highways in Meghalaya.

Strengthening of telecom network will result in increase the penetration of mobile connectivity in Meghalaya resulting in affordable and equitable access of communication, information and governance to people.
Providing access to public mobile network to hitherto unreached people of Meghalaya will empower citizens with benefits of ICTs for furthering socio-economic developments.
The innovative skill of uncovered areas will increase through broadband and internet access.
Cabinet approves enhancement of budget for implementation of Network for Spectrum for Defence Services

The Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs, chaired by the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi has given its approval for enhancement of budget by Rs.11,330 crore for Network For Spectrum (NFS) project for laying of alternate communication network for Defence Services for release of spectrum over and above Rs.13,334 crore already approved by Cabinet Committee on Infrastructure in July, 2012.
The project, being implemented by Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL), will be completed in a period of 24 months.
The NFS project will boost the communication capabilities of the Defence Forces and enhance national operational preparedness.
The field officers should focus on better customer service and try to change the negative customer perception about BSNL: Sh Manoj Sinha
The field officers of BSNL should focus on better customer service to change the negative customer perception about the company.
BSNL has many opportunities beyond mobile telephony. Market share of BSNL has been improved from 7.6% to 9.43%. Works worth Rs 150 Crore have been allotted to BSLN under smart city projects.
BSNL is a key partner in BharatNet implementation.
The government re-named the National Telecom Policy as National Digital Communication Policy (NDCP) 2018 with the aim of providing broadband for all by 2022.
BSNL is going to install 5 million wifi hotspots by 2020 and 10 million by 2022. 50% of households in India will have FTTH, Ms Sundararajan said.
BSNL has a tough competition in the telecom sector. BSNL has managed to increase its market share and remain MNP positive.
The Conference was attended by the Board of Directors and Heads of BSNL Telecom Circles.

Telecom Commission has approved TRAI’s Recommendation on In-flight Connectivity. Airlines and the TSPs can offer voice and data services in India Airspace once an aircraft reaches an altitude of 3000 metres. It will take 3 to 4 months to operationalise the service.

In line with earlier decision of Committee of Secretaries, In-Flight voice and data services shall be provided through Indian Satellites or through satellites approved by Department of Space for communication purposes, with gateways in India.

A separate category of licensee called In-Flight Connectivity Provider shall be created with a token license fee of Re. 1. Such facilityof voice and data connectivity shall also be extended to ships and other moving vehicles.
Foodgrain at subsidized prices being allocated to ensure adequate standards of nutrition in Welfare Institutions and SC/ST/OBC Hostels: Shri Ram Vilas Paswan
Shri Ram Vilas Paswan chairs meeting of Food Secretaries of State/UTs to discuss execution of Welfare Institutionsand Hostels Schemes
Foodgrain at subsidised prices is being allocated for welfare and development of weaker sections of society.

Shri Paswan stated that Government of India has revamped its scheme for additional allocation of foodgrain to ensure adequate standards of nutrition in such institutions with a view to meet the requirement of Welfare Institutions such as Beggar Homes, Nari-niketans and other similar welfare institutions sponsored by State Governments/UT Administrations, that are not covered under Targeted Public Distribution System or under any other Welfare Scheme; and also for residents of SC/ST/OBC Hostels.
All hostels with at least 2/3rd of resident students belonging to SC/ST/OBC community are eligible to get subsidised foodgrain.
The Food Minister has announced that the scale of issue of wheat and rice to the local authorities is as per the nutrition requirement of the residents.
The details of the scheme are available at this Department’s website (http://dfpd.nic.in/1sGbO2W68mUlunCgKmpnLF5WHm/newpolicy-070917.pdf)
Government of India makes systematic progress towards cash transfers of food subsidy
Shri Ram Vilas Paswan launches handbook to guide states in implementation of cash transfers of food subsidy
The handbook for implementation of cash transfer of food subsidies has been launched by the minister Ram Vilas Paswan.
The launch of a handbook on cash transfers of food subsidy scheme was held in India.
Ram Vilas Paswan, the Union Minister, has complemented the efforts of DoFPD and WFP in preparing a handbook on cash transfers for food subsidy.
Shri Paswan highlighted the reform measures implemented by his government to check leakages and diversions of foodgrains in the in-kind distribution of food grains.
WFP supports the government of India in its efforts towards food security and SDG 2 goals.

Currently, Cash Transfer of Food Subsidy is being implemented in union territories of Chandigarh, Puducherry and urban areas of Dadra & Nagar Haveli while some more states have shown interest in implementation.
Central Government issues orders for extending assistance to clear the dues of sugarcane farmers
Sugarcane farmers' dues have reached to over Rs.20,000 crores due to low domestic sugar prices.
The government has taken the following steps in the past three months to stabilise sugar prices:.
(a)  Increased customs duty on import of sugar from 50% to 100%.
(b)  Imposed reverse stock holding limits on producers of sugar for the months of February and March, 2018 to stabilise sugar price.
(c)  Government has also fully withdrawn the customs duty on export of sugar to encourage sugar industry to start exploring possibility of export of sugar.

(d)  In view of the inventory levels with the sugar industry and to facilitate achievement of financial liquidity, mill-wise Minimum Indicative Export Quotas (MIEQ) totalling 20 Lakh MT have been fixed for sugar season 2017-18.
(e)  Further, to facilitate and incentivize export of surplus sugar by sugar mills, Government has allowed Duty Free Import Authorization (DFIA) Scheme in respect of sugar.
The Central Government notified a production subsidy scheme to offset the cost of cane to clear the dues of sugarcane farmers.
The government has decided to provide financial assistance of Rs.5.50 per quintal of cane crushed in sugar season 2017-18 to sugar mills to offset the cost of cane.
Mills which meet the following conditions will be eligible for the assistance of Rs.5.50/qtl of cane crushed.

(a) Mills having ethanol production capacity and who have signed contracts with Oil Marketing Companies (OMCs) for supply of ethanol, should have supplied at least 80% of indented quantity of ethanol under Ethanol Blended with Petrol Programme (EBP) to OMCs during 2017-18 ethanol season (December, 2017 – November, 2018).

(b) The mill should have filed updated online return in Proforma-II relating to data on crushing of cane, production of sugar, sale of sugar and by-products, etc as prescribed by Government under the provisions of Sugar (Control) Order, 1966.
(c) The mill should have fully complied with all the orders/directives of Department of Food and Public Distribution (DFPD) to the sugar mills during 2017-18 sugar season.

The assistance of Rs.5.50/qtl of cane crushed will be provided on the basis of actual cane crushed or inter seallocation of earlier estimated 2800 LMT of cane to be crushed during 2017-18 sugar season.
The government will provide financial assistance of about Rs. 1540 crore to sugar mills to settle their cane price dues of farmers.
Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad delivers Key note address at CxO Forum on "Standardizing the Digital Space" organized by BIS
Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) organises a CxO Forum on "Standardizing the Digital Space" on 8 May, 2018 in New Delhi. The forum was attended by a number of dignitaries, luminaries and experts.
The key note address was delivered by the Union Minister of Law & Justice, Electronics & Information Technology.

Shri Prasad further added that Standards should be formulated in a manner that it lays down the compliance criteria, facilitates smooth and cost effective operation thereby enabling of digital inclusion.
BIS is involved in international standardisation work.
Shri Amitabh Kant, CEO of the NITI Aayog opined that digital standardization needs constant evolution andensures they do not stagnate.

The BIS is hosting a conference on "Standardizing the Digital Space" aimed at bringing together technocrats and tech-entrepreneurs from the country and global experts to discuss the key issues and challenges that need to be overcome in the journey of Digital transformation.

The event was organised to highlight the role of standardisation and invite participation in Standards Formulation for IT Sector. It is in line with the 33rd plenary and working group meetings of JTC 1/SC 7 being hosted by BIS from 6 to 11 May 2018.
Cabinet approves financial assistance to sugar mills for clearing cane dues of farmers
Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs has approved financial assistance of Rs. 5.50 per quintal of cane crushed in sugar season 2017-18 to sugar mills to offset the cost of cane.
The assistance shall be paid directly to the farmers on behalf of the mills.
The cane price payable to farmers will be adjusted against the cane price.
The mill’s account will be credited.
Assistance shall be provided to those mills which will fulfil the eligibility conditions as decided by the Government.
Sugarcane farmers have accumulated cane price dues of more than Rs.19,000 crore due to low sugar prices.

In order to stabilize sugar prices at reasonable level and to improve liquidity position of mills thereby enabling them to clear cane price dues of farmers, Government has taken following steps in past three months:
Increased customs duty on import of sugar from 50% to 100% in the interest of farmers.
Imposed reverse stock holding limits on producers of sugar for the months of February and March, 2018.
The government has fully withdrawn the customs duty on export of sugar.
The minimum minimum export quota for sugar is 20 Lakh tonnes of raw, plantation white and refined sugar for 2017-18 season.
Further, to facilitate and incentivize export of surplus sugar by sugar mills, Government has allowed Duty Free Import Authorization (DFIA) Scheme in respect of sugar.
The 2nd annual conference of the Institute of Insolvency Professionals (IPs) was held in Mumbai.

The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India (IBBI) in association with the three Insolvent Agencies, namely, the Indian Institute of Insolitry Professionals of ICAI, the ICSI Institute of Inolvencian Professionals, and the Insolvncy Professional Agency of Institute of Cost Accountants of India, organised a Conclave of Ins insolvency professionals yesterday in Mumbai.

Dr. M.S. Sahoo, Chairperson, IBBI, in his address on “Building the Institution of Insolvency Professionals” urged the profession of insolvency lawyers to collectively build and preserve the reputation of the institution.

The National Company Law Tribunal President, M. M. Kumar, in his address on "Duties of Resolution Professional under the Code & Best Practices", highlighted the paradigm shift in law that segregates commercial aspects of insolvency resolution from judicial aspects.

Mr. Rashesh Shah, President, FICCI and Chairman, Edelweiss Group, in his address on ‘Insolvency Professional as Key Facilitator for Value Creation’ dwelt on the insolvency reforms in developed nations and in India.
Mr. B.V. Kumar, Hon’ble Judicial Member, NCLT; Mr. M.K. Shravat and Dr. Navrang Saini are present at the Conclave.
The Conclave ended with the vote of thanks.
Cabinet approves Mutual Recognition Agreement between theInstitute of Chartered Accountants of India andthe South African Institute of Chartered Accountants

The Union Cabinet chaired by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi has has approved the Mutual Recognition Agreement between the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) and The South African Institute of Chartered Accountants (SAICA).

Approval of the Cabinet has been granted in respect of Mutual Recognition Agreement (MRA) between ICAI and SAICA to establish a mutual co-operation framework for the advancement of accounting knowledge, professional and intellectual development, advancing the interests of their respective members and positively contributing to the development of the accounting profession in South Africa and India.
Indian Accountancy Professionals with local qualification will be recognised in South Africa.
foster strong working relations between the two accounting institutes.
increase mobility of professionals at either end and would herald a new dimension for small and medium businesses in both countries.
The ICAI's strategic relationship with SAICA is strategic in nature and of mutual benefit.
The Chartered Accountants' Institute of India (ICAI) regulates the profession of Chartered accountants in India. SAICA is the foremost accountancy body in South Africa.
Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India invites comments from public on the Regulations notified under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016.

The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 is a modern economic legislation. Section 240 of the Code empowers the Insolventry Board of India (IBBI) to make Regulations subject to the conditions that they carry out the provisions of Code and are consistent with them.
The IBBI makes regulations. The process starts with a working group making draft regulations and ends with the Governing Board of the IBBI finalising regulations.
Regulators consult with the public on their regulations.
The IBBI has been following the usual regulatory procedure.
Regulators should take a more active role in making regulations.

The IBBI invites comments from public on Regulations already notified under the Code. The comments received between 30th April, 2018 and 31st December, 2018 shall be processed together and the regulations will be amended. The IBBI will notify modified Regulations by 31st March, 2019 and bring them into force on 1st April, 2019.
It is clarified that this is in addition to the extant approach of inviting public comments on Draft Regulations before notifying them.
For providing comments, please follow the process as under:
I.Visit IBBI website,www.ibbi.gov.in;
II.Select ‘Public Comments’;
III.Provide your Name, and Email ID;
IV.Select the stakeholder category, namely,-
V.Select the regulations, you wish to make a comment upon, from the dropdown menu, as under:
a)IBBI (Model Bye-Laws and Governing Board of Insolvency Professional
b)IBBI (Insolvency Professional Agencies) Regulations, 2016;
c)IBBI(Insolvency Professionals)Regulations,2016;
d)IBBI(Insolvency Resolution Process forCorporate Persons)Regulations, 2016;
e)IBBI(Liquidation Process)Regulations, 2016;
f)IBBI(Information Utilities)Regulations, 2017;
g)IBBI (Fast Track Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process) Regulations, 2017;
h)IBBI (Inspections and Investigations) Regulations, 2017;
i)IBBI(Voluntary Liquidation Process)Regulations, 2017;or
j)IBBI (Grievance and Complaint Handling Procedure) Regulations, 2017.
Kindly note that the selected regulations can be found by clicking the pdf icon right next to the ‘select regulations’ option.
VI.Select the kind of comments you wish to make, namely,
VII.If you have selected ‘General Comments’, please select one of the following options:
a)Inconsistency, if any, between the provisions within the regulations (intra-regulations);
b)Inconsistency, if any, between the provisions in different regulations (inter-regulations);
c)Inconsistency, if any, between the provisions in the regulations with those in the rules;
d)Inconsistency, if any, between the provisions in the regulations with those in the Code;
e)Inconsistency, if any, between the provisions in the regulations with those in any other law;
f)Any difficulty in implementation of any of the provisions in the regulations;
g)Any provision that should have been provided in the regulations, but has not been provided; or
h)Any provision that has been provided in the regulations, but should not have been provided.
And then write comments under the selected option.
VIII.If you have selected ‘Specific Comments’, please select regulation number and then sub regulation number, and write comments under the selected regulation / sub-regulation number.
You can make comments on more than one regulation or sub regulation number by repeating the process outlined above from point 8(V) onwards.
X.

If you are a creditor to a corporate debtor and wish to make a specific comment on the sub-regulation(1)(a) of regulation 6 relating to Eligibility for appointment of Liquidator, you need to follow the steps below.
i.Visit IBBI website,www.ibbi.gov.in;
iv.Select the stakeholder category, which in this case is “Creditor to a Corporate Debtor”
v.Select the regulations, which in this case is “Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India (Voluntary Liquidation Process) Regulations, 2017;
vii.Select the regulation / sub-regulation number, which in this case is “Regulation 6” and “Sub Regulation (1)(a)”;
viii.Write comment in the box “Comments”;
ix.If you wish to make comment on another regulations, or another regulation number of the same regulations, repeat the process from ‘V.’ onwards by clicking the icon ‘More Comments’;
x.Click ‘Submit’, after you have made all comments.
9th edition of ‘Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav’ under the Ministry of Culture, inaugurated in Tehri , Uttarakhand
Gala inaugural event showcases an amalgamation of Crafts & Art Forms, Cuisine Fest and Magnificent Cultural Performances

Continuing its endeavour to promote India’s rich cultural Heritage, Ministry of Culture has organised 3 day long diversified cultural festival ‘Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav’ festival which was inaugurated today by Chief Minister of Uttarakhand, Shri Trivendra Singh Rawat, at Koti Colony, Near Tehri Lake, Uttrakhand,
The North Zone Cultural Centre (NZCC) in Patiala has been entrusted with the responsibility as the nodal agency to carry forward the execution of the National Cultural Festival.
RashtriyaSanskriti Mahotsav is strengthening the spirit of Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat.
The inaugural day of the new state was marked with cultural parade and classical singing.
The inauguration ceremony of the festival was held. There were folk dance performances from Karnataka, Haryana, Gujarat, Rajasthan and Jagar Samrat Preetam Bhartwan.
Other eminent guests present were Satpal Maharaj, Tourism Minister, Uttarakhand, Mala Rajya Laxmi Shah, Member of Parliament, Tehri Garhwal and Dhan Singh Negi, MLA, Tehri.

Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav was conceived by the Ministry of Culture in the year 2015, when the Ministry decided to organize it with an intent to showcase the rich cultural heritage of the Country in all its rich and varied dimensions, viz Handicrafts, Cuisine, Painting, Sculpture, Photography, Documentation and Performing Arts-Folk, Tribal, Classical and Contemporary- all in one place.
The Ministry of Culture organises regional cultural symposiums (RSAs) in several Indian state capitals.
The festival of cultural festival of Uttarakhand will continue till 27th May, 2018.
Ministry of Culture to organize Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav 2018 in Tehri, Uttarakhand from 25th to 27th May, 2018
Uttarakhand Government’s Tehri Lake Festival to be a part of the RSM
Ministry of Culture is organising the 9th edition of the Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav in Tehri, Uttarakhand. Tehre Lake Festival will be subsumed within the event.

Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav is taking place in Uttarakhand. It aims to present rich diversity and uniqueness of Indian culture and to promote inter-linkages between the states to strengthen National integration.

The paired state for Uttarakhand under the Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat matrix is Karnataka, and while troupes from all over the country will be performing, special emphasis is being given to Karnataka.
The Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav will be held in the city of Varanasi. It will be a festival of Indian Culture.
Classical Singer Performance by Rashi Pant & Chirank Pant
· Nritya Natika on Veer Bhad Madho Singh Bhandari
· Dance Drama ‘based on Shiva’ by Padma Bhushan Saroja Vaidyanathan and her group
· Sound & Light Show – The Tehri Show at Lake Venue
Vani Raj Mohan performed Bharat Natyam.
· Fusion: Fashion show by Ministry of Textile
· Performance of Kajri Dadra by Padma Shri Malini Awasthi
The North Zone Cultural Centre (NZCC), Patiala has been entrusted with the responsibility as the nodal agency to carry forward the execution of the National Cultural Festival.
The detail program schedule of the Mahotsav is as follows:
CLASSICAL SINGER PERFORMANCE BY RASHI PANT & CHIRANK PANT
NRITYA NATIKA ON VEER BHAD MADHO SINGH BHANDARI
FOLK DANCE PERFORMANCES OF GORWARA KUNITHA (KARNATAKA), PHAG DANCE (HARYANA), SIDHI DHAMAL (GUJARAT), CHAKRI (RAJASTHAN) BY NZCC
DANCE DRAMA 'BASED ON SHIVA' BY PADMA BHUSHAN SAROJA VAIDYANATHAN AND HER GROUP
PERFORMANCE BY JAGAR SAMRAT PREETAM BHARTWAN (ON MAIN STAGE)
WATER SCREEN: THE TEHRI SHOW (SOUND & LIGHT SHOW, LAKE VENUE)
CULTURAL PERFORMANCE BY LOCAL TEHRI FOLK ARTISTS
FOLK DANCE PERFORMANCES OF BEESU KAMSALE (KARNATAKA), KALBELIA DANCE (RAJASTHAN) ROUFF DANCE (J&K) BY NZCC
SOLO PERFORMANCE of BHARAT NATYAM BY MS. VANI RAJ MOHAN.

MASTERCHEF FINALE JUDGED BY MANJIT GILL

KAJRI, DADRA ETC.

Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav was conceived by the Ministry of Culture in the year 2015.
The Ministry of Culture organises regional cultural symposiums (RSAs) in several Indian state capitals.
The Rashtriya Sanskriti Mahotsav is being held in Uttarakhand.
Major conservation, Up gradation and development works by ASI underway at the Purana Qila complex in New Delhi
CAC section at Purana Qila being upgraded to setup museum gallery of invaluable collection of artefacts for wider Public viewing
The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has taken up several conservation, restoration and up-Gradation works at the Historical Purana Qila in New Delhi.
The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has taken up conservation and upgradation of Central Antiquity Collection Section (CAC) at Purana Qila.
The Purana Qila is about to be illuminated soon. Major development work has also been undertaken for reviving the area around the PuranaQila and other historical monuments.
The work of conservation of excavated remains is also in progress to protect it from direct environmental effects.
Children Theatre Workshop by IGNCA from 21st May to 21st June

The Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts (IGNCA) will organize a children's theatre and personality development workshop from 21st May to 21st June 2018 in partnership with Udaan - the Centre of Theatre Art and Child Development.
This workshop is being held at Mother Divine Public School and Mount Abu Public School of Rohini in North Delhi. Children aged 6-14 years can take part in this workshop.

In the one month workshop children will be trained to increase their thinking and mind power, improve their stage manners including theatre, improvising, etc. and will be provided certificate at the end.
For the workshop, the IGNCA will support ‘Udaan’ which has been organising theatre workshops for the last 25 years in which more than 25000 children have participated.
Dr Mahesh Sharma leads the Indian Delegation to the SCO Cultural Ministers’ Meeting in Sanya, China; India participates in the Cultural Ministers’ Meet for first time as full time member
India attaches special importance to SCO in promoting multilateral, cultural, political, security, economic and people-to-people interaction in the region: Dr Mahesh Sharma.

Minister of State for Culture(I/c), Dr Mahesh Sharma along with other CultureMinisters of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) member states at the 15th Meeting of Cultural Ministers of the SCO in Sanya, China.

The Indian Minister of State for Culture, Dr Mahesh Sharma, led the Indian delegation to the 15th Meeting of the Cultural Ministers of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) in Sanya, Hainan province.
India has a long history of cultural exchanges with China and other SCO member states. Joining the SCO has provided a new platform for exchanges and cooperation.
Cultures are the glue that holds people together. Dr. Mahesh Sharma, India's Minister of Culture, wants to expand cultural exchanges between China and India.

Key discussions of the SCO meeting focused on achieving more in-depth and creative multilateral cultural cooperation and promoting regional cultural cooperation and mutual understanding of the people.

All participants agreed that cultural cooperation between SCO member states made remarkable progress in the past year, and reports presented at the meeting about diversified exchanges and cooperation clearly showed that bilateral and multilateral cooperation is growing deeper and wider.
The SCO member states have approved the 2018-20 Executive Plan.
India became a full member of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) on 9th June, 2017.

India has been participating in Cultural initiatives undertaken by SCO like nominating World Heritage sites for the SCO-UNESCO exhibition proposed to be held in Paris in September, 2018 and signing of MoU between SCO and UNESCO.

The Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) is an eight-member multilateral organization, established on 15 June 2001 in Shanghai, China by the leaders of China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.Pakistan also became the full member of SCO along with India, taking its membership to 8.After the expansion of membership, SCO represents approximately 42% of the world’s population, 20% of its GDP and 22% of the landmass.
The SCO is a regional economic, political, economic and cultural organisation with 27 member states.
Eminent Artist and Sculptor, Shri Uttam Pacharne appointed regular Chairman of Lalit Kala Akademi
Shri Uttam Pacharne has been appointed as the regular chairman of Lalit Kala Akademi.
Shri Pacharne will be sworn in as a minister. He is the recipient of several awards.
Shri M.L. Srivastava was appointed Protem Chairman of the Lalit Kala Akademi.
Dr. Mahesh Sharma will take part in the 15th Meeting of SCO Cultural Ministers at Sanya, China tomorrow.
India to attend the SCO Culture Ministers’ meet for the first time
The Indian minister of culture and environment will attend the first ever SCO Culture Ministers’ Meeting in Sanya tomorrow.
India became a full member of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) on 9th June, 2017.
Ministerial opening of the Exhibition- ‘India & The World – A History in Nine Stories’
“Proud of the rich cultural bondage between India and the UK”: Dr. Mahesh Sharma.

Ministerial Opening of the exhibition ‘India & The World - A History in Nine Stories’ by Hon’ble Minister of State for Culture, Dr. Mahesh Sharma, and Hon. Matt Hancock MP was held today at the National Museum auditorium in New Delhi.

Dr. Alexander Evans, deputy High Commissioner, British High Commission, New Delhi, Mr. Hartwig Fischer, Director, British Museum and B.R.Mani, Director General, National Museum were present at the event.

The Exhibition, ‘India and the World: A History in Nine Stories’ offers insights into two million years of history of India. It was planned as part of commemoration of 70 years of India’s independence and a year of cultural exchange between India and the UK.
India and the UK are bound by cultural bonds.
The Exhibition of India and UK is being held in London.
The Exhibition willrun for two months till June 30 and is available for public viewing on all days from 10 am to 6 pm, except on Mondays and public holidays
Exhibition to commemorate the birth anniversary of Rabindranath Tagore, inaugurated at NGMA, New Delhi
An exhibition celebrating the birth anniversary of Rabindranath Tagore was inaugurated at The National Gallery of Modern Art (NGMA) in New Delhi yesterday.
NGMA has displayed artworks of Rabindranath Tagore.
Post inauguration ceremony witnessed Welcome Song “Ekla Cholo Re” by Children and a musical concert by Hungarian Duo - Mrs. Virág Kiss pianist and Mr. Sándor Dezső cellist.
The exhibition will be on view for public from Friday, 8th May 2018 to 10th
June 2018, from 11 am – 6.30 pm, except on Mondays and National holidays.
Exhibition -‘India and the world: a history in nine stories’, to commemorate 70 years of India’s independence inaugurated at national museum, new Delhi today.
British Museum lends iconic objects to be shown for the first time in India
An exhibition on Indian Civilisation was inaugurated by the President of Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts.

The Exhibition,marks an unprecedented collaboration in museum exhibition, withthe British Museum, London; National Museum, New Delhi; and Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya (CSMVS), Mumbai and is actively supported by the Culture Ministry.
An exhibition on India and the World: A History in Nine Stories is being held in London as part of 70 years of India’s independence.

Shri Raidescribed the exhibition as a “journey through history”, taking Indians to “moments in history that are a matter of pride for us”.“This is also a celebration of cultural exchanges and a moment to remember that our civilization has existed for millions of years and what it has given to the world in terms of culture, science and spirituality,” he added.
The British Museum in London is hosting an exhibition on Indian civilisation.
British Museum is launching a project that brings together objects, cultures, institutions and the public to provide a new perspective on moments in Indian history.
An exhibition of British and Indian artefacts from the British Museum and the CSMVS is being held.
The exhibition on Indian history from two million years ago to the present day is an opportunity to learn and share the regional and global links.

A special feature added to this significant exhibition includes brail tactile feature of some of the displayed objects for those visually challenged visitors. Access for ALL, DAG and Radio Mirchi worked together to create an apparatus to understand the exhibition through multiple senses.
The Exhibition of India and the World will open on June 30.
Dr. Mahesh Sharma will inaugurate an exhibition on Indian Civilisation at National Museum, New Delhi tomorrow.
Over 200 objects from British Museum, London and 20 museums and private collections from India will be on display at the Exhibition

The Minister of State for Culture, Dr. Mahesh Sharma will inaugurate the Exhibition ‘India and the World: A History in Nine Stories’ tomorrow at 5.00 PM at the National Museum auditorium in New Delhi.
An exhibition on India and the World: A History in Nine Stories is being held in London as part of 70 years of India’s independence.
The British Museum, London and 20 museums and private collections from India are lending objects to the Exhibition.
The exhibition 'India and the World' is being held at the CSMVS.

The exhibition is spread over nine sections, each representing a pivotal moment in history: Shared Beginnings (1,700,000 years ago to 2000 BC), First Cities (3000-1000 BC), Empire (600 BC - AD 200), State and Faith (AD 100,  Picturing the Divine), Indian Ocean Traders (AD 200-1650), Court Cultures (AD 1500, 1800), Quest for Freedom (1800-present).

Beginning with the Indus Valley Civilisation and coming down to the present, the artefacts range from stone sculptures, terracotta, coins, tools, inscriptions and manuscripts to textiles, jewellery, Mughal miniatures and contemporary paintings, demonstrating the common threads of human history.
The show highlights the historical connections India has shared with the rest of the world.
The British Museum's exhibition on Indian Art brings together 104 works of art from the Indian subcontinent in dialogue with 124 iconic pieces from the British Museum.
The event is organised by India and the World.
The Exhibition is travelling to the national capital from Mumbai and will run for two months till June 30.
President of India chairs the first meeting of the National Committee for Commemoration of 150th Birth Anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi
The President of India, Shri Ram Nath Kovind, chaired the first meeting of the National Committee for the Commemoration of the 150th Birth Anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi at Rashtrapati Bhavan today.
The President of India will address the Commemoration meeting.
President Kovind paid tribute to Mahatma Gandhi.
The 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi is being celebrated.
The President wants the 150th Birth Anniversary Commemoration to be elevated to a global celebration.
The President then called upon those present to share their ideas and suggestions on how we may commemorate the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi.
The Commemoration of Mahatma Gandhi will be held from October 2, 2018 to October2, 2020.

Since it would not be feasible for the entire National Committee to be convened frequently, the meeting resolved to set up a smaller Executive Committee, headed by the Prime Minister, to take forward the commemoration of the 150th birth anniversary of Gandhiji.
The Prime Minister, Shri Narendra Modi, thanked various members of the Committee for their constructive suggestions and recommendations.
The Prime Minister wants all programmes associated with the celebration of Mahatma Gandhi's birthday to be based on the theme of Karyanjali - or “Gandhi in action”.
The Prime Minister wants the celebrations to take the shape of a mass movement.
The flight test of solid fuel ducted ramjet missile has been successfully carried out from the Launch Center-III in Chandipur, Orissa.
There is a misleading news item in Indian Express about alleged kickbacks to Indian government officials in the contract for spares for AN-32 Aircraft.
