134th NDA Convocation Ceremony Held

The convocation ceremony of 134th National Defence Academy (NDA) was held in Pune today. Chief of Integrated Defence Staff to the Chairman of Chiefs of Staff Committee (CISC) Lt Gen Satish Dua was the chief guest.
There were more than 350 cadets awarded degrees from Jawaharlal Nehru University during the programme.
The convocation of National Defence Academy was held. The Chief Guest was received by Commandant of the Academy, Air Marshal IP Vipin. The convocation address was delivered by Lt Gen Satish Dua.

Academy Cadet Adjutant GK Reddy won the Chief of the Army Staff Trophy presented by General K Sundarji for standing first in Science stream. CSM SS Bisht won the Admiral's Trophy presentedby Admiral Sureesh Mehta for standing second in BSc. Computer Science stream and Cadet PM Kiran won the Air Chief Marshal Suri Trophy for standing third in Social Science.

The Cantonments were once exclusive areas for service personnel and their families. Nowadays, civilians living close to the Cantonment area provide essential services to the military personnel and some of them feel aggrieved as they are denied access to their residential areas.

There are many roads in Cantonments that are open to civilian traffic. Some good public schools and Army Public School also exist in the area. Children from civilian background are studying in these schools and cannot be denied access.
The decision was taken to temporarily close roads in military areas for one month and then review the traffic flow in and out of these areas.
The LMA will soon issue a simplified procedure to control access to the Cantonments.
Joint indo-Bangladesh Army Trekking Expedition to Nanda Devi east base camp flagged off
A trekking expedition to Nanda Devi East Base Camp (4300m) was flagged off by Director General of Military Training on 28 May 18.
Mt Nanda Devi East Base Camp is located at an altitude of 4300M and is one of the challenging trekking routes of Himalayas.

Curtain Raiser: India-Nepal Joint Battalion LevelExercise SURYA KIRAN-XIII
Joint Military Exercise SURYA KIRAN-XIII between India and Nepal will be held at Pithoragarh from 30 May to 12 June 2018.

Exercise SURYA KIRAN with Nepal is the largest military training exercise of India and Nepal. The aim of this exercise is to conduct battalion level joint training with emphasis on counter terrorism operations in mountainous terrain. During the exercise, aspects of disaster management and relief work are also included.
The joint military exercise will enhance the level of defence cooperation which will further strengthen the bilateral relations between the two nations.

Successive test firing of Brahmos Missile to validateCritical Indigenous Components
BrahMos supersonic cruise missile was successfully test fired from the Integrated Test Range (ITR) in Odisha.
BrahMos launched a missile today. Major subsystems manufactured in India were tested.
SA to RM & DG (Missiles & Strategic Systems) Dr G Satheesh Reddy congratulated the Scientists for successfully developing the multiple sections of BrahMos and proving them in the mission.

Chairman DRDO & Secretary Department of Defence R&D Dr S Christopher congratulated Team DRDO and BrahMos on the successive successful flight test and said that a major milestone has been achieved in the indigenisation of BrahMos.
BrahMos is a joint venture between DRDO of India and NPOM of Russia. BrahMos is operationalised in the Indian Army, Indian Navy and Indian Air Force.
BRAHMOS has established itself as a major force multiplier in modern-day complex battlefields with its impeccable land-attack, anti-ship capabilities with multi-role and multi-platform abilities.
DAC Approves Measures to Simplify Defence Procurement Procedure
The Defence Acquisition Council (DAC), chaired by Raksha Mantri Smt Nirmala Sitharaman, met here today.

The Defence Procurement Procedure-16 will be incorporated in DPP-16, the manual governing the defence procurement procedure. The significant changes inter-alia include devolution of powers within the Ministry of Defence and the Service Headquarters, concurrent running of the acquisition process instead of sequential stage clearance, deletion of repetitive processes and aligning of various documents with revised financial guidelines.
These amendments form part of the ongoing Business Process Re-engineering in Defence Capital procurements.
Raksha Mantri Inaugurates Workshop on AI in National Security and Defence
The Raksha Mantri Smt Nirmala Sitharaman inaugurated the workshop on artificial intelligence in national security and defence.
Artificial Intelligence (AI) has shown significant technical advancement in some of the developed countries.
Most of this progress is due to advances in the AI sub-field of Machine Learning (ML).
The world is moving in a positive direction.
The research into artificial intelligence (AI) is being conducted in private and academic institutions.
A Task Force on AI and National Security has been formed by the government.
To establish tactical deterrent in the region.
To support its peaceful and commercial use.
To visualize potential transformative weaponry of future.
To facilitate in keeping a check on non-state actors.
To develop intelligent, autonomous robotic systems.
To enhance capabilities for collection and analysis of data and also creation of data.
The Terms of Reference for the AI Task Force, of Ministry of Defence are as under-
Study use of AI by other leading countries including US, China, Japan, Germany, Russia etc.
Study of level of AI/ML development in India in general and specific in the context of defence needs.
Make recommendations to make India a significant power of artificial intelligence in defence.
Make recommendations for policy and institutional interventions that would regulate and encourage AI based technologies for defence sector in the country.
Considering that most AI work is happening in private sector, make recommendations to work with start-ups/commercial industry in the field of use of AI for defence purposes.
Recommendations for RFIs that need to be floated in next 2 years on dual use AI capabilities.
Make recommendations regarding appropriate strategies of working with startups in US working in this area.
Recommendations for funding required to achieve aforementioned goals.
The AI Task Force of Ministry of Defence has met twice on 10 February and 28 April 2018. It has been decided to organise a Stakeholders’ Workshop on AI in National Security and Machine Learning.
Successful Test Firing of Brahmos to Validate Service Life Extension
BrahMos supersonic cruise missile was successfully test fired at 1040 hours today from the Integrated Test Range (ITR) in Balasore, Odisha.
The precision strike missile flew in its designated trajectory.

BrahMos is a joint venture between DRDO of India and NPOM of Russia, the highly versatile BrahMos has emerged as the ultimate weapon of choice in modern warfare with its unmatched speed, precision and firepower.

Raksha Mantri Smt Nirmala Sitharaman congratulated team DRDO and BrahMos for the successful test firingand said that it would result in huge saving of replacement cost of missiles held in the inventory of Indian Armed Forces.
The BrahMos missile successfully completed its flight test.
INSV Tarini completes historic Circumnavigation

The all-women crew of the sailing vessel Tarini, which completed a round-the-world journey, was received at the jetty by Smt. Nirmala Sitharaman. Admiral Sunil Lanba, Chief of the Naval Staff, Vice Admiral AR Karve, Flag Officer Commanding-in-Chief Southern Naval Command, senior officers and enthusiastic members of the naval community were present at the Naval Boat Pool to welcome INSV Tarini.
The all-women crew of Navika Sagar Parikrama successfully completed the round-the-world voyage.
The all-women crew of the vessel Vartika Joshi has circumnavigated the globe.
Team Tarini from India won the gold medal.

During his address Admiral Sunil Lanba Chief of the Naval Staff said, “The grit and determination displayed by these young women officers would definitely encourage future generations to take on daunting challenges and strive for success”.
The vessel has completed a round-the-world journey.
The crew and the vessel encountered rough seas and stormy weather conditions during the round-the-world journey.
The indigenously-built INSV Tarini is a 56-foot sailing vessel, which was inducted in the Indian Navy in February 2017, and has showcased the ‘Make in India’ initiative on the International forum.
The expedition organised by the National Geographic Society is aimed at promoting the cause of women empowerment.
The crew of the ship monitored weather forecast and ocean and marine pollution. They also engaged with local people during port halts.

A senior naval officer said, “The women officers have done the country proud not only in showing the Indian Flag at distant shores but also in demonstrating the sea faring capability of Indian women.”
The women officers will be proceeding to New Delhi shortly, where they will meet the Hon’ble Prime Minister.

E-Pension Payment Order: New Step in the Right Direction
The e-payment of pension orders has been extended to all defence pensioners including defence civilians.

Principal Controller of Defence Accounts (Pensions), Allahabad is the sole agency under Ministry of Defence which sanctions Pensions for the Defence Services viz., Army, Coast Guard, Defence Research and Development Organization,General Reserve Engineer Force, Border Roads Organization, Military Engineering Services and other Defence organisations including Defence Account Department and Defence Civilians.
The shift from manual system to e-PPO system is expected to reduce delays in pension disbursement and further revision as and when needed.
The PCDA (P) will digitize pension documents received from 46 record offices and more than 2900 Head of Offices to improve implementation of OROP.
Humanitarian and Disaster Relief Seminar:Head Quarter western Air Command

Head Quarter Western Air Command, Delhi conducted a seminar on Humanitarian and Disaster relief(HADR) on 14 May 18. The Dakota DC-3 VP 905, which was accepted by the CAS from the Hon’ble Member of Parliament (RajyaSabha) on 13 February 2018, was formally inducted into the IAF today evening at Air Force Station Hindan.

The IAF aircraft flew a total of 9750 km during its ferry journey from the UK to India and made stops in France, Italy, Greece, Jordan, Bahrain, Oman, and Oman en-route. It landed on Indian soil at Air Force Station Jamnagar on 25 Apr 18 and reached its final destination at Air force Station Hindan on 26 Apr 18.
The flight of Dakota DC-3 VP 905 across seven countries was a commemoration of the service provided by this aircraft to the nation.

The aircraft was escorted by the Indian Navy, C-130J and Su-30 MKIs on its final leg of the journey from Muscat to Jamnagar. It was received with due ceremony by Air Mshl RK Dhir, AOC-in-C SWAC and MP Shri Rajeev Chandrasekhar. Air Cmde MK Chandrashekhar (Retd) flew on board the aircraft on its way to Air Force Station Hindan.
The Dakota aircraft has returned to the Indian Air Force Station Hindan.

The unique journey undertaken by the Dakota to its homestead, the Vintage Aircraft Flight of the IAF, was keenly followed the world over and its arrival has scripted an indelible mark in the rich legacy of the IAF.

The government has set up a research centre on Brahmaputra flood control at Gauhati University in Assam.

Akshay Kumar launches ad campaign for Swachh Bharat
Akshay Kumar launched an advertisement campaign for the Swachh Bharat Mission in the capital.
Shri Akshay Kumar has been a strong supporter of the sanitation movement underway in the country.
Shri Akshay Kumar spoke about the need for influencers of society to talk freely about toilets and empty toilet pits around the country.
The District Collectors and field officials held an interactive session on the role of women in the sanitation mission in rural areas.
The twin pit toilet technology was invented in India and is the most well-suited toilet technology for rural India.
The toilet in a standard twin-pit toilet model fills up in about 5 years for a 6-membered family.
The waste from the first pit will be collected in the second pit.
The waste in the filled pit decomposes in about 6 months to 1 year.
The decomposed waste from agriculture is rich in nutrients and can be used for fertilizer.

The States are continuously encouraged by the Swachh Bharat Mission (Grameen) to include awareness generation about the above facts as part of their grassroots information, education and communication (IEC) efforts.
The Swachh Bharat Mission has launched a new advertisement campaign aimed at promoting technology.
CAG and Secy MDWS empty toilet pit near Pune for Swachh Bharat
Mission to launch Twin Pit toilet ad campaign with Akshay Kumar, Bhumi Pednekar

The Comptroller and Auditor General of India and the Secretary of Drinking Water and Sanitation emptied a toilet pit from a twin pit toilet in rural Maharashtra. Senior sanitation officers from other states followed suit.
Rural households in India are reluctant to use the twin-pit toilet because of the associated stigma.
The waste from a standard twin-pit toilet fills up in about 5 years. The waste from such a toilet can be easily re-directed to the second pit and composted to form a valuable fertilizer.
Today's pit-cleaning exercise in Pandharewadi gram panchayat, Daund block of Pune district was a step towards dispelling myths, biases and stigmas.
All officers held up the compost in their hands. Commemorative jars full of the compost were taken home by all present at the event.
The pit-emptying exercise was part of an ODF-Sustainability workshop.
The Mission is working on sustaining the ODF status in these areas.

University Grants Commission has approved UGC (Online Courses) Regulations, 2018 as landmark reform in the field of Higher Education.
Higher Educational Institutions can now offer Certificate, Diploma and Degree Programmes in full-fledged online mode in line with their regular programs.

UGC (Online Courses) Regulations, 2018 has been approved by the Grants Commission. Higher Educational Institutions can offer certificate, diploma and degree programme in full-fledged online mode only in disciplines where they have already been offering similar Programmes /Courses at graduation level in regular mode of classroom teaching or in Open and Distance Learning mode. Online Programmes requiring Practical/ Laboratory Courses as a curricular requirement cannot be permitted.

The Higher Educational Institutions will be eligible to offer Online Programmes if they have been in existence for at least five years and are accredited by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC). They should also be in the top-100 in overall category in the National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF) for the last three years. However, the conditions won't apply to existing government Open Universities.
Aadhaar and Passport will be used to authenticate Indian and foreign students for online interactions including teaching-learning and examinations.
The learners’ engagement will be monitored via participation in asynchronous / synchronous discussions, assignment activity and Programme involvement.

Overall Regulations provide enabling provisions for maintaining sanctity of admissions, teaching-learning, examination, authenticity of the learner and mandatory disclosure of Programme-wise information such as duration, start & end dates, fee, number of students, name of students with identifier, results, on HEI website/public domain.
Regulations aimed at increasing GER to 30% will come into effect from the academic session 2018-19.
Ministry of HRD launches ‘SamagraSiksha’ scheme for holistic development of school education
Emphasis on Integrationof two Ts - Teacher and Technology in the new scheme willhelp improve quality of education:Shri Prakash Javadekar
The Union Minister for Human Resource Development,Shri Prakash Javadekarlaunched an integrated Scheme for school education extending support to States from pre-school to senior secondary level.

The Ministry of Human Resources Development (HRD) has completely overhauled the Schemes in School Education to treat schooling as a smooth transition from pre-school, primary, upper primary, secondary and senior secondary level. It focuses on improving quality of education at all levels by integrating the two T’s - Teachers and Technology.

The budget for SSA, RMSA and Teacher Education was earlier Rs. 28,000 crore in 2017-18, but it will be increased to Rs. 34,000 Crores in 2018-19 and toRs. 41,000 Crème in 2019-20. One million schools will get library grant of Rs. 5,000 to 20,000.

Every school in India will get sports equipment under the SamagraShiksha scheme. Kasturba Gandhi BalikaVidyalaya (KGBV) to be expanded from Class 6-8 to Class 6 to 12 with allocation of Rs. 4385.60 crores in 2018-19 and Rs. 4553.10 crores from 2019-20.
The scheme aimed at improving quality of education for children in districts is being launched by the Education Minister.
Shri Javadekar announced a scheme aimed at strengthening the teacher training system.
He announced a scheme aimed at enhancing the use of digital technology in education.
The Minister also announced a competition over myGov to design an apt logo for the scheme which signifies a holistic approach for holistic development of children.

Shri Upendra Kushwaha in his address said that it is a new beginning in the field of education and SamagraShiksha will integrate schemes through a single school education development programme covering grades pre-school to 12th.
Shri Prakash Javadekar unveiled the brochure and website of the Samagra Shiksha Scheme.

The Website provides details about the Scheme for information of the States/UTs, teachers, children, institutions and public at large. It details out the interventions for which financial support is provided under the Scheme. All notifications, correspondences and circulars are uploaded on the website for ready reference of States and UTs. Project Monitoring System measures progress against targets and monitors processes of implementation of the Integrated Scheme.
Shri Anil Swarup, Secretary, Department of School Education and Literacy, Ms. Rina Ray, Special Secretary of the Department of Education, were present on this occasion.

Major steps taken by CBSE to ensure successful conduct of NEET Examination for the benefit of candidates
The CBSE is holding National Eligibility Cum Entrance Test (UGT) for 100% seats of MBBS/BDS in the country.
The Govt. of India has taken an initiative to curb malpractices in the admission of MBBS and BDS.
There has been an increase in the number of candidates who apply for entrance examinations in past 5 years.
The CBSE conducts examinations in a controlled and sanitized environment.
The CBSE framed Dress Code and barred electronic items, communication devices and other such items in the exam centers. Supreme Court of India decided one PIL in favour of the dress code.
Efforts are being made to accommodate more and more candidates for appearing in the examination.
CBSE has taken several measures to conduct the NEET (UG) successfully.
● Pen was provided by CBSE to all the candidates
● More than 4000 observers were deputed across the country at centres to oversee the examination.
● About 700 Board’s officials were deputed in all 136 cities to control the examination at local level.
● It is not out of place to mention here that the entire work of evaluation of Class X &XII was slowed down as all the officials of the CBSE were sent to conduct the NEET (UG) examination.
● For this examination, nearly 56000 rooms were arranged in 2255 centres.
● Nearly 2,00,000 persons were deputed by the schools for the conduct of NEET (UG).
● 153 City Coordinators were appointed in the cities of examination to coordinate with the centres in the city.
● Nearly 15000 police persons were deputed at examination centres with the help of State Police Department.
The CBSE informed nearly 1.33 crore candidates and their parents about the rules and regulations, conduct in examination everyday.
● More than 1,00,000 SMS and 30,000 mails were sent to centres on different issues, so that they can hold the examination successfully.
● A Radio Programme was also organized to make the candidates aware about the last minute preparations and action to be taken by the candidates, so that they are reaching the centre on time.
● A capacity building program through Web Radio was organized for all 2255 centres informing them about the preparations to be made at the centre.
● Nearly 12000 metal detectors were used to frisk candidates.
● Communication Jammers were installed at the centres across the country to ensure that communication devices are not being used.
● The entire examination was videographed by deputing about 3700 videographers.
The question paper for Physics, Chemistry and Biology is administered in 09 regional languages.
The CBSE has fixed schools affiliated to it and other institutions as the centre of learning for candidates.
The news about forced Tamil Nadu children from Udaipur to take an exam was wrong.

In 4 out of 2255 centers in India, during the conduct of examination, when it came to notice that the medium of Question paper was not correct for the candidates, CBSE immediately responded by providing them question paper in the language of their choice.
CBSE organises exams.
The media has unconditionally supported the Board’s initiatives to curb the menace of adoption of unfair means by candidates.
CBSE will continue to strengthen and improve NEET exams.

2nd Stage Long Range Forecast for the 2018 Southwest Monsoon Rainfall
Rainfall over the country as a whole for the 2018 southwest monsoon season (June to September) is most likely to be NORMAL (96% to 104% of long period average (LPA)).
Quantitatively, monsoon season (June to September) rainfall for the country as a whole is likely to be 97% of the LPA with a model error of ±4%.

Region wise, the season rainfall is likely to be 100% of LPA over North-West India, 99% of LPA over Central India, 95% of LPA over South Peninsula and 93% of LPA over North-East India all with a model error of ± 8 %.
The monthly rainfall over the country as whole is likely to be 101% of its LPA during July and 94% of LPA during August both with a model error of ± 9 %.
IMD has prepared the 2nd stage operational long range forecast of the 2018 southwest monsoon season.
Sea Surface Temperature Conditions in the Pacific & Indian Oceans

The moderate La Nina conditions that developed in the equatorial Pacific last year weakened to weak La Nina condition early this year. The MMCFS & other global climate models indicate that conditions over the Pacific are likely to be neutral during most of the monsoon season and turn to weak El Nino after the season.

The MMCFS and other global climate models predict that weak negative IOD conditions are likely to develop during the middle of the monsoon season and last until the early part of the post-monsoon season.
Monsoon Mission Coupled Forecasting System (MMCFS)

The latest experimental forecast based on the MMCFS suggests that the monsoon season rainfall during the 2018 monsoon season (June to September) averaged over the country as a whole is likely to be 102% ± 4% of LPA.
The Operational Second Stage Forecasts for the 2018 Southwest Monsoon Rainfall
Season (June-September) Rainfall over the country as a whole
The season rainfall for the whole country is likely to be 97% of the long period average.
The 5 category probability forecasts for the Season (June to September) rainfall over the country as a whole is given below.
Season (June-September) Rainfall over the Broad Geographical Regions

The season rainfall is likely to be 100% of LPA over North-West India, 99% of LPA over Central India, 95% of LPA over South Peninsula, and 93% of LPA over North-East India all with a model error of ± 8 %.
Monthly (July & August) Rainfall over the country as a whole
The monthly rainfall over the country as a whole is likely to be 101% of its LPA during July and 94% of LPA during August both with a model error of ± 9 %.
Southwest monsoon has set in over Kerala, today, the 29th May 2018

Today, the southwest monsoon has further advanced into remaining parts of southeast Arabian Sea, Comorin – Maldives area, entire Lakshadweep, most parts of Kerala, some parts of Tamil Nadu and some more parts of southwest, central and northeast Bay of Bengal.
Thus the southwest monsoon has set in over Kerala, today, the 29th May 2018, 3 days ahead of its normal date.
The Northern Limit of Monsoon passes through Lat. 120N/ Long 600E, Lat 120N / Long 650E, Kannur, Coimbatore, Kodaikanal, Tuticorin, Lat. 130N/Long 800E, Lit. 180N/L 900E, and Lat. 210N/Lat 930E.
Prevailing meteorological conditions leading to onset of monsoon over Kerala.
Widespread rainfall occurred over Kerala, during the past 3-4 days. Monsoon onset over Kerala has reached 60% from 25th May.
Westerly winds have strengthened in the lower levels and deepened with Westerly/West-southwesterly gusts upto 600 hPa over the south Arabian Sea.
There is persistent convection (cloudiness indicated by Outgoing Long-wave Radiation values <200 Wm-1) from 23 May.
In addition to the above features, the following developments are also noticed:
An east-west shear zone runs roughly along latitude 120N (across south peninsula) at 3.1 km above mean sea level.
A well marked low pressure area lies over southeast and adjoining eastcentral Arabian Sea off north Kerala- Karnataka coasts.
Another low pressure area lies over eastcentral and adjoining northeast Bay of Bengal. It is likely to develop into a depression during next 12 hours.
Further advance during next 48 hours

Conditions are favorable for further advance of Southwest Monsoon into some parts of central Arabian Sea, remaining parts of Kerala, some parts of coastal and south interior Karnataka, some more parts of eastcentral and northeast Bay of Bengal, and some parts of northeastern states during next 48 hours.
Fig 1: Northern Limit of Monsoon 2018 as on 29th May 2018
Fig.2: Parameters for declaring onset of monsoon over Kerala
Forecast of the Onset Date of Southwest Monsoon - 2018 over Kerala
Southwest monsoon sets over Kerala on 1st June.
IMD’s operational forecasts of the date of monsoon onset during the past 13 years were correct except in 2015. Forecast verification for the recent 5 years is given in the table below.
Monsoon is approaching over the Andaman Sea.

The southwest monsoon advances over the Andaman Sea around 20th May with a standard deviation of about one week. It is likely to reach some parts of Andaman sea and southeast Bay of Bengal around 23rd May 2018.
3. Forecast for the 2018 Monsoon Onset over Kerala
The southwest monsoon is expected to set in over Kerala on 29th May 2018 with a model error of ± 4 days.
Deep Depression intensified into a Cyclonic Storm " SAGAR" over Gulf of Aden

A depression formed over Gulf of Aden yesterday. It intensified into a deep depression in the early morning and into a cyclonic storm “Sagar” today. It is located about 400 km east-northeast of Aden (Yemen) and 560 km west-northwest of Socotra Islands.

Gale winds speed reaching 65-75 kmph gusting to 85 kmph is very likely around the system centre covering Gulf of Aden and adjoining areas of westcentral and southwest Arabian Sea during the next 24 hrs and gradual decrease thereafter.
Sea condition will be high around the system centre covering Gulf of Aden and adjoining areas of westcentral and southwest Arabian Sea during the next 24 hrs.
Fishermen are advised not to venture into Gulf of Aden and adjoining areas of westcentral and southwest Arabian Sea during the next 48 hrs.

NIC launches new data centre in Bhubaneswar; to hire 800 people all India in 1 year

Bhubaneswar becomes the fourth National data centre of National Informatics Centre (NIC) after Delhi, Hyderabad and Pune.The new cloud-enabled National Data Centre aims to offer round-the-clock operations with secure hosting for various e-governance applications of Central and State Governments and has ability to support 35,000 virtual servers.
Unveiling the new national data centre in Bhubaneswar, Sh. Ravi Shankar Prasad said that this data centre is of global standards.
NIC launched a new storage and computing facility for Government apps. NIC provides technology support to all governance services and hosts nearly 10,000 websites of the Government.

ShriRavi Shankar Prasad to inaugurate cloud enabled Data Centre at Bhubaneshwar

SIDBI to extend direct funding facility to VLEs in CSCs

CSC SPV and Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) signed an MoU for providing financial support to CSCs across the country here today in the auspicious presence of Minister of Electronics & IT and Law & Justice, Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad.

During the meeting, Hon’ Minister Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad said that, “I am happy that SIDBI has come forward to support CSCs across the country to promote rural entrepreneurship, and with financial support new avenues of opportunities will come up for CSCs.”
CSCs are providing low-cost sanitary napkins to girls and women in rural India.

Standing Committee on Information Technology (2017-18) seeks public views on Data Security & Privacy

The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Information Technology, headed by Shri Anurag Singh Thakur, M.P., Lok Sabha are examining various aspects related to the subject ‘Citizens’ data security and Privacy’.

In view of the immense importance of the subject, the Committee for the purpose of wider consultations invite suggestions from the public in general and experts/professionals/organizations/associations and stakeholders interested in the subject in particular
The Committee on Rules and Decisions (C&IT) requires two copies of opinion/views on the subject to be submitted to it within two weeks from the date of publication/broadcasting of the Press Release.

The memoranda which might be submitted to the Committee would form part of the records of the Committee and would be treated as strictly confidential and the contents thereof would not be divulged to anyone, as such an act would constitute a ‘breach of privilege’ of the Committee.
People who want to give oral evidence before the Committee are asked to inform the Lok Sabha Secretariat well in advance.

The minister inaugurates workshop on tele-centre entrepreneurship.
He appreciated the efforts of the enterprising VLEs in providing key services at the grassroots level and announced introduction of rewards for the best performing entrepreneurs.

There are 2.92 lakh CSCs across the country, which is more than the number of VLEs in 2013-14. The transactions of CSC have increased from one Cr for 180 Cr in 2013 to 17.83 Cr for Rs. 19,000 Cr in 2017-18. VLE have given employment to 10 million people in India.

The Minister also asked to explore the possibility of involvement of CSCs in health insurance scheme and support the citizens in availing this unique initiative of the government.
Sh. Ajay Prakash Sawhney, Secretary, MeitY congratulates VLEs for their tremendous role in CSC movement.
CSCs are playing a central role in the government’s Digital India program. The government is encouraging women to set up CSCs.
VLEs from across India are taking part in CSC SPV workshop.

Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad addresses the Plenary Session on ‘Media Regulation Policies: Ethics, Rules and Laws’, at the 15th Asia Media Summit 2018
Media must empower the common man in an accountable manner: Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad
Freedom of Media is enshrined in the Indian Constitution and reinforced by judiciary, Shri Prasad said.

On misuse of data, the Minister said India will not allow the country to become a centre of data pilferage. He said all the online companies which deal in data must understand the nuances of accountability.
The Law Minister believes that the media must be fair, true, properly presented and empowering the consumers of news.
The Information Technology Minister, Ravi Prasad, has said that content going through intermediaries should not be dangerous, libelous or impinge upon the security and integrity of the country.
The Minister for Electronics and Information Technology, Shri Prasad, has said that the Government respects social media but some of its content can be problematic.
Shri Prasad has said that Internet must be global and must have links with local ideas and culture.
The session on Media Regulation was held at the Press Council of India.

In all the presentations, there was a consensus on a host of issues including ensuring freedom of expression and healthy development of an independent media, respecting individual privacy, combating cyber crimes and terrorism.
“Need to Connect People, Get them on to a Single Platform”:Environment Ministry
Ministry, FICCI Jointly Hold Interactive Session of Stakeholders in the Run-Up to World Enviornment Day 2018
The World Environment Day is an attempt to connect people and get them on to a single platform in the run-up to WorldEnvironment Day 2018 celebrations.
The interactive conversation with stakeholders included senior officers from the Ministry of Environment, Forest & Climate Change and representatives from FICCI.
The Knowledge Sessions will focus on air pollution in Indian cities and local green enterprises.
An exhibition by various institutions/organisations will be put up in the back lawns of Vigyan Bhawan from June 2-5, 2018.
"Beat Plastic Pollution" is the theme of World Environment Day 2018 celebrations.
Dr. Harsh Vardhan asks people to give up single use of plastic and adopt a Green Good deed every day.
Environment Minister addresses a Curtain Raiser in the run-up to World Environment Day 2018 Celebrations
The fight against plastic pollution and other environmental issues can be won only with minor behavioural changes, according to the Union Minister for Environment.

There is 25, 940 tonnes of plastic waste generated every day in the country. 40% of the plastic waste is uncollected and 60 million tonnes of solid waste is generated in one year. It takes plastic bottles up to 1000 years to decompose.
Dr. Harsh Vardhan addresses the Curtain Raiser in the run-up to World Environment Day celebrations. Secretary, Shri C.K Mishra is also seen.

The World Environment Day celebrations will be held from June 1-5, 2018 in New Delhi and across the country. There will be international conversations on topics related to air pollution, Himalayan ecosystem, plastic pollution, marine litter strategy, new plastic economy and waste to resource. The technology exhibition “Sambandh” will take place on the back lawns of lawns India Gate from June 2-4, the conference of state environment ministers - “Green India” on June 4, besides conferences, workshops and seminars on various environmental subjects.
The Indian government organises a series of cleanliness and environmental events.

BACKGROUND OF WORLD ENVIRONMENT DAY:
The 5th June is World Environment Day.
June 5th is World Environment Day.
The theme for World Environment Day is “Seven billion dreams, one planet, consume with care”.
Dr. Harsh Vardhan asks people to give up single use of plastic and adopt a Green Good deed every day.
Environment Minister addresses a Curtain Raiser in the run-up to World Environment Day 2018 Celebrations
The fight against plastic pollution and other environmental issues can be won only with minor behavioural changes, according to the Union Minister for Environment.

There is 25, 940 tonnes of plastic waste generated every day in the country. 40% of the plastic waste is uncollected and 60 million tonnes of solid waste is generated in one year. It takes plastic bottles up to 1000 years to decompose.
Dr. Harsh Vardhan addresses the Curtain Raiser in the run-up to World Environment Day celebrations. Secretary, Shri C.K Mishra is also seen.

The World Environment Day celebrations will be held from June 1-5, 2018 in New Delhi and across the country. There will be international conversations on topics related to air pollution, Himalayan ecosystem, plastic pollution, marine litter strategy, new plastic economy and waste to resource. The technology exhibition “Sambandh” will take place on the back lawns of lawns India Gate from June 2-4, the conference of state environment ministers - “Green India” on June 4, besides conferences, workshops and seminars on various environmental subjects.
The Indian government organises a series of cleanliness and environmental events.

International Day for Biodiversity Celebrated across the Country; National-Level Celebrations held in Hyderabad
The International Day for Biodiversity (IDB) 2018 was celebrated all over the country today. The national-level celebrations were held in Telangana.
The celebration is being held in India to mark the 25th anniversary of conservation of nature.
The Telangana government is promoting the conservation of biodiversity.

In his opening remarks, Additional Secretary, MoEF&CC, Shri Arun Kumar Mehta pointed out that managing the living environment is a much more complex issue than managing the physical environment. India has contributed towards achieving the global Aichi Biodiversity Targets 11 and 16. However, the continuing loss of species may lead to the sixth mass extinction.
The secretary of a government department has called for collective action by MoEFCC and MoA&FW for guarding against genetic erosion.
Conservation of biodiversity is vital for securing our own future.

The UNDP Country Director, Ms. Marina Walter, in her address highlighted that conservation of biodiversity in India will have a global impact and will be central to the achievement of multiple Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
There was a gathering of senior officials from the government and non-governmental organisations.
The International Day of Biodiversity is being celebrated in India.

India Calls for Judicious Use of Resources at 4th Brics Ministerial Meeting in Durban
Dr Harsh Vardhan Reiterates India’s Commitment to Build Responsive, Inclusive and Collective Solutions
India has called for a judicious use of resources.
BRICS countries should work on cooperation in air pollution control and capacity building, Dr. Harsh Vardhan said.
Dr. Harsh Vardhan, the minister of environment, green initiatives, urged the BRICS countries to help in developing a social movement that can be emulated by the rest of the world.
Some of the world's most senior officials were in Johannesburg for the meeting.
Environment Ministry Forms 19 Teams to Undertake Cleaning of Beaches, River Fronts and Lakes in Nine Coastal States
Dr Harsh Vardhan asks School Principals to Take Steps to Become Plastic Free in the Run-Up to World Environment Day
The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has formed 19 teams to take up cleaning of beaches, river fronts and lakes in the country in the build-up to the World Environment Day 2018.
MoEF&CC, the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change and the State Pollution Control Board will form 19 teams and engage them in cleaning exercise along the coastal stretches.
The clean-up activities for the beach, river front and lake will start from May 15 and will end on June 5.
The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change has announced a programme for cleaning the water bodies in every State.
All schools across the country should declare their schools and institutions free from plastic pollution.
No plastic items may be used in schools.
Adopt a water body, pond, wetland, beaches or eco-sensitive area and make them plastic free.
Cleanliness drives to be undertaken on prescribed holidays between April to May.
The Union Minister for MoEF&CC will issue certificates titled ‘Green School/College’ to institutions that declare themselves free from plastic pollution.
The Ministry of Environment organises cleanliness drives and mini-marathon on June 3.
The Environment Ministry has drawn up several programmes and activities for the World Environment Day celebrations.
“Green Skill Development Programme will go a long way in reaping the demographic dividend of the country; GSDP to cover nearly 5 lakh people by 2021”: Dr. Harsh Vardhan.
Environment Minister Launches Mobile App of GSDP
The Green Skill Development Programme aims to get 80,000 people imparted green skills and in filling the skill gaps in the environment sector.
The number of people to be employed under GSDP will be increased to 2.25 lakh people next year and to 5 lakh people by the year 2021, according to the Minister Harsh Vardhan.
There is a shortage of middle-level workforce and 31% of children drop out of school after secondary stage.
The Ministry of Environment, Forest & Climate Change (MoEF&CC) is launching a programme to develop green skilled workers.

The pilot project of GSDP aimed at training Biodiversity Conservationists and Para-taxonomists was launched in June, 2017. ENVIS RPs in Botanical Survey of India (BSI), Zoological Survey of  India (ZSI) and their respective regional offices were the nodal Centres for the pilot programme.
The GSDP is being scaled up to an all-India level. There will be more than 30 skilling programmes being conducted during 2018-19.
MoEF&CC hosted a programme on GSDP.
“Botanic Garden will be Developed as one of the Most Distinct Gardens with Modern-Day Landscape.
Foundation Stone Laid for Development and Upgrading of Botanic Garden, Noida.

The Botanic Garden of Indian Republic (BGIR) Noida will be developed and upgraded with the objectives of collection of plant species, research, training, environment education, public awareness, aesthetics and entertainment.
The first phase of the Botanic Garden project in Delhi-NCR will be completed by 2018.
The project to protect plant biodiversity and natural resources in the country has been started by the Botanical Garden of India Republic.
Uttar Pradesh Minister Shri Dara Singh Chouhan and local MLA, Shri Pankaj Singh were among others present at the foundation-stone laying ceremony.
‘Government has Made Serious Efforts to Deal with Air Pollution’: Environment Ministry
Air Quality Data for 2017 & 2018 Shows Improvement in Air Quality
Delhi is the most polluted city in the world. However, the Government has made efforts to deal with air pollution. BS-IV was upgraded.
The annual average PM 2.5 and PM 10 levels have come down in the year 2017.
Particulate Matter Concentrate in Delhi has improved in the last two years.
The newspaper reports highlight observations by various experts suggesting that action similar to that in Delhi and NCR should be taken in other polluted cities.

The non-attainment cities were asked to prepare detailed action plans for improving air quality. Out of 94 non-targets, 61 of them have already done so. Now the concerned States have been asked to steer implementation of the action plans in these cities.
The state governments of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and West Bengal should take urgent action to clean air in the polluted cities.
The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) has taken several measures to control air pollution in Delhi and the National Capital Region (NCR).
MoEFCC launched National Clean Air Programme (NCAP) in April 2018. It was preceded by Clean Air Program in Delhi in February 2018 to sensitise the public and implementing agencies.
With similar intervention in other polluted cities and active participation of ULBs and state governments, air quality is expected to improve further.

Two Day Thematic Seminar on ‘Water and Sanitation’ in a run-up to 3rd Annual Meeting of Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) begins in Pune ​, Maharashtra​ ; Experts call for a holistic and integrated approach on Water and Sanitation Management.
The seminar on Water and Sanitation in India is being held in Pune, Maharashtra.
The Panel Discussions on water and sanitation sector was held at the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sansthan.

Mr. Parameshwaran Iyer, Secretary, Ministry of Drinking Water and Sanitation in his Lead Presentation discussed how Swachh Bharat Mission has made significant changes in the sanitation sector with pioneering initiatives by various states to tackle the menace of open defecation. He said that the mission is unique with focus on building infrastructure and bringing about behavioral change.

Government of India launched a community-led drinking water project aimed at providing sustainable and adequate drinking water in rural areas. The government will provide technical and financial assistance.
There was a conference on public private partnership (PPP) in the water sector.
In his Opening Remarks, Dr. Amitabh Kundu said that India has 2.4% of the world's habitable land and 4% of water resources but has a huge challenge of feeding 17% of world population.

Dr. Seshadri Chari, Member of Governing Council, RIS, said that the problem of water and sanitation is becoming acute as the development process goes forward. He stressed on the importance of water for all.
FICCI has constituted the water mission to catalyse a dialogue and work with the Government on policy changes.
Roll out of e-Way Bill system for intra-State movement of goods in Chhattisgarh, Goa, Jammu & Kashmir, Mizoram, Odisha, Punjab, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal

GST Council has approved e-Way Bill system for inter-State movement of goods. It has been rolled out in the States of Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Haryana, Himachal, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Rajasthan, Sikkim, Telangana, Tripura, Uttarakhand and Uttar Pradesh. It was rolled out on 30th May 2018 in the Union Territories of Andaman & Nicobar Islands.
It is informed that e-Way Bill system for intra-State movement of goods would be implemented in the following States :-
Chhattisgarh, Goa, Jammu & Kashmir, Mizoram, Odisha & Punjab

The e-Way Bill system for intra-State movement of goods will be implemented by the latest by 03rd June, 2018. It has been two months since the system was implemented and it is working smoothly. Trade and industry should be well versed with the provisions of the e- Way Bill rules.
Government of India and World Bank signs $500 Million Additional Financing for Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana Rural Roads Project
The Government of India and the World Bank signed a $500 million loan agreement to provide additional financing for the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) Rural Roads Project.
The World Bank has supported PMGSY since 2004. It has invested over $1.8 billion in loans and credits for rural roads in North India.
The loan agreement for the Project was signed by the Joint Secretary of the Department of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Finance and Junaid Ahmad, Country Director, World Bank India.

The PMGSY has brought about a paradigm shift in the way rural roads are mapped, designed, monitored and built involving communities especially women. The additional finance will bring a new shift in construction technology.
There are concerns about the condition of the road network in Pakistan.
The World Bank is funding a project in India aimed at building climate resilient roads.
The PMGSY and the Bank will focus on managing the rural road network through green and climate-resilient construction.

Climate vulnerability assessment during the design process to identify the critical locations affected by floods, water-logging, submergence, cloud bursts, storms, landslides, poor drainage, excessive erosion, high rainfall and high temperatures.
Special treatment for flood-affected areas through adequate waterways and submersible roads to allow easy passage of water, use of concrete block pavements, and improved drainage;

Use of environmentally optimized road designs and new technologies which uses local and marginal materials and industrial by-products such as sand, local soils, fly ash, brick kiln wastes, and other similar materials in place of crushed rocks;

Innovative bridges and culverts through use of pre-fabricated/pre-cast units for roads and bridges having better ability to withstand earthquakes and water forces such as continuous beams, bearing free construction, and river training works;
Use of hill cutting material in roads, improved drainage and other improvements for landslide prone areas.
The Additional Financing will extend the community-based maintenance contract for 500 km of PMGSY roads over 5 states.
The World Bank is funding a project aimed at improving road conditions in India and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
A $500 million loan from the IBRD has been approved.
The Finance Commission will be able to devolve more powers according to the new law.

To sustain a rate of growth to deal with enormous expenditure outlays that Kerala is required to make.
To manage its high debt to GDP ratio as per the FRBM Act of the State
Capital expenditure needs to be enhanced.
Kerala has problem of increasing ageing population which increases its liability.
Fiscal deficit as well as revenue deficit of Kerala has gone up.
Challenge of managing public sector undertakings especially State Transport Corporation and state electricity board.
Kerala looking forward for a generous and fair allocation of Resources – State suggests an alternative formula for devolution based on population

The Commission has asked political parties, local bodies and representatives from Trade and Industry for their opinion on grant for backward areas and performance grants for local bodies.

Special Refund Fortnight from 31.05.2018 to 14.06.2018
The government has sanctioned more than Rs 30,000 crore for refund of IGST and ITC till now. The amount sanctioned for ITC refund during May 2018 is to the tune of Rs 8,000 cr.
The CBIC has issued a circular no 12/2018 dated 29-05-2018. It will send the incorrect export supplies to the Customs EDI System, which will automatically process the refunds.

Circular No 45/19/2018-GSTGST has been issued on 30th May, 2018 clarifying matters related to refund claims by an Input Service Distributor, composition dealer, exports of services and supplies made to SEZ and restriction imposed under Rule 96(10).
All claimants may note the refund application in FORM GST RFD-01A will not be processed unless a copy of the application is submitted to the jurisdictional tax office.

Project to contribute to improved Budget Execution, enhanced Accountability and greater efficiency in Revenue Administration in Rajasthan.

Auction for Sale (Re-issue) of Government Stocks
Government of India has announced the sale of three tranches of government shares: 6.65%, 7.59% and 6.57% government bonds.

Up to 5% of the notified amount of the sale of the stocks will be allotted to eligible individuals and Institutions as per the Scheme for Non-Competitive Bidding Facility in the Auction of Government Securities.
The competitive and non-competitive bids for the auction should be submitted between 10.30 a.m. and 12.00 p.m., on June 1, 2018.

No change in the GST law and taxation relating to farmers since July, 2017; Support Services to agriculture, forestry, fishing or animal husbandry are exempt from GST;Agriculturists are also exempted from taking GST Registration.

It has been reported in certain section of the Press that certain changes have been made in GST law relating to farmers, which will come into force with effect from 1stJune, 2018 according to which farmers would be required to take registration and pay GST of 18% when they lease out their land.

There has been no change in the law and taxation relating to farmers since July, 2017 when GST was implemented. Rental or leasing of land for agriculture, forestry, fishing, or animal husbandry is not taxed under GST.
Further, agriculturists are also exempted from taking GST registration.Agriculturist has been defined to mean an individual or an HUF who undertakes cultivation of land-
·by servants or wages payable in cash or kind or by hired labour under personal supervision or the personal supervision of any member of the family.

The term of the Task Force constituted to review the existing Income-tax Act, 1961 and draft a new Direct Tax Law in consonance with economic needs of the country has been extended by 3 months.

​Earlier, suggestions and ​f​eedback from the stakeholders and the general public were invited through e-mail atrewriting-itact[at]gov[dot]inlatest by April 2, 2018 in the format provided on the departmental websitewww.incometaxindia.gov.in.
The deadline for sending suggestions and feedback to the Task Force has been extended by three months.
Kerala, the first state in southern India, to be visited by 15th Finance Commission from 28th to 31st May 2018
Kerala has performed well in social sector; however, social sector spending on ageing population will be a matter of concern
The Fifteenth Finance Commission of the Government of India is visiting the state of Kerala from 28th to 31st May 2018.

Kerala is the 10th largest economy in India and contributes around 4.2% of India's GDP. Its GDP grew at 7.4% in 2016-17. The state has one of the highest per capita GDP and per capita income. The growth is mainly driven by the service sector.
NRI remittances have a major role to play in the Kerala economy.
Kerala has been one of the most developed and progressive states in terms of development indicators.
The population above 60 years old is expected to grow at a faster rate than the working age group 15-59 years.
Kerala has the highest literacy level among the states, but learning outcomes are not commensurate.
Kerala is a state where private stage carriages are the mainstay of the public transport system.
The Fifteenth Finance Commission will visit Kerala during its visit.

The Commission will have meetings with Chief Minister, Ministers and other officials of the state. Detailed presentations will be made on the finances of the State Government. The Commission will also meet leaders of political parties and representatives of trade and industry.

Fifteenth Finance Commission constitutes a High Level Group to examine the strengths and weaknesses for enabling balanced expansion of Health Sector

The Fifteenth Finance Commission has constituted a high level group consisting of eminent experts from across the country in Health Sector. Dr. Randeep Guleria, Director, AIIMS, New Delhi, will be its Convenor.
The role and functions of the High Level Groupon Health Sector will be:

To evaluate the existing regulatory framework in the Health sector and examine its strength and weaknesses for enabling a balanced yet faster expansion of the health sector keeping in view India’s demographic profile;
To suggest ways and means to optimize the use of existing financial resources and to incentivize the state governments’ effort on fulfillment of well-defined health parameters in India; and
To holistically examine best international practices for the health sector and seek to benchmark our frameworks to these practices for optimizing benefits keeping in mind our local issues.
High Level Group on Health Sector will have following Convenor and Members:
Dr. RandeepGuleria, Director, AIIMS, New Delhi (Convenor),
Dr. Devi Shetty, Chairman, Narayana Health City, Bengaluru;
Dr. DeelipGovindMhaisekar, Vice Chancellor, Maharashtra University of Health Science, Pune.
Dr. NareshTrehan lives in Medanta City, Gurgaon.
Dr. BhabatoshBiswas, Prof & HOD of Cordio Thoracic Surgery, R.G.Kar Medical College, Kolkata, and Dr.
Prof. K. Srinath Reddy is the President of Public Health Foundation of India.

The father and son have been arrested under CGST Act and remanded to judicial custody for 14 days.

Cabinet approves MoU between India and Turkey on trade inpoppy seeds to ensure quick and transparent processing forimport of poppy seeds from Turkey

The Union Cabinet chaired by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi has approved the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between India and Turkey on trade in poppy seeds to ensure quick and transparent processing for import of poppy seeds from Turkey.

Turkish Grain Board (TMO) shall maintain an online system to enable regulation of export of poppy seeds from Turkey to India. Exporting companies shall submit application through the Agean Exporters Association (EIB).

Each year, the quantity of poppy seeds which shall be imported by India from Turkey shall be decided by Government of India in consultation with Government of Turkey taking into account the production of poppy seeds in Turkey in a crop year, balance from previous crop years and domestic or other export requirement of Republic of Turkey.
The exporting companies shall get registered with the TMO.
Taking into account the quantity as referred to in Para 2 above, every year both parties may consider to set a quantity to be imported by any Indian importer in a crop year.
The Central Bureau of Narcotics (CBN) will register the sales contract registered by TMO as per details accessed on the online system.
The TMO shall provide a legal production certificate for the poppy seeds to exporters following the submission of sales contract and the completion of other necessary procedures.
The Ministry of Agriculture has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with the Turkish government regarding the importation of poppy seeds.
The MoU will ensure continuous availability of poppy seeds in domestic market of India and ultimately Indian consumers of poppy seeds will be benefited.

The importation of poppy seeds from Turkey got delayed due to legal issues. This resulted in a rise in price of the same in domestic market of India and hoarding by importers. An MoU between India and Turkey should be signed to prevent such complications in future.
Extension of time by three months of the Task Force for drafting a New Direct Tax Legislation

The Task Force constituted by the Government of India to review the existing Income-Tax Act, 1961 and draft a new direct tax law in consonance with the economic needs of the country has to submit its report within six months.
The Government has now extended the term of the said Task Force by a period of three months.
One day Regional Conference on “Clean and Renewable Energy” as a lead up event to 3rd Annual Meeting of Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank(AIIB) held in Bhopal;
The report recommends various measures to boost investment in Renewable Energy Sector.

The Minister of New and Renewable Energy, Govt. of Madhya Pradesh, Shri Narayan Singh Kushwah, inaugurated the one day Regional Conference on the theme of "New and renewable energy" in Bhopal. The conference is being held in the lead-up to 3rd Annual Meeting of the Board of Governors of Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) in Mumbai on 25th and 26th June 2018.
The Minister of New and Renewable Energy, Madhya Pradesh, Shri Kushwah, has addressed the conference on clean and renewable energy.
Following are the major outcomes of the discussions held during different Sessions of the one day Conference on ‘Clean and Renewable Energy’ in Bhopal :
There exists immense transformative potential of renewable energy in India both in view of meeting rising energy demand and from the well-being of the society.
Power sector is experiencing profit in certain segments even though the sector as a whole requires a major turnaround.
Per capita energy consumption is rising in India; hence the renewable energy sector would be a supplementary source of energy in the country.
Stringent rigidities in this Sector have to be addressed for better outcomes.
Due to various tax incentives and new initiatives of the Government of India in last 3-4 years, investment in Renewable Energy Sector has increased manifold.
A rational view of markets is needed when planning for any energy transition.
Besides cleaner sources of energy, the clean parameters apply equally to transmission and consumption as well.
Prices of solar and wind energy have gone down.
Renewable energy has become more economical in the recent years than before.
Bankability of projects is the key to attract sustained flow of capital to the RE sector.
Payment Security Fund may be created to deal with the delays in DISCOM payments.
Public Private Partnership (PPP), inventing storage technologies and capacity development etc would be critical for success of investments in the Sector.
International Solar Alliance focuses on massive deployment of technology which would contribute significantly to energy transition and the future energy mix.
Climate change adaptation and mitigation are being factored into energy projects.
Issues in roof-top solar have to be addressed amicably.
Instead of project-based bonds, innovative instruments like bridge equity, patient capital, green bonds may be explored.
De-risking of projects is necessary.
Governance, predictability and rate of return are the three pillars that determine the flow of capital to the RE sector.
Concentration of RE projects in some states necessitates proper RE policy in other states as well.
Viability of distributed panels needs to be addressed.
Integrating different sources of renewable energy is an efficient model of meeting energy demand at affordable prices.
The idea of socializing a part of the costs of RE may be thought of.
Distribution companies can take the responsibility of payment assurance.
Potential of Floating solar can be taken into consideration in the RE mix.
Co-financing, securitization, masala bonds are the possible instruments of raising resources in the markets and tackling financing requirements of the RE sector.
Financing is not the issue, but efficient financing matters.
Geothermal energy is also a potential source of energy in in the North Eastern parts of India.
Disparity in terms of regulatory landscape, capability, potential and willingness across the states.
Challenges of the import dependence and then challenges in terms of technology deployment, financial mechanism, land availability, storage capacity are to be addressed.
IT and government programmes like Make-in India and skill development are crucial for exploiting RE.
There is need for economical financing in order to bring down the tariffs.

The Fifteenth Finance Commission met with economists and domain experts today.
New context post abolition of Planning Commission which has altered the traditional system of resource allocation and consequently abolition of distinction between Plan and Non-Plan funds
Furthermore, issues of uncertainty pertaining to GST needed to be fully factored in.
Issues of rewards for past performance needed to be balanced with incentivizing future performance.
Inadequacy of data and its reliability constituted a significant handicap in realistic revenue projectionand other key variables like employment as well asin determining measurable criteria.
The taxation capacity of states and any formula on devolution needed to be formed by equity, justice and uniformity.
While the TOR were broad ranging, thecommission has significant latitude defining its own procedure of work under the Constitution.
There wereseveral key challenges inmaking robust projections on GDP, pension liability, revenue realization andavailability of resources beyond devolution for grants-in-aid.
State finances were stressed inter alia due to the behavior of Power Sector and implication of UDAY bonds on interest liability of states.
The future of Centrally Sponsored Schemes remained problematic with changing pattern of funding and a holistic view needs to be taken.
The discussion on the devolution of revenue in the commission concluded that further engagement with domain experts will help in firming up the approach.
The Commission was chaired by N. K. Singh and other members were also present.

Cabinet approves signing and ratification of Agreement between India and Brunei Darussalam for the Exchange of Information and Assistance in Collection with respect to Taxes

The Union Cabinet Chaired by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi has has approved the signing and ratification of Agreement between India and Brunei Darussalam for the Exchange of Information and Assistance in Collection with respect to Taxes.

The Agreement enables the competent authorities of India and Brunei Darussalam to provide assistance through exchange of information that is foreseeably relevant to the administration and enforcement of the domestic laws of the two countries concerning taxes covered by this Agreement.

The information received under the Agreement shall be treated as confidential and may be disclosed only to persons or authorities concerned with assessment, collection, enforcement, prosecution or determination of appeals in relation to taxes covered under the agreement.
The Agreement also provides for automatic exchange of information between India and Brunei with respect to categories of cases.
The Agreement also enables assistance in collection of tax revenue claims between both countries.
The Agreement provides for Mutual Agreement Procedure for resolving any difference or for agreeing on procedures under the Agreement.
The Agreement shall enter into force on the date of notification of completion of the procedures required by the respective laws of the two countries for entry into force of the Agreement.
The Agreement aimed at promoting tax cooperation between India and Brunei has been signed.
The Agreement does not have any financial implications. In the event of extraordinary costs exceeding USD 500, the same will be borne by the Government of India.
The Central Government of India and the Government of Brunei Darussalam have reached agreement on the text of the Agreement for the Exchange of Information with respect to taxes.

Time for a dedicated think tank for the North Eastern Region (NER) at the Central Government level;

Need for thrust on Water and Waterways Strength in the Region, Improving Economic Corridors, Digital Technology as the Future of Connectivity, Addressing Infrastructure Deficit as per Local Demand and Needs, Encouraging Grassroots R&D Facilities, Strengthening Regional Value Chains, and Focusing on Clean and Green Energy among others : Outcome of the two day Regional Conference organized by the Ministry of Finance in Guwahati
There should be a dedicated think tank for the North Eastern Region at the Central Government level, according to Prof. Sachin Chaturvedi.
Discussing on the salient takeaways from the consultation of the two day conference, Prof. Chaturvedi said there were several important recommendations.

The North East Region (NER) was once connected to South-East Asia, but the connectivity links were broken after Independence. Now there is a greater recognition of opening the arteries of connectivity within the NER and with neighbouring countries like Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar.

The NITI Aayog has recently launched the ‘NITI Forum for the North East’ which envisages that development projects in the NER will be based on the concept of “HIRA” (Highways, Inland Waterways, Railways, and Airways). Emphasis will be made on Education, Health and Skill Development in the region.
Water is a great strength in NER and should be leveraged in the most optimum manner.
The National Eradication Road Network (NER) aims to extend digital connectivity across the region especially for remote areas.
According to the report by the National Rural Enterprise Research Institute (NER), local development priorities should be considered in the development of infrastructure in NER.
The region needs to have effective research and development (R&D) facilities.

Local industries in NER are losing their competitiveness due to global competition, poor infrastructure and unfavorable government rules and regulations. Agri-based value chains have higher prospects in the NER.
NER has great potential for developing Green and Clean Energy based on generating Solar Energy.
MDBs like World Bank and ADB fund projects in developed States whereas States like Arunachal Pradesh and Sikkim need more resources for infrastructure development.
Prof. Chaturvedi believes that there should be a dedicated think tank for the National Economic Research Institute (NER).

The concluding day was attended by Prof. Bhupen Sarmah, Director, Omeo Kumar Das Institute of Social Change and Development, Shri P R Jaishankar, Chief General Manager, Indian Infrastructure Finance Company Limited, and Dipok Kumar Barthakur, Vice-Chairman, State Innovation & Transformation Aayog.

Before the Valedictory Session, there was Session on “Creating Social Infrastructure for Inclusive Growth” chaired by Shri Dinesh Sharma. Shri Shyam Jagannathan, Commissioner & Secretary, Finance Department, Shri A. K. Yadav, Chief Administrative Officer, Northeast Frontier Railway, Mr. Halla Maher Qaddumi, Senior Water Economist, The World Bank, Sabyasachi Dutta, Executive Director, Asian Confluence, Otojit Kshetrimayum, Associate Fellow and Coordinator, Centre for North East India, V. V. Giri National Labour Institute were present on the occasion.

The 5th Regional Conference of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) was held in Delhi. The next one is going to be held in Bhopal, Pune and Mumbai. The 3rd Annual Meeting of the Board of Governors of AIIB will be hosted in Mumbai on 25th and 26th June 2018.
Atal Pension Yojana subscribers base crosses 1 croremark on completion of 3 years of launch of the Scheme
Atal Pension Yojana (APY) Scheme’s subscriber base has reached 1.10 Crore mark.

Atal Pension Yojana (APY) is a guaranteed pension scheme for citizens of India. It is focused on the unorganised sector workers. The minimum pension is Rs. 1,000/- or 2,000/ 3,000 / 4,000 or 5,000 per month depending on the contributions. The Spouse of the Subscriber is also eligible for pension.

The Pension Fund Regulatory Development Authority (PFRDA) in coordination with the Department of Financial Services, Ministry of Finance and Government of India launched a massive outreach campaign to increase the enrolment in APY.
The Atal Pension Yojana (APY) Scheme has collected around Rs. 3950 crores since its inception.
PFRDA appreciates the efforts taken by banks and DoP for making India a Pensioned Society.

The Governor of Assam inaugurated a seminar on physical and social infrastructure for regional development.

He said that successful Regional Development hinges on connecting remote areas through physical infrastructure and investing in social infrastructure. He also stressed the need to ensure greater participation of women in the development process.
The Governor has concluded his remarks on regional development.

The pre-independence time, North East was prosperous because of good trade routes. However, after Independence, the river routes were completely stopped.
The AIIB is meeting in Arunachal Pradesh.
There is a need to make investments in the right regions to reduce regional disparities, according to Prof Amitabh Kundu and Mr Seshadri Chari.

There was an inauguration ceremony. After the Inaugural Ceremony, a Session on the topic of Infrastructure needs in Aspirational Areas was organized in which various panelists discussed on various issues pertaining to the topic. Prof. Sebastian Morris from the Indian Institute of Management (IIM), Ahmedabad gave the lead presentation.

D Sona, Principal Secretary (Tourism), Government of Arunachal Pradesh, Shri Ravi Capoor, Additional Chief Secretary, Department of Industries and Commerce, Government of Assam, Prof. Manab Majumdar, Deputy Secretary General (DDG), FICCI, Amitabh Kundu, distinguished Fellow, RIS, Miss Laurel Ostfield, Head of Communications, AIIB and Shri Seshadri Chari are attending the function.
Roll out of e-Way Bill system for intra-State movement of goods in the States of Assam & Rajasthan
The e-Way Bill system for inter-State movement of goods has been rolled out from 01st April 2018 to 13th May 2018.
The e-Way Bill system for intra-State movement of goods will be implemented in Assam from 16 May 2018 and in Rajasthan from 20 May 2018.
The roll-out of e-Way Bill system in these States/ Union Territory is expected to facilitate trade and industry.

Customs and Postal Department hold First ever Joint Conference to deliberate on streamlining imports and exports by post; To cater to the SMEs and to boost the Make in India program, Customs Department proposes new simplified procedures for exports through India Post.
Indian Customs and Department of India Posts held a Joint Conference at Vigyan Bhavan in New Delhi yesterday to discuss ways of streamlining imports and exports by post.

Imports and exports by post are the most complained about citizen grievances under CPGRAMs. Customs and Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) have worked together to liberalise, reform and align laws relating to imports and exports. e-commerce exports are allowed through FPOs under MEIS incentives.
C Customs is planning some initiatives to speed up the release of goods and fight smuggling.
